Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed)

well, i'm thinking of thinking out loud right now.  and what i'm  
thinking about is starting one of those podcast radio shows, starring  
who else but good old me, i do a short interview at the beginning,  
take phone calls, or just yell at you about the new world order for 5  
or 10 minutes, then give you like a 45 minute mix of music.  anyway,  
don't expect it soon, and the book's still in pause mode, haven't  
forgotten about that either.

but here's some really great news!  terror storm is now being offered  
in stores.  yes, you can go pick up your copy at borders books or even  
order it off netflix.  this is huge, now i can really say, go watch  
this film, everyone else is doing it.

but we're ravers.  since when did we wait until everyone else is doing  
something?

fog out

TerrorStorm is the DVD of The Resistance!

european distributo left. The three other majors one
in germany and two one england bit the dust more than
2 years ago.

blame it on the laptop and cd dj's who stole music
rather than paid for it.

E

At 07:35 PM 11/1/2006, dangers@yahoo.com wrote:
>http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2006/11/01/BAGF0M3UOQ5.DTL The future of the Castro Halloween celebration is in question that's for sure. Peace, Peter ----- Original Message ---- From: Thomas May <thomas.may@gmail.com> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org Sent: Wednesday, November 1, 2006 7:29:48 PM Subject: Re: [sfraves] castro WTF happen at castro  the 31?  so not  SF style. i never  have felt that vibe in a SF event. 

That's because it's no longer a SF event,  just like Folsom Street Fair.  Both started out as spontaneous, unpermitted queer community events.  Locals.   In the past ten or so years the fists, gay bashers, non-costumed gawkers  and tramplers came from outside the City;  then the knives;  now guns.   Last time I went to the Castro Halloween party in the late nineties a female friend from the east coast was pushed to the ground and trampled by some high-spirited straights.  Fuck it.  Much of the SF vibe is beyond resurrection.

Apollo

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."

X-Scanned-By: MIMEDefang 2.56 on 171.66.118.90
X-Greylist: Sender IP whitelisted, not delayed by milter-greylist-2.0.2 (kzsu.stanford.edu [127.0.0.1]); Thu, 02 Nov 2006 12:33:40 -0800 (PST)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] castro

On 1 November 2006, Apollo wrote:

> That's because it's no longer a SF event, just like Folsom Street 
> Fair.  Both started out as spontaneous, unpermitted queer community 
> events.  Locals.  In the past ten or so years the fists, gay bashers, 
> non-costumed gawkers and tramplers came from outside the City;  then 
> the knives;  now guns.  Last time I went to the Castro Halloween party 
> in the late nineties a female friend from the east coast was pushed to 
> the ground and trampled by some high-spirited straights.  Fuck it. 
> Much of the SF vibe is beyond resurrection.

That's pretty much an observation that really impacted me personally in 
the recent past, pushing me into a somewhat depressed state.  This 
beloved city of San Francisco seems to have lost a fair bit of it's 
luster, for reasons (and attitudes behind those very reasons) Apollo 
stated above.  And I'll dig back up my experience of being on critical 
mass one Friday and passing a live work loft and having someone toss a 
can of something out their window and down toward the riders.  Luckily 
it didn't make impact with anyBODY, merely hitting the ground just in 
front of my front tire instead.  I point out the live/work (yeah right) 
loft aspect of things because the attitude behind that sort of action is 
exactly the attitude that I've experienced from a lot of the people that 
live in those spaces.  To be sure, there's no way to classify them all 
as being that way, but I stand behind saying that a higher proportion of 
that group of people has that mindset.

And I wish it wasn't so.


http://www.joketribe.com

On Nov 2, 2006, at 11:53 AM, Chris Jackson wrote:

> Yeah...Prime Distribution, whom I had a nice P&D deal with for my  
> Refined
> Music label, went belly up too!  They were HUGE!!  I mean fucking
> HUUUUUGE...and still didn't survive.  Times have changed folks, and  
> like
> Eric said, it's because of these damn laptop DJ's and CDR pirates..
> Bastards.  Die.

i wouldn't blame it entirely on pirates and laptop DJs.  i think the  
distribution model has just changed so much that it's too difficult  
for vinyl to compete and make any money.

the download services let you 1) listen from anywhere (i shop for  
tunes while i'm working at my desk, in fact!), 2) buy only the tracks  
you want, not an entire EP to get the 1 good track on it, 3) let you  
get the music right away, with no shipping charges.  it's hard to  
beat that.

-philip-

------=_Part_12554_20176173.1162503263827
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

People can point fingers all day and scapegoat whoever they want, but the
truth of the matter is that vinyl is dying because times change, and
technology changes.

Let's face it, vinyl has a HUGE amount of inherent problems with it,
including: difficulty and expense of manufacture, the fact that it can
scratch easily and become worthless, it's prone to skipping, it's fucking
outrageously expensive ($10+ for 2 songs!?!), it's HEAVY, it requires a
bunch of middlemen (who all want a cut) to get it from the producer to the
consumer (see: Intergroove, Watts, BPM), and god knows how many more reasons
i could think of if i needed to.

The bottom line is, vinyl WILL die.  It's not a question of if, but when. It
will, without a doubt, go the route of the 8-track, cassette, and yes soon
even the almighty CD, until the only people that collect it are nostalgia
freaks clinging to the past. The only people whining about this fact are the
ones that have invested huge amounts of money into what will soon amount to
a bunch of clunky plastic, or people that stand to make money off of said
frisbees.

Walking around these days with a shirt that says "REAL DJs PLAY
VINYL" is the equivalent of a photographer walking around with a shirt that
says "REAL PHOTOGRAPHERS SHOOT FILM".  Well, sorry folks, but digital is
just better. It's pretty much exceed the quality of film, not to
mention it's innumerable other advantages. Show me a pro photographer that
still shoots on film, and I'll show you a man wasting alot of time, money,
and resources.

CDs are the next to go, kids.  Eventually DJs will just plug in their
harddrive, or swipe their card to access their collection from the Supreme
Databank of Everything.  Hell, maybe someday we'll ALL have access to every
song ever recorded.  Then how good of a DJ you are won't be a matter of what
records you can afford or are cool enough to obtain, but actually what mood
or experience you're able to create with the same music that everyone else
has. And I'll bet by then people won't be relying on their ability to
manipulate a turntable either...that's just another thing we'll have made a
machine to do better than we can anyway. I for one won't won't miss the
trainwrecks.

EVOLVE OR DIE. (...like Intergroove, Watts, and BPM just did.)

that's my .02    let the flames begin.


-----> Greg "no, I'm not a DJ" Bird

Subject: Re: Re: [sfraves] the end is near!!!!

however, there are certain things that film cameras can do that digital cannot.

take something like a Lomo camera.  you can make a photoshop filter to
try and replicate the color saturation...but it's not the same.  it's
a cheap, toy, plastic camera...and photographers love it.

vinyl has it's pops and clicks.  you can physically pick up the needle
and drop it anywhere you want.  it's imperfect, and that's what makes
it appealing to people.

ps.  i'm buying legal MP3s and playing CDs more and more these days.

>
> The bottom line is, vinyl WILL die.  It's not a question of if, but when. It
> will, without a doubt, go the route of the 8-track, cassette, and yes soon
> even the almighty CD, until the only people that collect it are nostalgia
> freaks clinging to the past. The only people whining about this fact are the
> ones that have invested huge amounts of money into what will soon amount to
> a bunch of clunky plastic, or people that stand to make money off of said
> frisbees.
>
> Walking around these days with a shirt that says "REAL DJs PLAY
> VINYL" is the equivalent of a photographer walking around with a shirt that
> says "REAL PHOTOGRAPHERS SHOOT FILM".  Well, sorry folks, but digital is
> just better. It's pretty much exceed the quality of film, not to
> mention it's innumerable other advantages. Show me a pro photographer that
> still shoots on film, and I'll show you a man wasting alot of time, money,
> and resources.
>
> CDs are the next to go, kids.  Eventually DJs will just plug in their
> harddrive, or swipe their card to access their collection from the Supreme
> Databank of Everything.  Hell, maybe someday we'll ALL have access to every
> song ever recorded.  Then how good of a DJ you are won't be a matter of what
> records you can afford or are cool enough to obtain, but actually what mood
> or experience you're able to create with the same music that everyone else
> has. And I'll bet by then people won't be relying on their ability to
> manipulate a turntable either...that's just another thing we'll have made a
> machine to do better than we can anyway. I for one won't won't miss the
> trainwrecks.
>
> EVOLVE OR DIE. (...like Intergroove, Watts, and BPM just did.)
>
> that's my .02    let the flames begin.
>
>
> -----> Greg "no, I'm not a DJ" Bird
>
>
>
>
>
> On 11/2/06, Chris Jackson <cjax@sbcglobal.net> wrote:
> >
> > Yeah...Prime Distribution, whom I had a nice P&D deal with for my Refined
> > Music label, went belly up too!  They were HUGE!!  I mean fucking
> > HUUUUUGE...and still didn't survive.  Times have changed folks, and like
> > Eric said, it's because of these damn laptop DJ's and CDR pirates..
> > Bastards.  Die.

Subject: [sfraves] digital photography  (was Re: [sfraves] the end is near!!!!)


On Nov 2, 2006, at 2:04 PM, Bam wrote:

> however, there are certain things that film cameras can do that  
> digital cannot.
>
> take something like a Lomo camera.  you can make a photoshop filter to
> try and replicate the color saturation...but it's not the same.  it's
> a cheap, toy, plastic camera...and photographers love it.

not entirely true.

you can also use a Lomo (or other cheap plastic) lens with a body  
adaptor for your camera.  try it sometime:  http://pikol.blogspot.com/ 
2006/09/my-digital-colorsplash.html has an example

i'm making a home-made tilt/shift lens (cost - $18) and a pinhole  
lens (cost - $5) that will work with our Nikon digital SLR. homemade  
lenses are the new thing with digital photography, btw.  that's how  
you get the funky effects of the old-school film cameras.

Araya still shoots film, but only medium-format with her Hasselblad.   
95% of her professional work these days is digital.  there *are*  
medium-format digital backs out there, but they cost something like  
$30,000:  http://www.luminous-landscape.com/reviews/cameras/ 
valeo22.shtml

Subject: Re: [sfraves] digital photography  (was Re: [sfraves] the end is near!!!!)

Neither of you know *anything* about the Lomo :)

a) when referring to "the Lomo" as a noun describing a specific  
camera, you are talking about the original LCA (Lomo Compact Automat)  
or the almost-released LCA+, not any of the other cameras that the  
Lomographic Society has begun selling.

b) it is neither plastic, nor cheap, nor a toy.

c) the saturation and vignetting effects can almost be photoshopped,  
but at that point you're becoming more "painter" and less "photographer"

Here's a good example of what it does:

http://www.flickr.com/photos/scosol/262480902/

--
"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
AIM:IMFDUP

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Deepfog" <sfgroove@deepfog.com>
To: "The Twilight Laser Outpost (West)" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, November 02, 2006 5:20 PM
Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)


> this is another quote i pulled off the movie freedom to fascism.

> has anything really changed in 80 years?
>
> --
>
> I am a most unhappy man.  I have unwittingly ruined my country.  A  great 
> industrial nation is now controlled by its system of credit.   We are no 
> longer a government by free opinion, no longer a government  by conviction 
> and the vote of the majority, but a government by the  opinion and duress 
> of a small group of dominant men.

Well, we haven't really changed since the establishment of the government 
conceived by Madison.  The US was never intended to be a democracy but a 
polyarchy.  Our government was designed, among many things, "to protect the 
minority of the opulent against the majority" (to quote Madison himself). 
It's inevitable that the mechanisms for protecting the minority of the 
opulent (the senate, electoral college, etc.) would eventually be used a a 
way for them to further their own interests.  Maybe it was even designed 
that way from the start...

However, things have changed in the last 80 years.  Vietnam was one major 
turning point.  It was the time when the politicians woke up and realized 
that they had to contend with the public will as a true force.  And as a 
sidenote, remember who was in the lead of that revolution - the artists, the 
"radical" intellectuals, and the grassroots activists.

Notice that today there is a much greater emphasis on wartime propaganda to 
garner public support.  The government is using both guilt and strong-arm 
tactics to control carefully the form and content of what's being presented 
in the media.  They are also using our "two-party" political system to turn 
support for the war into a partyline game to divert attention away from the 
real issues.  However, I do see all of this as change in a positive 
direction because it shows that our government is at least afraid of what 
the public *might* do if properly motivated.  That doesn't mean we can rest 
and stop pushing for greater reform towards a true democracy.  And since 
public media is being handcuffed, it's still up to artists, radical 
intellectuals, and activists to spread the word... hopefully coherently and 
not while on drugs.  :) 


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] My Halloween WR!!!!! Oh My Goodness man... Soo Dope!

OK.. Friday... took Bus Bus Bart Bart & walked out to Jelly's, i was kinda
hungry, so like i got a good deal of some semi-freshly made 25 pieces of
Sushi for $5 :)  YUM!!!  So YUM!  Then I got invited to go to an Art show
where i kinda grubbed on Cheese, crackers, & grapes... like the art show,
I dunno man... the art kinda sucked... I mean... i dunno... totally IMHO!

So I got to Jelly's.. OK.. YAAAAY...Hello 2day... it was so fun!!  Hangin'
out w/ the Subscience Crew & OK.. Proxy opened up the Jungle area & he had
a sick set... alota old skool 'cause I know he ain't been shopping for new
vinyl lately... I forgot who went up next, oh oh oh wait... Proxy played
Outter Space by Prodigy Heeeeeella sped up & it sounded like totally
HappyHArdCore-ish (which I LOVED) & oooh.. it was Dope!  I hella danced @
that part :P  LOL.. Hello 2Day :)

OK... now like Dave from Aquasky spun & it was an Awesome Awesome fuckin'
Wicked set man!  I Loved it... ok.. but as like he started to like i
mean.. his set was totally coming up & I was totally feeling & dancing
harder!  OK.. then these fuckin' fire Dancers started like hoggin up the
floor & doin' their thing, which i totally woulda appreciated if i wasn't
like so soooooooooo soooooooo sooooo stuck on the Jungle Groove & i was
still dancing... I mean.. no offense to the Fire Dancers, they Rocked it..
but fuck man.. i wanted to Dance!

OK.. here's were things get kinda fuzzy... like i kinda got outta
commision for like 2 hours i think & missed AquaSky's Breaks set &
Gridlock's set.. but i heard they both killed it!  Oh yeah... Dulce Vita's
opening set, Yummy.. nice way to warm up to a Yummy Breaks night!  Bam's
set got me Groovin' hard!  Then like well... last set i remember in that
room was Aaron Jae & MODdie (& MOD kinda looked like hitler during that
time which kinda freaked me out a lil')

Very fun night actually... ya know.. what also kinda touch me that night
was I had a loooooooong talk a/ Dave from Aquasky & turns out... him & I
know alota the same people so we kinda played catch up on who how what is
& stuff :)  So that made my night too :)

Saturday.. FnF/ Urban Wasteland HAlloween Rave....what can i say... a
night full of Family, YUmmy Music, & just Goofy times & Mondo Laughs!  It
was Dope goin' to an Underground that like although it was primarily like
Family populated, it was a fairly mixed crowd!  Alota Burners, a few Bay
Ravers showed up, aloa Newbie Ravers.... oh my gosh.. Reunion w/ like
heeeeeeeella old skool people!!!  Loved it!  I seriously almost nixed gon'
out that night 'cause it was a tiring week & i was tired, but I belonged
there.. i totally did!

Like when UW was like midway through the night & it was @ it's peek... I
dunno man.. Andy briefly mentioned something about this in his post, but
yeah man, there was something totally familiar & old skool about that
night.. I mean.. seriously.. that's how I started in the scene, soin' to
small warehouse parties like where UW was @ or like Loft Raves back in
like 95... so this was like totally nostalgic of like the early days for
me :)  Loved it!  I'm glad i didn't nix goin out...

OK.. yeah.. so CandyFly was there, so was Terri, & ofcourse i asked for a
ride home... they took me home.. (yeah... U know what that means my dear
Groovers), but not 'til we went to another Underground... this time it was
Outdoor :)  So Sunday Morning, right before the Sun Rose into place, we
got to the Fire Trail where ?Brass Trax? was being held.. OK.. lol.. this
was kinda Bizzare.. i mean.. still being crack out (literally) from the
night b4 & tired from dancing & la la la yada yada, i was like
ooooooooooooooooooooh... but i kinda caught a 2nd & met so many Awesome
Strangers.. Made Really Good Friends w/ this English Dude who looked like
the lead singer of an 80's cover band & his Homie who Loves Grime & Jungle
as much as me!  Oooh.. so many people showed up.. I even got to kick it w/
my Homie Rocky who I barely get to see these days & that was Dope :)  I
mean.. talk about the theme for the weekend, the Underground sometimes F8
small warehouse/ Loft/ & even outdoors that i started going to back in the
day was w/ Rocky, literally my oldest Homie in the Scene!
http://i131.photobucket.com/albums/p314/OsbyWonka/halloweenwknd2006/ebssfnfuw075.jpg

^^^^^^^^^that's us ^^^^^^^^^^

Oh yeah... the owner of Temple was there also... Terri went up to him &
introduced herself as his Magenta Twin 'cause they both had on these
Magenta outifts & looked kinda like Zhan & Jana, the Wonder Twins!  I
don't wanna kinx this too much, but i may get a job there @ Temple as
something something as soon as they get all their fuckin' permits &
officially open the fuck up!

Oh oh oh oh oh ohh.. 1 of my mondo biggest Bad Ass Moments that morning
was fiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiinally meeting Jim Cyr :)  YAAAAAAAAAY!!! 
LoLoLoLoL  yeah man... lol... after all these years of bein' neighbors on
the list... lol.. So Dope!!  {{{HUGZ JIM}}}

Yeah... the ride home was kinda hardcore as usual since it was me, Dina,
Terri, & neighbor Mikey who's almost 6'1" but not quite... yeah..
intense...

Oh yeah... pictures.. sorry i didn't get all y'all & stuff... but yeah...
it was a mad fun Hello 2day mondo confuzing time.. LOLOLOLMAO.. !

http://s131.photobucket.com/albums/p314/OsbyWonka/halloweenwknd2006/

LoL... wow.. i'm impressed i wrote such a short WR for 3 days in a row! 
Yeah... sorry for the lack of my WR's... i've kinda been focusing on alota
other stuff lately & haven't had energy to write up my WRs... but i'll
play catch up soon! :)  Love U SFR!!!!  Love U Aryck if you're reading
this!  Love U BRD if you're lurking on here again Fucker!

-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] the end is near!!!!

   if pre recorded music is in question, i'd hate to admit it myself, 
but djing itself is also obsolete. the classic definition of a dj is 
null when you can just set up your ableton live  to premix tracks for 
you while you stand up there pretending to be a dj. why the hell 
bother?sure you can claim that you have to be there to create the right 
kind of vibe for the right moment but you can just as easily tailor your 
ableton or tractor dj to totally slaughter your mixed tracks and remix 
them on the fly which is the same as playing 'live' right? so why bother 
even djing the tracks when you can be more creative and original by 
making your own? djing used to be about hearing new music in the style 
of the dj, in the future i think people will play other people's music 
less and will see more people playing, remixing live and making their 
own tracks. new music will be bought and sold in single format and be 
most likely heard first on your friend's i-pod.

i see that with the recording music industry as a whole as well. i work 
(for the moment) at a dinosaur known as tower records and, haha 
surprise... they are fucking TOAST! music is as cheap and devalued as 
modern art paintings. the industry that supports  musicians is failing 
because  people are poor and lazy. they don't want to pay for that great 
Yes album. they want that 'great' single off the new corinne bailey rae 
album they heard on 'Alice'. they'd rather not buy something they'd not 
like and they'd rather get it for less. they also don't want to carry 
around all that bulk and lose it to the ravages of time and wear or ex 
boyfriends/girlfriends. the industry made all of its money on albums and 
not singles. because you can't justify spending 20 bucks on a single. 
sort of the same way people can't justify paying 12 bucks for an import 
vinyl.

     i think people would not rather pay for *recorded music at all. i 
think instead they would rather go to the concert and see the performer 
live. just as with visual art, you see the painting in a thumbnail 
sketch or in a book but nothing compares to seeing, for example, a 
jackson pollock in person. there's no question. coming next year i can 
guarantee you'll hear somebody new you've never heard before and when 
they come to town the place you see them in will be packed. the artist 
will make less money off of recorded music and more off the door.

 if vinyl is dying, the symbol of our culture is dead as well. the 
technics deck is as synonymous with electronic music as the 4-4 beat 
pattern. nothing will change my love for vinyl and nothing will stop me 
collecting all the old techno (oxymoron?lol) i can find. i mean there 
are people still that have never heard that music and its unlikely to be 
heard on any new format. i still think it is by far the best format for 
music  but i also have to agree, that the scene we are in changes and 
innovates all the time. to stay alive in that scene, you have to roll 
with the changes. the tracks you used to dj aren't as cool as they used 
to be. to keep the scene fresh and innovative and 'techno' you have to 
be accustomed to change. i'm sorry to say, i'm still just starting to 
come to terms with that.

i'll end my rant with a little word of caution..  if downloading from 
beatport is our only option at this point for new music legally i think 
we are doomed to be suckered into buying the same crap as anyone else. 
and in that sense beatport is no more less insidious than any other 
major record industry label.they could push anything they wanted on you. 
if you were to use their tracks for djing purposes you would be sure to 
sound just like every one else who DL's tracks from beatport. if we are 
to exist in the downloaded music age i would really want to see way more 
sources of  music available and the money for the music being paid 
directly to the musician.


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

studying for school).

has a nice flow to it.  don't think i've ever heard you DJ anything
quite like this.  i don't feel like i'm getting slammed over the head
with a hammer...but at the same time it's not light and minimal.
pretty chunky and chugs along nicely.

would like to hear this with a live crowd.  i rarely hear techno when
i go out these days.



On 10/28/06, AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:
>
> One of my biggest regrets in how I've driven things as far as my music was
> taking on a different DJ name and producer name.  This is what we call
> "dumb branding".  If you're a DJ that has played for thousands of people
> over the years, don't flush that down the toilet when you start putting
> records out.
>
> So in any case, I put records out and play live as an entity called Mutor.
> I've kinda decided I might still use that name but I'm gonna be better
> about making sure the link is more obvious.  I should have done it from
> the start except that the stuff I make and the stuff I spin are slightly
> different animals.
>
> Well, in any case, I've been playing live PAs since 1998 or so and got
> tracks out on a few labels, and actually did production work long before I
> ever thought turntables were anything but an archaic media playback
> system.
>
> Here's a little something something I busted out with a few years ago, a
> live techno set.  No tracklisting CAUSE I WROTE EVERY SINGLE NOTE
> MUTHAFUKKAS (ok, maybe a little bob marley sample towards the end...).
> Set played from Ableton Live (and regrettably, a stupid setting munges up
> one of my favorite parts at around 12:00 or so... stupid timestretching
> settings), on a G3 pismo with a UC-33 controller using a Gigaport AG audio
> output (allowing me to feed multiple channels on a mixer so I can still
> use EQ and crossfader from the mixer).  That's my "light setup", which
> allowed me to play live sets with plenty of control on a setup that fit in
> a backpack.
>
> http://www.saturn5.com/andy/andyw-LiveAtHuggermugger.mp3
>
> Meh.

JUST IN TIME FOR THE ELECTION! 

J-Boogie (Dubtronic Science) and Deuce Eclipse (Zion I) release a new political video addressing the immigrant rights issue and the struggle for freedom.

Dropping science alongside footage of protests, border patrol agents, detainees, workers, revolutionaries and musicians, J-Boogie and Deuce Eclipse take on the Minute Men in the newest music video release from
J-Boogies Dubtronic Science: Que Pasa. 

The Latin Hip-Hop sound of Que Pasa features bilingual rap, Latin percussion, Cumbia horns, and a very special spoken word piece. The poem La Reunion speaks to people who want to be free. It asks to unite
in strength for a day of justice. The musical message is strong and Om Records has teamed up with Peek Media, Pepelicula and Monday Night Laundry to create a video that reflects the minds of many. 

The song will be included on J-Boogies Dubtronic Science sophomore album coming this spring 2007 featuring Zion I, Jennifer Johns, Lunar Heights, Rebirth, Raashan Ahmad and more. Check out the video and.... 

We urge you to get out and vote! Check out theballot.org for progressive information brought to you by the league of young voters. 

The music video Que Pasa is available on Youtube, Google Video and MySpace!

Subject: [sfraves] Welcome to Wonderland

--=====================_28362390==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Welcome to Wonderland
(film documentary review by Graham St John)

Welcome to Wonderland is unique in the world of psy-trance films. I've viewed many psy-trance documentaries in recent times. Most are promotional, endorsements for event organisations or particular artists. Some are full of bravado, bristling with machismo and boasters embodied by DJs portrayed as shaman priests. But if shamanic consciousness is apparent in psy-trance, and quite a few propose that it is, it would be discovered right there on the dance floor: where egos are dissolved, limits trespassed and identities transformed. Like no other film on psy-trance culture Welcome to Wonderland penetrates this difficult membrane, exposes the organic machinery, capturing the heart of dance, or more specifically, the social characteristics of modern trance dance.

James Short's film about the Melbourne psy-trance scene, a product of 6 years work, does not sell itself as an ethnographic film - but it passes as one nevertheless. And it does so because it is a grassroots film, dedicated in its pursuit of a milieu of people from various backgrounds and ages, through some of the most outrageous, intimate and self-annihilating moments of their lives. Recording comments and gesticulations with careful attention to detail cut to a fine sound track, the film enables participants to narrate their stories and allows viewers access to the 'participation mystique' momentarily transparent in the primal real estate between the speaker stacks at majestic bush and forest locations at Australia's Rainbow Serpent and Earthcore Festivals. The film records a momentous locomotional transit into the new millennium at the Earthcore Millennial party at Lake Eildon. With a great score that includes work by Sugar and Ben Last, and an excellent series of dance montage
s and interviews, this film should not be missed by any trance enthusiast or indeed anyone interested in electronic dance music culture.

More about the film: and view the trailer:
http://www.welcometowonderland.com/

-- 




http://www.asambleapopulardeoaxaca.com/

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

"Americans like to talk about (or be told about) Democracy but, when put to the test, usually find it to be an 'inconvenience.' We have opted instead for an authoritarian system disguised as a Democracy. We pay through the nose for an enormous joke-of-a-government, let it push us around, and then wonder how all those assholes got in there." - Frank Zappa 

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Evinrude originally sent this out.  Hope he doesn't mind the forward!
In the end he mentions the 51% expected turnout.  I certainly wish there=20
was more support, or more strength, in the Progressive and Libertarian=20
camps.  Maybe that stat would be a lot different.


---------- Forwarded message ----------

Hi all,

I hope you don't mind me abusing this list to urge you to vote. This time, =
I
feel it's important enough. I'm hoping I can convince just a few people, wh=
o
may otherwise not have bothered, to get up and go to the polls today.

I personally always vote. But a lot of people I know don't ever vote, or
don't do it very often.

It's especially bad with these non-presidential elections, which some peopl=
e
view as less important. In fact, this one's really important. I've seen a
few people state in the press that this is the most important election of
the past two decades. Although I can't find a link, and it seems that they
often say this, I believe this one really is key.

Why? Because there are some ballot measures that are truly horrendous, whic=
h
could have awful consequenses if implemented. Like Prop. 85 which would
require parental notification for abortions. The disastrous implications of
this proposition going through are obvious. And Prop. 90, which the Guardia=
n
calls "by far the worst item on the November California ballot, a draconian
measure that could potentially eliminate a wide range of government
regulations =97 from rent control and zoning to workplace safety and
environmental laws =97 and bankrupt local agencies that in any way try to
limit what a property owner can do with land or buildings."

And there are some really great ones which could have some really positive
effects. Prop. 84 would send $5.4 billion (one of the largest environmental
preservation bonds in history) to preserving forests, beaches and waterways=
,
as well as rebuilding dikes and levees (parts of the Delta are another New
Orleans waiting to happen). And Prop. 87, which would tax oil companies,
making them pay their fair share and earning California $4 billion a year =
=96
ALL of which would be spent on alternative energy programs (and A full 58
percent of which would go toward incentives for the purchase of
alternative-fuel vehicles, incentives for producers to supply alternative
fuels, and grants and loans for private research). It's time to start
getting off of our massive addiction to oil, and this is a great step
towards that.

And who to vote for? If I even have to tell you not to vote Republican,
remind me to perform flying wrestling body-slam type moves on you (or at
least a few flicks in the ear) next time I see you. (P.S.: Angelides is
actually a great candidate, who really only wants to raise taxes on the ver=
y
rich. It's ridiculous that Arnold is probably going to win this one.)

If you don't know who/what to vote for, I personally usually agree with mos=
t
of what the Guardian recommends, with a few exceptions. Here are their
endorsements this year:

www.sfbg.com/entry.php<http://www.sfbg.com/entry.php?entry_id=3D1767&catid=
=3D&volume_id=3D254&issue_id=3D259&volume_num=3D41&issue_num=3D05>

Please vote. 51% is the expected voter turnout at the polls today, and
that's baaaaaad. And it seems that it's always the liberals who don't turn
out. Maybe it's because we have all the stoners, the anarchists, the
skeptics who don't believe the system even works. I don't know. But really,
what do you have to lose? It's 20 minutes out of your day. And a lot is at
stake this year.

Thanks for reading my rant!

-E


http://www.joketribe.com
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

"The difference between Iraq and Vietnam is that Bush had a plan to
get out of Vietnam."

--=20
"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Please VOTE today! This time, let's actually do it. (fwd)

IMO, Prop 87 may be one of the most important on the list and a reason to go 
vote by itself.  I'm not super-thrilled by it.  It's actually only $4B over 
ten years and I wish the incentives for alt-fuel vehicles and university 
grants was a higher percent.  But let's not fool ourselves.  It's more or 
less a gas tax and we'll probably see a small ($4B over 10 years is not a 
lot to the bottomline) impact at the pump.  Although it says it will be 
illegal to pass the costs to consumers, there's just no way the suits at 
Chevron are going to get outsmarted by the public officials on the 
equalization board.

But I'm for it because it's been long overdue.  We need to start 
aggressively taxing activities that consume our public resources (like clean 
air and a healthy planet) without penalty today.  I really do see this as a 
major leap forward in *practical* environmental reform.

See you at the polls!



----- Original Message -----

ALL of which would be spent on alternative energy programs (and A full 58
percent of which would go toward incentives for the purchase of
alternative-fuel vehicles, incentives for producers to supply alternative
fuels, and grants and loans for private research).

From: Nathan Seven <scosol@scosol.org>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Please VOTE today! This time, let's actually do it. (fwd)

Well- here's my quick guide-

VOTE NO ON EVERYTHING EXCEPT 1A  and 90 :)
1A says that gas taxes have to be spend on roads etc
90 is important in the defense of private property rights.

All those bond measures?  CA does not have a revenue problem, it has  
a *spending* problem...
I have no desire to get further and further in to debt so more poorly- 
overseen programs can be funded.

89- the "fair election" one?  It is a power grab by the nurses  
organization- with all it's messaging about "get big money out of  
elections", it is actually worded so that corporations' donations get  
severely cut, but... surprise surprise - "organizations" like the  
nurses are still able to effectively donate large sums

87- the tax on oil company drilling?  Gasoline consumption needs to  
be addressed on the *consumption* side, not the production side- hell  
I'm all for a $3 direct-to-consumer gas tax to reduce consumption, -  
make gas got $6- $10- I don't care!  But that's not what this is.  It  
is being positioned as some sort of big stab-back-at-big-oil-with- 
their-big-profits so people who don't like high gas prices can feel  
good- and what does it do? It makes oil more expensive to produce IN  
california, making it cheaper to IMPORT in to ca.  No wonder that  
this is backed by... wait for it... a huge ethanol entrepreneur!!!

here's a great writeup: http://i-r-squared.blogspot.com/2006/08/ 
californias-proposition-87.html

Unfortunately- organizations, people, and corporations have *forever*  
been foisting legislation upon us under the guise of great-sounding- 
things- do NOT let yourself be a fucking sheep.
READ THE MEASURES
READ THE ARGUMENTS ON BOTH SIDES OF THEM
FOLLOW THE MONEY

--
"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
AIM:IMFDUP

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Please VOTE today! This time, let's actually do it. (fwd)


----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Nathan Seven" <scosol@scosol.org>
> 87- the tax on oil company drilling?  Gasoline consumption needs to  be 
> addressed on the *consumption* side, not the production side- hell

Well, it doesn't really matter where you tax it.  It has the same effect 
from an economic standpoint.

> I'm all for a $3 direct-to-consumer gas tax to reduce consumption, -  make 
> gas got $6- $10- I don't care!  But that's not what this is.  It  is being 
> positioned as some sort of big stab-back-at-big-oil-with- 
> their-big-profits so people who don't like high gas prices can feel  good- 
> and what does it do?

That's how it's being marketed but that isn't how it will work.  The impact 
is too small to be a big stab in the back.  Mostly, it's about siphoning a 
little bit of profits and channeling it towards alt-fuel incentives.  How it 
is being marketed is unfortunate but a sign of the times.

> It makes oil more expensive to produce IN  california, making it cheaper 
> to IMPORT in to ca.

Maybe.  Again, the impact is so small I really doubt it is going to create 
huge incentives to drill less in CA.

> No wonder that  this is backed by... wait for it... a huge ethanol 
> entrepreneur!!!

Yeah, it's backed by a lot of rich people who have investments in alt-fuel 
research.  Like Vinod Khosla.  Only 10% of it goes to directly to them as 
venture funding.  Most of it goes to alt-fuel car buyers (~60%) and 
fundamental research at universities.  It's a good thing because without 
grant money, a lot of this research would never happen.  Yeah, someone is 
going to get rich from it.  That's how America works best.

> here's a great writeup: http://i-r-squared.blogspot.com/2006/08/ 
> californias-proposition-87.html
>
> Unfortunately- organizations, people, and corporations have *forever* 
> been foisting legislation upon us under the guise of great-sounding- 
> things- do NOT let yourself be a fucking sheep.
> READ THE MEASURES
> READ THE ARGUMENTS ON BOTH SIDES OF THEM
> FOLLOW THE MONEY

I've read it. I've studied it.  And I have my reservations.  It's not 
perfect but it's better than doing nothing because as long as we do nothing, 
polluters get a FREE RIDE.  Pollution in classic economic terms is an 
externality and every economist agree that even a perfectly efficient market 
does not function perfectly in the presence of an externality.  Most 
economists agree that dealing with externalities require some kind of 
legislation to internalize the costs.  That's why I'm for this measure. 


---------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Please VOTE today! This time, let's actually do it. (fwd)

On Nov 7, 2006, at 2:37 PM, J.C. wrote:

> this proposition going through are obvious. And Prop. 90, which the =20=

> Guardian
> calls "by far the worst item on the November California ballot, a =20
> draconian
> measure that could potentially eliminate a wide range of government
> regulations =97 from rent control and zoning to workplace safety and
> environmental laws =97 and bankrupt local agencies that in any way =20
> try to
> limit what a property owner can do with land or buildings."

Since I didn't specifically talk about prop 90 beyond recommending =20
it, I figure I should-

That is a bunch of BS- this is what the law says today:

Say you have a house, and the city says "we're building a new freeway =20=

and taking your house"
Ok- fine- you get paid fair market value for your house.

What Prop 90 adds is fair compensation for *use* restrictions-

As in- say you buy a small commercially-zoned empty space for $100k.
Then, the city decides to rezone it to residential-only, and now =20
because of that your shop is only worth $50k as a residence and you =20
can't build your shop.

Under current law, you just got screwed out of $50k.
Under Prop 90, you would be compensated for your loss.

It doesn't restrict any ability to pass any rent control, =20
environmental measures, or anything else.
It merely compensates the owners of the property for any loss they incur

--
"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
AIM:IMFDUP

On Nov 7, 2006, at 4:34 PM, J C wrote:

>> No wonder that  this is backed by... wait for it... a huge ethanol  
>> entrepreneur!!!

> Yeah, it's backed by a lot of rich people who have investments in  
> alt-fuel research.  Like Vinod Khosla.  Only 10% of it goes to  
> directly to them as venture funding.  Most of it goes to alt-fuel  
> car buyers (~60%) and fundamental research at universities.  It's a  
> good thing because without grant money, a lot of this research  
> would never happen.  Yeah, someone is going to get rich from it.   
> That's how America works best.

I guess we differ then on how "America works best"- I believe that it  
works best in an arena of fair competition, not by duping voters in  
to taxing my competitors to subsidize my own interests.

> I've read it. I've studied it.  And I have my reservations.  It's  
> not perfect but it's better than doing nothing because as long as  
> we do nothing, polluters get a FREE RIDE.

That's one way to look at it, but I think that this kind of thinking  
is what has put us in to the entire political situation we are in  
today.  Instead of demanding real change, the continued passing of  
dubious half-measures only encourages the introduction of... more  
dubious half-measures.

Haha- you know what? forget it- instead of bitching about the system,  
I should just take advantage of it and start introducing some  
legislation! :D

I'm voting no on all the props!

ethanol is a terrible alternative fuel.  I'm all for reducing our 
dependency on crude, but 87 is not the way to do it.

90 protects land owners.. but the small fries don't really 
matter.  What matters is the mega developers, who will be compensated 
whenever a municipality changes zoning of an area, for any reason... 
out of tax payers' pockets.

there's a good write up of the props in the express:

http://www.eastbayexpress.com/Issues/2006-11-01/news/feature6_full.html


sarilion

> >nurses are still able to effectively donate large sums
> >
> >87- the tax on oil company drilling?  Gasoline consumption needs to
> >be addressed on the *consumption* side, not the production side- hell
> >I'm all for a $3 direct-to-consumer gas tax to reduce consumption, -
> >make gas got $6- $10- I don't care!  But that's not what this is.  It
> >is being positioned as some sort of big stab-back-at-big-oil-with-
> >their-big-profits so people who don't like high gas prices can feel
> >good- and what does it do? It makes oil more expensive to produce IN
> >california, making it cheaper to IMPORT in to ca.  No wonder that
> >this is backed by... wait for it... a huge ethanol entrepreneur!!!
> >
> >here's a great writeup: http://i-r-squared.blogspot.com/2006/08/
> >californias-proposition-87.html
> >
> >Unfortunately- organizations, people, and corporations have *forever*
> >been foisting legislation upon us under the guise of great-sounding-
> >things- do NOT let yourself be a fucking sheep.
> >READ THE MEASURES
> >READ THE ARGUMENTS ON BOTH SIDES OF THEM
> >FOLLOW THE MONEY
> >
> >--
> >"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
> >AIM:IMFDUP
> >
> >
> >
> >On Nov 7, 2006, at 3:47 PM, J C wrote:
> >
> >>IMO, Prop 87 may be one of the most important on the list and a
> >>reason to go vote by itself.  I'm not super-thrilled by it.  It's
> >>actually only $4B over ten years and I wish the incentives for alt-
> >>fuel vehicles and university grants was a higher percent.  But
> >>let's not fool ourselves.  It's more or less a gas tax and we'll
> >>probably see a small ($4B over 10 years is not a lot to the
> >>bottomline) impact at the pump.  Although it says it will be
> >>illegal to pass the costs to consumers, there's just no way the
> >>suits at Chevron are going to get outsmarted by the public
> >>officials on the equalization board.
> >>
> >>But I'm for it because it's been long overdue.  We need to start
> >>aggressively taxing activities that consume our public resources
> >>(like clean air and a healthy planet) without penalty today.  I
> >>really do see this as a major leap forward in *practical*
> >>environmental reform.
> >>
> >>See you at the polls!
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >>----- Original Message ----- From: "J.C." <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu>
> >>And Prop. 87, which would tax oil companies,
> >>making them pay their fair share and earning California $4 billion
> >>a year -
> >>ALL of which would be spent on alternative energy programs (and A
> >>full 58
> >>percent of which would go toward incentives for the purchase of
> >>alternative-fuel vehicles, incentives for producers to supply
> >>alternative
> >>fuels, and grants and loans for private research).

> matter.  What matters is the mega developers, who will be compensated
> whenever a municipality changes zoning of an area, for any reason...
> out of tax payers' pockets.

> >1A says that gas taxes have to be spend on roads etc
> >90 is important in the defense of private property rights.
> >
> >All those bond measures?  CA does not have a revenue problem, it has
> >a *spending* problem...
> >I have no desire to get further and further in to debt so more
> >poorly- overseen programs can be funded.
> >
> >89- the "fair election" one?  It is a power grab by the nurses
> >organization- with all it's messaging about "get big money out of
> >elections", it is actually worded so that corporations' donations get
> >severely cut, but... surprise surprise - "organizations" like the
> >nurses are still able to effectively donate large sums
> >
> >87- the tax on oil company drilling?  Gasoline consumption needs to
> >be addressed on the *consumption* side, not the production side- hell

> >is being positioned as some sort of big stab-back-at-big-oil-with-

> >good- and what does it do? It makes oil more expensive to produce IN
> >california, making it cheaper to IMPORT in to ca.  No wonder that

> >I have no desire to get further and further in to debt so more
> >poorly- overseen programs can be funded.
> >
> >89- the "fair election" one?  It is a power grab by the nurses
> >organization- with all it's messaging about "get big money out of
> >elections", it is actually worded so that corporations' donations get
> >severely cut, but... surprise surprise - "organizations" like the
> >nurses are still able to effectively donate large sums
> >
> >87- the tax on oil company drilling?  Gasoline consumption needs to
> >be addressed on the *consumption* side, not the production side- hell
> >I'm all for a $3 direct-to-consumer gas tax to reduce consumption, -
> >make gas got $6- $10- I don't care!  But that's not what this is.  It
> >is being positioned as some sort of big stab-back-at-big-oil-with-
> >their-big-profits so people who don't like high gas prices can feel
> >good- and what does it do? It makes oil more expensive to produce IN
> >california, making it cheaper to IMPORT in to ca.  No wonder that
> >this is backed by... wait for it... a huge ethanol entrepreneur!!!
> >
> >here's a great writeup: http://i-r-squared.blogspot.com/2006/08/
> >californias-proposition-87.html
> >
> >Unfortunately- organizations, people, and corporations have *forever*
> >been foisting legislation upon us under the guise of great-sounding-
> >things- do NOT let yourself be a fucking sheep.
> >READ THE MEASURES
> >READ THE ARGUMENTS ON BOTH SIDES OF THEM
> >FOLLOW THE MONEY
> >
> >--
> >"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
> >AIM:IMFDUP
> >
> >
> >
> >On Nov 7, 2006, at 3:47 PM, J C wrote:
> >
> >>IMO, Prop 87 may be one of the most important on the list and a
> >>reason to go vote by itself.  I'm not super-thrilled by it.  It's
> >>actually only $4B over ten years and I wish the incentives for alt-
> >>fuel vehicles and university grants was a higher percent.  But
> >>let's not fool ourselves.  It's more or less a gas tax and we'll
> >>probably see a small ($4B over 10 years is not a lot to the
> >>bottomline) impact at the pump.  Although it says it will be
> >>illegal to pass the costs to consumers, there's just no way the
> >>suits at Chevron are going to get outsmarted by the public
> >>officials on the equalization board.
> >>
> >>But I'm for it because it's been long overdue.  We need to start
> >>aggressively taxing activities that consume our public resources
> >>(like clean air and a healthy planet) without penalty today.  I
> >>really do see this as a major leap forward in *practical*
> >>environmental reform.
> >>
> >>See you at the polls!
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >>----- Original Message ----- From: "J.C."
> >>And Prop. 87, which would tax oil companies,
> >>making them pay their fair share and earning California $4 billion
> >>a year -
> >>ALL of which would be spent on alternative energy programs (and A
> >>full 58
> >>percent of which would go toward incentives for the purchase of
> >>alternative-fuel vehicles, incentives for producers to supply
> >>alternative
> >>fuels, and grants and loans for private research).

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Please VOTE today! This time, let's actually do it. (fwd)

Yeah, the governator thing was too much of a given to be any kind of  
surprise or too much of a disappointment.  It was more of a "it's our  
cross to bear" thing that I was kind of resigned to at that point.   
The bright point, I read in an article though, is that after this  
time, term limits make him ineligible for re-election.  And, of  
course, being foreign-born, he can't run for president.  So this  
particular republican bigot's political career is at an end.

Where I was disappointed was more in the propositions than the  
races.  I really thought that California had the integrity and gonads  
to stand up to the oil and tobacco corporations; and to likewise  
support the health care and alternative energy research funding that  
would have gone with that courage.

Oh well, can't win 'em all, I guess.  And nothing says we can't try,  
again and harder, next time around.  And other than props 86 and 87,  
(And, of course, Schwarzenegger.), I am pretty happy overall with the  
outcome.

Now, if only we keep our fingers crossed for that virginia recount...


cya,
john

On 8 November 2006, John B wrote:

> Yeah, the governator thing was too much of a given to be any kind of surprise 
> or too much of a disappointment.  It was more of a "it's our cross to bear" 
> thing that I was kind of resigned to at that point.  The bright point, I read 
> in an article though, is that after this time, term limits make him 
> ineligible for re-election.  And, of course, being foreign-born, he can't run 
> for president.  So this particular republican bigot's political career is at 
> an end.

Not exactly.  He could run for House or Senate.

>
> Where I was disappointed was more in the propositions than the races.  I 
> really thought that California had the integrity and gonads to stand up to 
> the oil and tobacco corporations; and to likewise support the health care and 
> alternative energy research funding that would have gone with that courage.

I think this may have likely been an issue of verbage of the 
propositions more than anything else.  And of course actually getting 
people to vote to tax themselves is often pretty difficult. :)

> At 04:13 PM 11/7/2006, Nathan Seven wrote:
> >Well- here's my quick guide-
> >
> >VOTE NO ON EVERYTHING EXCEPT 1A and 90 :)
> >1A says that gas taxes have to be spend on roads etc
> >90 is important in the defense of private property rights.
> >
> >All those bond measures? CA does not have a revenue problem, it has
> >a *spending* problem...
> >I have no desire to get further and further in to debt so more
> >poorly- overseen programs can be funded.
> >
> >89- the "fair election" one? It is a power grab by the nurses
> >organization- with all it's messaging about "get big money out of
> >elections", it is actually worded so that corporations' donations get
> >severely cut, but... surprise surprise - "organizations" like the
> >nurses are still able to effectively donate large sums
> >
> >87- the tax on oil company drilling? Gasoline consumption needs to
> >be addressed on the *consumption* side, not the production side- hell
> >I'm all for a $3 direct-to-consumer gas tax to reduce consumption, -
> >make gas got $6- $10- I don't care! But that's not what this is. It
> >is being positioned as some sort of big stab-back-at-big-oil-with-
> >their-big-profits so people who don't like high gas prices can feel
> >good- and what does it do? It makes oil more expensive to produce IN
> >california, making it cheaper to IMPORT in to ca. No wonder that
> >this is backed by... wait for it... a huge ethanol entrepreneur!!!
> >
> >here's a great writeup: http://i-r-squared.blogspot.com/2006/08/
> >californias-proposition-87.html
> >
> >Unfortunately- organizations, people, and corporations have *forever*
> >been foisting legislation upon us under the guise of great-sounding-
> >things- do NOT let yourself be a fucking sheep.
> >READ THE MEASURES
> >READ THE ARGUMENTS ON BOTH SIDES OF THEM
> >FOLLOW THE MONEY
> >
> >--
> >"Jupiter accepts your offer..."

> >
> >

> >>IMO, Prop 87 may be one of the most important on the list and a
> >>reason to go vote by itself. I'm not super-thrilled by it. It's
> >>actually only $4B over ten years and I wish the incentives for alt-
> >>fuel vehicles and university grants was a higher percent. But
> >>let's not fool ourselves. It's more or less a gas tax and we'll
> >>probably see a small ($4B over 10 years is not a lot to the
> >>bottomline) impact at the pump. Although it says it will be
> >>illegal to pass the costs to consumers, there's just no way the
> >>suits at Chevron are going to get outsmarted by the public
> >>officials on the equalization board.
> >>
> >>But I'm for it because it's been long overdue. We need to start
> >>aggressively taxing activities that consume our public resources
> >>(like clean air and a healthy planet) without penalty today. I
> >>really do see this as a major leap forward in *practical*
> >>environmental reform.

I gather from what you're saying Allen took Virginia?

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:  You are buying into the rhetoric. Not one of these things has happened yet. And IMO a lot of it probably won't happen.

The Democrats control the House but not the Senate as I understand it. According to CNN, they picked up five Senate seats, bringing the Senate to 50 Democrats and 50 Republicans. However VP Dick Cheney is the tie breaker.

If I remember correctly a bill needs to pass both the House and Senate to become a law, see http://www.school-house-rock.com/Bill.html

And Bush still has the veto.

> >nurses are still able to effectively donate large sums

Subject: [sfraves] Funk, breakbeat, hip-house, house & hip-hop vinyl for sale....

Here's a rack of VERY tasty choons, most on the funked tip, some straight up 
funk, some house, some reakbeat, some hip-hop & hip-house - but all from the 
same flavor. Tinged with latin, hammond organs, live percussion etc., if you 
like your shit funky - snatch up some tunes!

All 12"s are firmly priced at $6 each , which is a steal considering they're 
all practically brand new.

These are FIRST COME FIRST SERVE - I won't hold them for more than a couple 
days at a pop. If you want anything shipped, there'll be a shipping/handling 
fee.

Without further adieu - the list:


1. Ursula 1000 - Boop/Kaboom (w/ All Good Funk Alliance & Skeewiff mixes) - 
ESL Music
2. A-Skillz & Krafty Kuts - Tricka Technology (feat. TC Izlam)/Ain't It 
Funky (Roll Over Baby)/Gimme The Breaks (Feat. Kurtis Blow) - Finger Lickin'

rerub) - promo

Recordings

Funk Alliance) - Fort Knox Recordings

Weapons

Innvision Records

mix)/Skeewiff's "Now I'm Living For Me" (FK5 mix) - Fort Knox Recordings
10. Fort Knox 5 - The Big Score EP - Fort Knox Recordings
11. Fort Knox 5 - Blowing Up The Barrio EP - Fort Knox Recordings
12. Fort Knox 5 - The Brazilain Hipster (w/ Dr. Rubberfunk mixes) - Fort 
Knox Recordings

Recordings
14. Fort Knox 5 - Radio Free DC EP (W/ Afrika Bambaataa) - Fort Knox 
Recordings
15. Geriba - So High (A.G.F.A. mix)/Guaranteed (w/ Clayton & Fulton remix) - 
Funk Weapons

Funk Weapons
17. Dr. Delay - The Limitations EP (w/ A.G.F.A. remix) - Funk Weapons

Citrona

> out of tax payers' pockets.

> >
> >VOTE NO ON EVERYTHING EXCEPT 1A and 90 :)
> >1A says that gas taxes have to be spend on roads etc
> >90 is important in the defense of private property rights.
> >
> >All those bond measures? CA does not have a revenue problem, it has
> >a *spending* problem...
> >I have no desire to get further and further in to debt so more
> >poorly- overseen programs can be funded.
> >
> >89- the "fair election" one? It is a power grab by the nurses
> >organization- with all it's messaging about "get big money out of
> >elections", it is actually worded so that corporations' donations get
> >severely cut, but... surprise surprise - "organizations" like the
> >nurses are still able to effectively donate large sums
> >
> >87- the tax on oil company drilling? Gasoline consumption needs to
> >be addressed on the *consumption* side, not the production side- hell
> >I'm all for a $3 direct-to-consumer gas tax to reduce consumption, -
> >make gas got $6- $10- I don't care! But that's not what this is. It
> >is being positioned as some sort of big stab-back-at-big-oil-with-
> >their-big-profits so people who don't like high gas prices can feel
> >good- and what does it do? It makes oil more expensive to produce IN
> >california, making it cheaper to IMPORT in to ca. No wonder that
> >this is backed by... wait for it... a huge ethanol entrepreneur!!!
> >
> >here's a great writeup: http://i-r-squared.blogspot.com/2006/08/
> >californias-proposition-87.html
> >
> >Unfortunately- organizations, people, and corporations have *forever*
> >been foisting legislation upon us under the guise of great-sounding-
> >things- do NOT let yourself be a fucking sheep.
> >READ THE MEASURES
> >READ THE ARGUMENTS ON BOTH SIDES OF THEM
> >FOLLOW THE MONEY
> >
> >--
> >"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
> >AIM:IMFDUP
> >
> >
> >
> >On Nov 7, 2006, at 3:47 PM, J C wrote:
> >
> >>IMO, Prop 87 may be one of the most important on the list and a
> >>reason to go vote by itself. I'm not super-thrilled by it. It's
> >>actually only $4B over ten years and I wish the incentives for alt-
> >>fuel vehicles and university grants was a higher percent. But
> >>let's not fool ourselves. It's more or less a gas tax and we'll
> >>probably see a small ($4B over 10 years is not a lot to the
> >>bottomline) impact at the pump. Although it says it will be
> >>illegal to pass the costs to consumers, there's just no way the
> >>suits at Chevron are going to get outsmarted by the public
> >>officials on the equalization board.
> >>

> >>aggressively taxing activities that consume our public resources

> >>environmental reform.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Please VOTE today! This time, let's actually do it. (fwd)



If nothing else, the election has broken Bush's iron grip on this nations
levers of power.

C'mon people, aren't you down with the blog-ohh-sphere?  Democratic Webb
is up by 7,000 votes in Virginia, but that is close enough that Republican
Allen can demand a state-sponsored recount, which he most certianly will.

But, judging from the history in Florida, it is unlikely a recount will sway
the election back to Republican Allen.

If the vote in Virginia stands, the Democrats will have 51 votes in the 
Senate, if you include the two independents (Leiberman, and.. Jeffords?)

The Democrats swept the elections, and they now have full control of the 
policy agenda.  Lets wish them well for the sake of the nation.

Yesterday was a truly inspiring day for democracy.  It restores a lot of faith
in my country.

-troy





On Wed, Nov 08, 2006 at 03:31:42PM -0800, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> That's what CNN is saying, not me.  Hell if I know.  If it goes the other way, you still have to ensure that no Democrats defect and then there's still the presidential veto.  I guess we'll see what happens.
> 
> Not to be a downer or whatever, but our system tends to prevent big sudden changes in policy for better or worse.  When you get a different party in the Whitehouse from the one controlling Congress, often things just grind to a halt with conflict and nothing much happens at all.  At least that's my recollection of what has happened in the past.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Please VOTE today! This time, let's actually do it.
 (fwd)


Erm, the "standing up to the oil and tobacco corporations" is a funny way 
to put taxing their consumers.

Drill fees, standing up to major car manufacturers that target market and 
sell upscale gas guzzlers and tax on tobacco advertising seem a way better 
means of "screwing the man".  Both propositions were not well written and 
full of shitty side legislation.

How about a modest tax increase on oil products, with a progressive 
exception for companies that invest X dollars in California based 
companies researching alternative fuels?  And a drill tax like other oil 
bearing states have implemented.  How about a progressive tax on passenger 
cars that get worse than 30mpg (1% sales tax on every 1 mpg below 30 for 
example, with another .1% per mpg at yearly registration time).  Getting 
rid of half the SUVs sold per year in favor of more practical cars would 
be way better for us than subsidizing 50,000 hybrids, cheaper to 
implement, and would send a more realistic message.  the car manufacturers 
are already trying to scramble the message with hybrid SUVs that get 
*close* to the mileage of a much simpler to build, cheaper, safer 
econobox.  The law is it was simply wasn't practical, and would put 
California in an even worse place.  No reduction in gasoline use, existing 
loopholes for SUVs would stay in place, and the "promise" of oil companies 
not dicking a state that pays for some of the most expensive gas in the 
nation... *wake up*.

On the tobacco side, how about a progressive tax increase over several 
years so you don't get a panic response from people currently smoking, and 
better provisions for the resulting monies.  The way that proposition was 
written screwed our schools out of their (recent proposition mandated) 40% 
of new tax earning, and had private health care providers (the same guys 
funding the ads... hrm...) as the biggest benefactors.  Add to that a 
weird provision in the fine print regarding changing some financial 
disclosure and anti-trust provisions for large health care organizations 
and you've got a total piece of shit.  If you want people to quit smoking, 
how about a law that mandates tobacco companies list all the additives on 
the box in a readable font, and creates a trust for medical damages 
claimed in tobacco lawsuits *from the company side*?  The fact that the 
largest single line item in 86 (according to the Cal.gov web site) was 
coverage for emergency care for underinsured/undocumented hospital visits 
says it all (a painful cost for helath providers, but almost NOTHING to 
do with smoking related illnesses).

And here's the stupid thing.  I want a fucking GPS for free from the state 
of Cali.  Who wants to get sex offended and stuff?

*shakes head*
andyw

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy

"No sound ever comes from the gates of Eden" - Bob Dylan

tsheets@saturn5.com wrote:
  

If nothing else, the election has broken Bush's iron grip on this nations
levers of power.

C'mon people, aren't you down with the blog-ohh-sphere? Democratic Webb
is up by 7,000 votes in Virginia, but that is close enough that Republican
Allen can demand a state-sponsored recount, which he most certianly will.

But, judging from the history in Florida, it is unlikely a recount will sway
the election back to Republican Allen.

If the vote in Virginia stands, the Democrats will have 51 votes in the 
Senate, if you include the two independents (Leiberman, and.. Jeffords?)

The Democrats swept the elections, and they now have full control of the 
policy agenda. Lets wish them well for the sake of the nation.

Yesterday was a truly inspiring day for democracy. It restores a lot of faith
in my country.

-troy





On Wed, Nov 08, 2006 at 03:31:42PM -0800, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> That's what CNN is saying, not me. Hell if I know. If it goes the other way, you still have to ensure that no Democrats defect and then there's still the presidential veto. I guess we'll see what happens.
> 
> Not to be a downer or whatever, but our system tends to prevent big sudden changes in policy for better or worse. When you get a different party in the Whitehouse from the one controlling Congress, often things just grind to a halt with conflict and nothing much happens at all. At least that's my recollection of what has happened in the past.

"screwed our schools out of" is a bit missleading. It's not like the schools would be getting any less money than they are now, they just wouldn't be getting any of this money. Aside from that, do you really thing this was a revenue generating proposition? Maybe for a short period of time, but it's goal is obviously to give people an even better reason (as if they need one) to quit... It's an anti-smoking proposition. 

 



AndyW wrote:

>Erm, the "standing up to the oil and tobacco corporations" is a funny way 
>to put taxing their consumers.
>
>Drill fees, standing up to major car manufacturers that target market and 
>sell upscale gas guzzlers and tax on tobacco advertising seem a way better 
>means of "screwing the man".  Both propositions were not well written and 
>full of shitty side legislation.
>
>How about a modest tax increase on oil products, with a progressive 
>exception for companies that invest X dollars in California based 
>companies researching alternative fuels?  And a drill tax like other oil 
>bearing states have implemented.  How about a progressive tax on passenger 
>cars that get worse than 30mpg (1% sales tax on every 1 mpg below 30 for 
>example, with another .1% per mpg at yearly registration time).  Getting 
>rid of half the SUVs sold per year in favor of more practical cars would 
>be way better for us than subsidizing 50,000 hybrids, cheaper to 
>implement, and would send a more realistic message.  the car manufacturers 
>are already trying to scramble the message with hybrid SUVs that get 
>*close* to the mileage of a much simpler to build, cheaper, safer 
>econobox.  The law is it was simply wasn't practical, and would put 
>California in an even worse place.  No reduction in gasoline use, existing 
>loopholes for SUVs would stay in place, and the "promise" of oil companies 
>not dicking a state that pays for some of the most expensive gas in the 
>nation... *wake up*.
>
>On the tobacco side, how about a progressive tax increase over several 
>years so you don't get a panic response from people currently smoking, and 
>better provisions for the resulting monies.  The way that proposition was 
>written screwed our schools out of their (recent proposition mandated) 40% 
>of new tax earning, and had private health care providers (the same guys 
>funding the ads... hrm...) as the biggest benefactors.  Add to that a 
>weird provision in the fine print regarding changing some financial 
>disclosure and anti-trust provisions for large health care organizations 
>and you've got a total piece of shit.  If you want people to quit smoking, 
>how about a law that mandates tobacco companies list all the additives on 
>the box in a readable font, and creates a trust for medical damages 
>claimed in tobacco lawsuits *from the company side*?  The fact that the 
>largest single line item in 86 (according to the Cal.gov web site) was 
>coverage for emergency care for underinsured/undocumented hospital visits 
>says it all (a painful cost for helath providers, but almost NOTHING to 
>do with smoking related illnesses).
>
>And here's the stupid thing.  I want a fucking GPS for free from the state 
>of Cali.  Who wants to get sex offended and stuff?
>
>*shakes head*
>andyw
>

>AndyW wrote:
>
>>Erm, the "standing up to the oil and tobacco corporations" is a 
>>funny way to put taxing their consumers.
>>
>>Drill fees, standing up to major car manufacturers that target 
>>market and sell upscale gas guzzlers and tax on tobacco advertising 
>>seem a way better means of "screwing the man".  Both propositions 
>>were not well written and full of shitty side legislation.
>>
>>How about a modest tax increase on oil products, with a progressive 
>>exception for companies that invest X dollars in California based 
>>companies researching alternative fuels?  And a drill tax like 
>>other oil bearing states have implemented.  How about a progressive 
>>tax on passenger cars that get worse than 30mpg (1% sales tax on 
>>every 1 mpg below 30 for example, with another .1% per mpg at 
>>yearly registration time).  Getting rid of half the SUVs sold per 
>>year in favor of more practical cars would be way better for us 
>>than subsidizing 50,000 hybrids, cheaper to implement, and would 
>>send a more realistic message.  the car manufacturers are already 
>>trying to scramble the message with hybrid SUVs that get *close* to 
>>the mileage of a much simpler to build, cheaper, safer 
>>econobox.  The law is it was simply wasn't practical, and would put 
>>California in an even worse place.  No reduction in gasoline use, 
>>existing loopholes for SUVs would stay in place, and the "promise" 
>>of oil companies not dicking a state that pays for some of the most 
>>expensive gas in the nation... *wake up*.
>>
>>On the tobacco side, how about a progressive tax increase over 
>>several years so you don't get a panic response from people 
>>currently smoking, and better provisions for the resulting 
>>monies.  The way that proposition was written screwed our schools 
>>out of their (recent proposition mandated) 40% of new tax earning, 
>>and had private health care providers (the same guys funding the 
>>ads... hrm...) as the biggest benefactors.  Add to that a weird 
>>provision in the fine print regarding changing some financial 
>>disclosure and anti-trust provisions for large health care 
>>organizations and you've got a total piece of shit.  If you want 
>>people to quit smoking, how about a law that mandates tobacco 
>>companies list all the additives on the box in a readable font, and 
>>creates a trust for medical damages claimed in tobacco lawsuits 
>>*from the company side*?  The fact that the largest single line 
>>item in 86 (according to the Cal.gov web site) was coverage for 
>>emergency care for underinsured/undocumented hospital visits says 
>>it all (a painful cost for helath providers, but almost NOTHING to 
>>do with smoking related illnesses).

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Please VOTE today! This time, let's actually do it. (fwd)



All you smokers will cost all of us non-smokers in shared health care
costs.

I think it is only fair that you start paying now for the cost you will
inflict on our healthcare system in the future.

I would extend this logic to french fries, alcohol, and any other 
voluntary, unhealthy consumer purchases.

Healthcare costs are poised to cripple our nation's economy.  We could ease 
the damage by staying healthy.  

-troy

yes, i think nathan's got it right here, and i think there's even  
more to it than that.  you see, every time a bond is created, that is  
basically a loan that is added to the debt.  well where does that  
money come from?  in this case it *might* be coming from people that  
are interested in buying municipal bonds, or it might be the type of  
bond that isn't offered to the public, in which case it is created  
out of thin air and added to the money supply which creates a hidden  
tax called inflation to all american citizens.


On Nov 7, 2006, at 7:13 PM, Nathan Seven wrote:

> Well- here's my quick guide-
>
> VOTE NO ON EVERYTHING EXCEPT 1A  and 90 :)
> 1A says that gas taxes have to be spend on roads etc
> 90 is important in the defense of private property rights.
>
> All those bond measures?  CA does not have a revenue problem, it  
> has a *spending* problem...
> I have no desire to get further and further in to debt so more  
> poorly-overseen programs can be funded.
>
> 89- the "fair election" one?  It is a power grab by the nurses  
> organization- with all it's messaging about "get big money out of  
> elections", it is actually worded so that corporations' donations  
> get severely cut, but... surprise surprise - "organizations" like  
> the nurses are still able to effectively donate large sums
>
> 87- the tax on oil company drilling?  Gasoline consumption needs to  
> be addressed on the *consumption* side, not the production side-  
> hell I'm all for a $3 direct-to-consumer gas tax to reduce  
> consumption, - make gas got $6- $10- I don't care!  But that's not  
> what this is.  It is being positioned as some sort of big stab-back- 
> at-big-oil-with-their-big-profits so people who don't like high gas  
> prices can feel good- and what does it do? It makes oil more  
> expensive to produce IN california, making it cheaper to IMPORT in  
> to ca.  No wonder that this is backed by... wait for it... a huge  
> ethanol entrepreneur!!!
>
> here's a great writeup: http://i-r-squared.blogspot.com/2006/08/ 
> californias-proposition-87.html
>
> Unfortunately- organizations, people, and corporations have  
> *forever* been foisting legislation upon us under the guise of  
> great-sounding-things- do NOT let yourself be a fucking sheep.
> READ THE MEASURES
> READ THE ARGUMENTS ON BOTH SIDES OF THEM
> FOLLOW THE MONEY

there's a lot of eminent domain abuse going on in the country right =20
now, i even think i remember michael savage talking about barbara =20
boxer being involved in some kind of land grabbing scam, though i =20
never followed that too much.

what i did follow though was this family farm in new jersey that was =20
land grabbed within the last few months, the city or county told them =20=

they were reclaiming the land for environmental purposes and would =20
only pay them pennies on the dollar of what the property was worth.  =20
by the way, this was an organic family owned farm.  so the family =20
refused the offer they were stating, and the government came back and =20=

said they were going to just take the land and charge them back rent =20
for it.

then the sad part is most of the time they end up rezoning the land a =20=

few years down the road as commercial property and make condos out of =20=

it and making tons of money.  they did the same thing in mexico =20
running people off the land scorching the farms making them all move =20
to mexico city and now you can buy land there.  by the way there was =20
one person that got their land grabbed and tried to sue the =20
government and got charged with terrorism under the patriot act and =20
sentenced to 5 years in prison.  don't you just love this country?

oh, you can go look this stuff up on the internet if you don't =20
believe me.  i can't remember their names but it's there.  but look =20
up stuff like eminent domain abuse, there is a ton of information.  =20
so i think i voted for 90.  i mean, it doesn't really matter because =20
the electronic voting machines do all the work for you, if you know =20
what i mean.

what we *really* need in california is for people to get together and =20=

DEMAND paper ballots only statewide, either by referendum or through =20
the legislature.


On Nov 7, 2006, at 7:44 PM, Nathan Seven wrote:

> On Nov 7, 2006, at 2:37 PM, J.C. wrote:
>
>> this proposition going through are obvious. And Prop. 90, which =20
>> the Guardian
>> calls "by far the worst item on the November California ballot, a =20
>> draconian
>> measure that could potentially eliminate a wide range of government
>> regulations =97 from rent control and zoning to workplace safety and
>> environmental laws =97 and bankrupt local agencies that in any way =20=

>> try to
>> limit what a property owner can do with land or buildings."
>
> Since I didn't specifically talk about prop 90 beyond recommending =20
> it, I figure I should-
>
> That is a bunch of BS- this is what the law says today:
>
> Say you have a house, and the city says "we're building a new =20
> freeway and taking your house"
> Ok- fine- you get paid fair market value for your house.
>
> What Prop 90 adds is fair compensation for *use* restrictions-
>
> As in- say you buy a small commercially-zoned empty space for $100k.
> Then, the city decides to rezone it to residential-only, and now =20
> because of that your shop is only worth $50k as a residence and you =20=

> can't build your shop.
>
> Under current law, you just got screwed out of $50k.
> Under Prop 90, you would be compensated for your loss.
>
> It doesn't restrict any ability to pass any rent control, =20
> environmental measures, or anything else.
> It merely compensates the owners of the property for any loss they =20
> incur
>
> --
> "Jupiter accepts your offer..."
> AIM:IMFDUP
>
>
