>>> elections", it is actually worded so that corporations' donations  
>>> get
>>> severely cut, but... surprise surprise - "organizations" like the
>>> nurses are still able to effectively donate large sums
>>>
>>> 87- the tax on oil company drilling? Gasoline consumption needs to
>>> be addressed on the *consumption* side, not the production side-  
>>> hell
>>> I'm all for a $3 direct-to-consumer gas tax to reduce consumption, -
>>> make gas got $6- $10- I don't care! But that's not what this is. It
>>> is being positioned as some sort of big stab-back-at-big-oil-with-
>>> their-big-profits so people who don't like high gas prices can feel
>>> good- and what does it do? It makes oil more expensive to produce IN
>>> california, making it cheaper to IMPORT in to ca. No wonder that
>>> this is backed by... wait for it... a huge ethanol entrepreneur!!!
>>>
>>> here's a great writeup: http://i-r-squared.blogspot.com/2006/08/
>>> californias-proposition-87.html
>>>
>>> Unfortunately- organizations, people, and corporations have  
>>> *forever*
>>> been foisting legislation upon us under the guise of great-sounding-
>>> things- do NOT let yourself be a fucking sheep.
>>> READ THE MEASURES
>>> READ THE ARGUMENTS ON BOTH SIDES OF THEM
>>> FOLLOW THE MONEY
>>>
>>> --
>>> "Jupiter accepts your offer..."
>>> AIM:IMFDUP
>>>
>>>

>>> On Nov 7, 2006, at 3:47 PM, J C wrote:
>>>
>>>> IMO, Prop 87 may be one of the most important on the list and a
>>>> reason to go vote by itself. I'm not super-thrilled by it. It's
>>>> actually only $4B over ten years and I wish the incentives for alt-
>>>> fuel vehicles and university grants was a higher percent. But
>>>> let's not fool ourselves. It's more or less a gas tax and we'll
>>>> probably see a small ($4B over 10 years is not a lot to the
>>>> bottomline) impact at the pump. Although it says it will be
>>>> illegal to pass the costs to consumers, there's just no way the
>>>> suits at Chevron are going to get outsmarted by the public
>>>> officials on the equalization board.
>>>>
>>>> But I'm for it because it's been long overdue. We need to start
>>>> aggressively taxing activities that consume our public resources
>>>> (like clean air and a healthy planet) without penalty today. I
>>>> really do see this as a major leap forward in *practical*
>>>> environmental reform.
>>>>
>>>> See you at the polls!
>>>>
>>>>

In regards to proposition 90, try googling the man behind the scam, Howie
Rich.  A real estate megadeveloper from NYC who has tried to pull similar
proposition antics in other states.  Ultimately, the proposition attempts to
take the teeth out of local/state government and zoning laws, allowing the
developer to proceed with whatever type of project money will let them buy.
If the prop passed, new developments in SF might not be required to set
aside a certain amount of units to affordable or below market rate housing.
And you'd better believe, if you are a renter, you'd be losing a lot of your
rights.

So we're ready for socialized medicine, but only if you pay for 
cigarettes?

If that's the motive/whatever, let's do it.  Otherwise, seriously, fuck 
off.

I am perfectly okay with socialized medicine, but I don't see propositions 
for alcohol related, or other lifestylye related elevated health 
risk choices (including "participating" in dance culture).

Especially in the case of this bill, it's a fiscal hit that is out of tune 
with where the money goes.  Follow the money know the score.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Please VOTE today! This time, let's actually do it. (fwd)

It doesn't have to be all or nothing.  Effective politics is about 
compromise.  The US is not ready for socialized medicine - we're not ready 
for anything that sounds like socialism.  That doesn't mean that we can't 
make some compromises along the way.

Here is a link to an old JAMA article on the CDC website (1993 - sorry I 
didn't have the patience to find something more recent) on causes of death.

http://www.cdc.gov/nccdphp/publications/ActualCauses/pdf/acd.pdf

Tobacco is estimated to be responsible for 19% of deaths.  Poor diet - 14%. 
Alcohol - 5%.  Illicit use of drugs - less than 1%.

Since we can't realistically or practically tax poor diet yet, I don't see a 
problem with taxing the biggest contributor.  I'd be for an alcohol tax too 
but too many lushes vote.  We could tax heroin too if it were legal. :0  I 
do have firm ideals but when it comes to politics, I'm willing to bend them 
a little to do what makes sense.

Also, Penta KICKED ASS at Synchronize tonight.  His set reaffirmed my faith 
in psytrance.

Government of, by, and for the people. Now there's a novel concept, huh? "Lord" forbid anybody subscribed to this concept nowadays. 
   
  As far as Madame Speaker is concerened, you have any doubt this will happen in Jan., as the president & other leading Dems have also recognized her in addition to CNN? 
   
  As I told someone else off list, look at what happend in "the first" 24 hours: We saw Bush bow down to min. wage hikes, send Rummy 'hiking, and the Dems seize control of Congress. So excuse me if I have a little more faith in her "1st Hundred Hour" campaign than others. I know actions speak louder than words, but there's been some serious action. . . not just talk like people make it out to be.

>> At 04:13 PM 11/7/2006, Nathan Seven wrote:
>>> Well- here's my quick guide-
>>>
>>> VOTE NO ON EVERYTHING EXCEPT 1A and 90 :)
>>> 1A says that gas taxes have to be spend on roads etc
>>> 90 is important in the defense of private property rights.
>>>
>>> All those bond measures? CA does not have a revenue problem, it has
>>> a *spending* problem...
>>> I have no desire to get further and further in to debt so more
>>> poorly- overseen programs can be funded.
>>>
>>> 89- the "fair election" one? It is a power grab by the nurses
>>> organization- with all it's messaging about "get big money out of
>>> elections", it is actually worded so that corporations' donations 
>>> get
>>> severely cut, but... surprise surprise - "organizations" like the
>>> nurses are still able to effectively donate large sums
>>>
>>> 87- the tax on oil company drilling? Gasoline consumption needs to
>>> be addressed on the *consumption* side, not the production side- 
>>> hell
>>> I'm all for a $3 direct-to-consumer gas tax to reduce consumption, -
>>> make gas got $6- $10- I don't care! But that's not what this is. It
>>> is being positioned as some sort of big stab-back-at-big-oil-with-
>>> their-big-profits so people who don't like high gas prices can feel
>>> good- and what does it do? It makes oil more expensive to produce IN
>>> california, making it cheaper to IMPORT in to ca. No wonder that
>>> this is backed by... wait for it... a huge ethanol entrepreneur!!!
>>>
>>> here's a great writeup: http://i-r-squared.blogspot.com/2006/08/
>>> californias-proposition-87.html
>>>
>>> Unfortunately- organizations, people, and corporations have 
>>> *forever*
>>> been foisting legislation upon us under the guise of great-sounding-
>>> things- do NOT let yourself be a fucking sheep.
>>> READ THE MEASURES
>>> READ THE ARGUMENTS ON BOTH SIDES OF THEM
>>> FOLLOW THE MONEY
>>>
>>> --
>>> "Jupiter accepts your offer..."
>>> AIM:IMFDUP
>>>

>>> On Nov 7, 2006, at 3:47 PM, J C wrote:

>>>> IMO, Prop 87 may be one of the most important on the list and a
>>>> reason to go vote by itself. I'm not super-thrilled by it. It's
>>>> actually only $4B over ten years and I wish the incentives for alt-
>>>> fuel vehicles and university grants was a higher percent. But
>>>> let's not fool ourselves. It's more or less a gas tax and we'll
>>>> probably see a small ($4B over 10 years is not a lot to the
>>>> bottomline) impact at the pump. Although it says it will be
>>>> illegal to pass the costs to consumers, there's just no way the
>>>> suits at Chevron are going to get outsmarted by the public
>>>> officials on the equalization board.
>>>>
>>>> But I'm for it because it's been long overdue. We need to start
>>>> aggressively taxing activities that consume our public resources
>>>> (like clean air and a healthy planet) without penalty today. I
>>>> really do see this as a major leap forward in *practical*
>>>> environmental reform.
>>>>
>>>> See you at the polls!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Ed Bradley RIP

i had a chance to meet Ed Bradley this past summer in New York and
hear him speak about his career path.  he talked about covering the
Vietnam War (and being hit with scrapnel in the process), journalistic
integrity, etc.  he was extremely humble and friendly.

but a few of the funnier bits that he shared were:

- he chose his college not because of academics nor because it was a
historically Black university....but because he visited the campus and
there were lots of hot girls

- before he became a journalist, he lived in paris.  he shared  a
small apartment with several other foreigners and slept on the floor.
he said that he was having trouble paying his bills and he had two
choices:  become a DJ at a nightclub or take a job with CBS news
radio.  he chose news.

can you imagine if Ed Bradley had ended up as a Paris nightclub DJ?

rest in peace, Mr. Bradley.

Subject: Re: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Ed Bradley RIP

(CBS) The 2005-06 season marks Correspondent Ed Bradley's 25th on 60
MINUTES. He joined the broadcast during the 1981-82 season. He also
anchors and reports hour-long specials.

Bradley's consummate skills as a broadcast journalist and his
distinctive body of work have been recognized with numerous awards,
including 19 Emmys, the latest for a segment that reported the
reopening of the 50-year-old racial murder case of Emmett Till. He
received three Emmys at the 2003 awards: a Lifetime Achievement Emmy;
one for a 60 MINUTES report on brain cancer patients, "A New Lease on
Life" (April 2002); and another for his hour on 60 MINUTES II about
sexual abuse in the Catholic Church, "The Catholic Church on Trial"
(June 2002).

Bradley's 60 MINUTES interview with condemned Oklahoma City bomber
Timothy McVeigh (March 2000) was the only television interview ever
given by the man guilty of one of the worst terrorist acts on American
soil; it also earned Bradley an Emmy. His reporting on the worst
school shooting in American history, "Columbine" (April 2001),
revealed on 60 MINUTES II that authorities ignored telling evidence
with which they might have prevented the massacre.

Other hourlong reports by Bradley have prompted praise and action:
"Death by Denial" (June 2000) won a Peabody Award for focusing on the
plight of Africans dying of AIDS and helped convince drug companies to
donate and discount AIDS drugs; "Unsafe Haven" (April 1999) spurred
federal investigations into the nation's largest chain of psychiatric
hospitals; and "Town Under Siege" (December 1997), about a small town
battling toxic waste, was named one of the Ten Best Television
Programs of 1997 by Time magazine.

Bradley's significant contribution to electronic journalism was also
recognized by the Radio/Television News Directors Association when it
named him its Paul White Award winner for 2000. He joins other
distinguished journalists, such as Edward R. Murrow, Walter Cronkite
and Peter Jennings, as a Paul White recipient.

More recently, the Denver Press Club awarded him its 2003 Damon Runyon
Award for career journalistic excellence. Another prestigious honor
received by Bradley is the Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Awards grand
prize and television first prize for "CBS Reports: In the Killing
Fields of America" (January 1995), a documentary about violence in
America, for which he was co-anchor and reporter.

His work on 60 MINUTES has gained much recognition, including a George
Foster Peabody Award for "Big Man, Big Voice" (November 1997), the
uplifting story of a German singer who became successful despite birth
defects. In 1995, he won his 11th Emmy Award for a 60 MINUTES segment
on the cruel effects of nuclear testing in the town of Semipalatinsk,
Kazakhstan, a report that also won him an Alfred I. duPont-Columbia
University Award in 1994. Also in 1994, he was honored with an
Overseas Press Club Award for two 60 MINUTES reports that took viewers
inside sensitive military installations in Russia and the United
States.

In 1985, he received an Emmy Award for "Schizophrenia," a 60 MINUTES
report on that misunderstood brain disorder. In 1983, two of Bradley's
reports for 60 MINUTES won Emmy Awards: "In the Belly of the Beast,"
an interview with Jack Henry Abbott, a convicted murderer and author,
and "Lena," a profile of singer Lena Horne.

He received an Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Silver Baton and a
1991 Emmy Award for his 60 MINUTES report "Made in China," a look at
Chinese forced-labor camps, and another Emmy for "Caitlin's Story"
(November 1992), an examination of the controversy between the parents
of a deaf child and a deaf association.

In addition to "In the Killing Fields," his work for "CBS Reports" has
included: "Enter the Jury Room" (April 1997), an Alfred I.
duPont-Columbia University Award winner that revealed the jury
deliberation process for the first time in front of network cameras;
"The Boat People" (January 1979), which won duPont, Emmy and Overseas
Press Club Awards; "The Boston Goes to China" (April 1979), a report
on the historic visit to China by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which
won Emmy, Peabody and Ohio State Awards, and "Blacks in America: With
All Deliberate Speed?" (July 1979), which won Emmy and duPont Awards.

Bradley's coverage of the plight of Cambodian refugees, broadcast on
the "CBS Evening News with Walter Cronkite" and CBS NEWS SUNDAY
MORNING, won a George Polk Award in journalism. He also received a
duPont citation for a segment on the Cambodian situation broadcast on
CBS News' "Magazine" series. He covered the presidential campaign of
Jimmy Carter during Campaign '76, served as a floor correspondent for
CBS News' coverage of the Democratic and Republican National
Conventions from 1976 through 1996, and has participated in CBS News'
election-night coverage.

Prior to joining 60 MINUTES, Bradley was a principal correspondent for
"CBS Reports" (1978-81), after serving as CBS News' White House
correspondent (1976-78). He was also anchor of the "CBS Sunday Night
News" (November 1976-May 1981) and of the CBS News magazine "Street
Stories" (January 1992-August 1993).

Bradley joined CBS News as a stringer in its Paris bureau in September
1971. A year later, he was transferred to the Saigon bureau, where he
remained until he was assigned to the CBS News Washington bureau in
June 1974. He was named a CBS News correspondent in April 1973 and,
shortly thereafter, was wounded while on assignment in Cambodia. In
March 1975, he volunteered to return to Indochina and covered the fall
of Cambodia and Vietnam.

Prior to joining CBS News, he was a reporter for WCBS Radio, the CBS
Owned station in New York (August 1967-July 1971). He had previously
been a reporter for WDAS Radio Philadelphia (1963-67).

Bradley was born June 22, 1941, in Philadelphia and was graduated from
Cheyney (Pa.) State College in 1964 with a B.S. in education. He lives
in New York with his wife, Patricia Blanchet.--

>-&e->> >short period of time, but it's goal is obviously to give people an
>-&e->> >even better reason (as if they need one) to quit... It's an
>-&e->> >anti-smoking proposition.
>-&e->> >
>-&e->> >
>-&e->> >
>-&e->> >AndyW wrote:
>-&e->> >
>-&e->> >>Erm, the "standing up to the oil and tobacco corporations" is a
>-&e->> >>funny way to put taxing their consumers.
>-&e->> >>
>-&e->> >>Drill fees, standing up to major car manufacturers that target
>-&e->> >>market and sell upscale gas guzzlers and tax on tobacco advertising
>-&e->> >>seem a way better means of "screwing the man".  Both propositions
>-&e->> >>were not well written and full of shitty side legislation.
>-&e->> >>
>-&e->> >>How about a modest tax increase on oil products, with a progressive
>-&e->> >>exception for companies that invest X dollars in California based
>-&e->> >>companies researching alternative fuels?  And a drill tax like
>-&e->> >>other oil bearing states have implemented.  How about a progressive
>-&e->> >>tax on passenger cars that get worse than 30mpg (1% sales tax on
>-&e->> >>every 1 mpg below 30 for example, with another .1% per mpg at
>-&e->> >>yearly registration time).  Getting rid of half the SUVs sold per
>-&e->> >>year in favor of more practical cars would be way better for us
>-&e->> >>than subsidizing 50,000 hybrids, cheaper to implement, and would
>-&e->> >>send a more realistic message.  the car manufacturers are already
>-&e->> >>trying to scramble the message with hybrid SUVs that get *close* to
>-&e->> >>the mileage of a much simpler to build, cheaper, safer
>-&e->> >>econobox.  The law is it was simply wasn't practical, and would put
>-&e->> >>California in an even worse place.  No reduction in gasoline use,
>-&e->> >>existing loopholes for SUVs would stay in place, and the "promise"
>-&e->> >>of oil companies not dicking a state that pays for some of the most
>-&e->> >>expensive gas in the nation... *wake up*.
>-&e->> >>
>-&e->> >>On the tobacco side, how about a progressive tax increase over
>-&e->> >>several years so you don't get a panic response from people
>-&e->> >>currently smoking, and better provisions for the resulting
>-&e->> >>monies.  The way that proposition was written screwed our schools
>-&e->> >>out of their (recent proposition mandated) 40% of new tax earning,
>-&e->> >>and had private health care providers (the same guys funding the
>-&e->> >>ads... hrm...) as the biggest benefactors.  Add to that a weird
>-&e->> >>provision in the fine print regarding changing some financial
>-&e->> >>disclosure and anti-trust provisions for large health care
>-&e->> >>organizations and you've got a total piece of shit.  If you want
>-&e->> >>people to quit smoking, how about a law that mandates tobacco
>-&e->> >>companies list all the additives on the box in a readable font, and
>-&e->> >>creates a trust for medical damages claimed in tobacco lawsuits
>-&e->> >>*from the company side*?  The fact that the largest single line
>-&e->> >>item in 86 (according to the Cal.gov web site) was coverage for
>-&e->> >>emergency care for underinsured/undocumented hospital visits says
>-&e->> >>it all (a painful cost for helath providers, but almost NOTHING to
>-&e->> >>do with smoking related illnesses).
>-&e->> >>
>-&e->> >>And here's the stupid thing.  I want a fucking GPS for free from
>-&e->> >>the state of Cali.  Who wants to get sex offended and stuff?
>-&e->> >>

> > >>
> > >>Drill fees, standing up to major car manufacturers that target
> > >>market and sell upscale gas guzzlers and tax on tobacco advertising
> > >>seem a way better means of "screwing the man".  Both propositions
> > >>were not well written and full of shitty side legislation.
> > >>
> > >>How about a modest tax increase on oil products, with a progressive
> > >>exception for companies that invest X dollars in California based
> > >>companies researching alternative fuels?  And a drill tax like
> > >>other oil bearing states have implemented.  How about a progressive
> > >>tax on passenger cars that get worse than 30mpg (1% sales tax on
> > >>every 1 mpg below 30 for example, with another .1% per mpg at
> > >>yearly registration time).  Getting rid of half the SUVs sold per
> > >>year in favor of more practical cars would be way better for us
> > >>than subsidizing 50,000 hybrids, cheaper to implement, and would
> > >>send a more realistic message.  the car manufacturers are already
> > >>trying to scramble the message with hybrid SUVs that get *close* to
> > >>the mileage of a much simpler to build, cheaper, safer
> > >>econobox.  The law is it was simply wasn't practical, and would put
> > >>California in an even worse place.  No reduction in gasoline use,
> > >>existing loopholes for SUVs would stay in place, and the "promise"
> > >>of oil companies not dicking a state that pays for some of the most
> > >>expensive gas in the nation... *wake up*.
> > >>
> > >>On the tobacco side, how about a progressive tax increase over
> > >>several years so you don't get a panic response from people
> > >>currently smoking, and better provisions for the resulting
> > >>monies.  The way that proposition was written screwed our schools
> > >>out of their (recent proposition mandated) 40% of new tax earning,
> > >>and had private health care providers (the same guys funding the
> > >>ads... hrm...) as the biggest benefactors.  Add to that a weird
> > >>provision in the fine print regarding changing some financial
> > >>disclosure and anti-trust provisions for large health care
> > >>organizations and you've got a total piece of shit.  If you want
> > >>people to quit smoking, how about a law that mandates tobacco
> > >>companies list all the additives on the box in a readable font, and
> > >>creates a trust for medical damages claimed in tobacco lawsuits
> > >>*from the company side*?  The fact that the largest single line
> > >>item in 86 (according to the Cal.gov web site) was coverage for
> > >>emergency care for underinsured/undocumented hospital visits says
> > >>it all (a painful cost for helath providers, but almost NOTHING to
> > >>do with smoking related illnesses).
> > >>
> > >>And here's the stupid thing.  I want a fucking GPS for free from
> > >>the state of Cali.  Who wants to get sex offended and stuff?
> > >>
> > >>*shakes head*

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Please VOTE today! This time, let's actually do  it. (fwd)

This issue is near and dear to my heart-

Some people have such varied interests that they might be on 100  
different mailing lists, receiving over 2000 emails per day-

The person who works like this deletes entire threads that do not  
interest them, and has a filter set up so that messages directly  
addressed to them are highlighted and placed in a special folder,  
while other mail is processed as usual.

The "sending of the message to both the person, and the mailing list"  
is reflective of a personal response that may have group interest.   
By sending direct to the person as well, it is ensured that the  
message is seen and possibly responded to promptly, thus promoting  
lively discussion on said list.

What is the cost of this behavior? 2 copies of one email.
If you receive only 10 per day, perhaps this is in fact troublesome.

Feel free to continue to reply only to the list if you like, but  
don't expect a prompt response from people such as this- and I think  
it unsound to chastise those who do otherwise...

--
"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
AIM:IMFDUP

>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: mac book pro???


> ----- Original Message ----- 
> From: <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>

> Wasn't Apple charging extra for black?  Probably to match Job's 
> turtlenecks.

> Charging for a color just rubs me the wrong way personally.

I'm not sure that we had color options before Jobs so I guess you have to 
cut him a little slack.

Btw, one of my favorite stories about Jobs:
"Wozniak's friend Steve Jobs worked at Atari, and took on the project from 
Al Alcorn, the project's manager. Jobs turned around and enlisted Wozniak to 
design the game, which he did in four days. However, Atari was unable to use 
Steve Wozniak's design. In his usual zest to design the board as elegant as 
possible, he also cut down the amount of TTL (transistor-transistor logic) 
chips to just 42 total. This final design he submitted through Steve Jobs, 
however, made it impossible to manufacture - it was just too compact and 
complicated to be feasible with Atari's then current manufacturing methods. 
Jobs still got paid for the design, and because of a bonus clause in the 
contract based on the amount of TTL's cut ($100 per TTL) he earned a US$5000 
bonus. However, he only paid Wozniak $350, which he stated was half of the 
claimed $700 design fee. Atari wound up having to design their own version 
for production, which ultimately contained about 100 TTL's"

Also, I think Jobs' major (and only) contribution to the early Apple 
computer was the plastic case.

I've had the opportunity to use several of the last versions of the Apple
laptops for work and also for personal use.

Peter has it mostly right...  The Pro version is basically more.. larger
screen, larger hard drive, more memory, faster processor, better video ,
more money, aluminum shell etc etc..  As far as charging more for black..
meh..  they simply made the macbook with the most options available only in
black..

for the record my aluminum shelled powerbook has survived yearly falls onto
a hard floor..  and after 5 years the hard drive is finally crashing..
I've had good luck with  Apple computers at home and at work.

Hope this helps..

Matthew


Macbook
http://store.apple.com/1-800-MY-APPLE/WebObjects/AppleStore.woa/wa/RSLID?mco=A4791B5D&nclm=MacBook

MacBook Pro
http://store.apple.com/1-800-MY-APPLE/WebObjects/AppleStore.woa/wa/RSLID?mco=925997E8&nclm=MacBookPro

Subject: RE: [sfraves] nrr: mac book pro???

I have that black Macbook, my gf and I bought it back in August. She likes
that it is more portable (the smaller screen), I like the power and features
(esp the remote!).

I also did a dual-boot camp with WindowsXP on it...had a few driver issues
at first but they are all settled now. It really is a sweet system and for
media management there is no substitute to OS-X. I just use the Windows side
for business related jobs.

If you have the extra cash and dont mind the large notebook (ie the bigger
screens), go for the Macbook Pro. More portable and affordable solution, go
with the Macbook.

-Smithers

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: mac book pro???

On 14 November 2006, Matthew Phillips wrote:

> for the record my aluminum shelled powerbook has survived yearly falls onto
> a hard floor..  and after 5 years the hard drive is finally crashing..
> I've had good luck with  Apple computers at home and at work.

This just reminded me of my experience with Sony Vaio laptops, which has 
been quite the opposite of Matthew's Mac experience.  Turns out with one 
model that I had Sony actually chose to skimp on the solder on the 
joints for the memory socket  (What did that save them, maybe a penny a 
laptop??)  The end result; they eventually break and you have a dead 
laptop.  I've been told this has been the case on other sony products, 
like CD walkmans, stereo equipment, etc.  Yikes!

get out of Vietnam."

laptop??)  The end result; they eventually break and you have a dead =0Alap=
top.  I've been told this has been the case on other sony products, =0Alike=

the FiX crew at their monthly throw-down. It promises to get nasty, funky,
dirty and sweaty this Saturday as I join FiX residents Ron/E and JiVe. If
you're not into that sort of thing stay home. Otherwise... see you Saturday
night.

10th)

"ebay" values either because in both cases your still getting a solid deal

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] minimal techno Friday night - PHEEK at the Canvas Gallery on Friday, 11/17

I'm going to this and thought other folks might be
interested.  

Date & Time: 2006-11-17 9:00 PM
Location: The Canvas

Bay Area Beatdr_p and Cinematheque Present: 

PHEEK (Live PA) with supporting DJ sets from solekandi
and Playdoughboy @ Canvas Gallery 1200 9th Ave., San
Francisco, CA 94101 

Pheek is spicing up his live set with a lot of spaced
out 'n' funky twists and turns reminiscient of
Europe's reigning DJ and producer Ricardo Villalobos. 

Cost: $10 
RSVP for discount guestlist: 
guestlist@playdoughboy.com 

Don't miss this rare West Coast appearance by
Montreal's PHEEK (archipel, m-nus, contexterrior,
telegraph, thinner) with support of solekandi and
Playdoughboy. 

Inspired by the art of the DJ culture, Jean-Patrice
Remillard (aka Pheek) eschews the traditional dance
formula and instead constructs techno that echoes the
intensity of Ritchie Hawtin's cozy melodies. For those
seeking minimalism, Pheek's sultry atmospherics that
stretch the boundaries between acid house and techno's
main components are a refreshing antidote. 

Pheek's contribution to the Minimize To Maximize
compilation on M_nus last year followed up by a number
of releases on some great labels (Adjunct,
Contexterrior, Toys for Boys, Tic Tac Toe ect) and
live sets at DEMF and Mutek has made him one of the
most sought after minimal producers in North America.
Pheek's new album "En legere suspension" is in stores
now. 



 
____________________________________________________________________________________
Sponsored Link

Don't quit your job - take classes online
www.Classesusa.com

Subject: [sfraves] RIGHT NOW! ::AuraSF's Progressive Experience Radio Show:: 3p-5p PST :: Give it a Listen!!!

Event Description:

Get ready for the launch of our new monthly radio show:

The AuraSF ProgressiveExperience

The AuraSF Progressive Experience Radio Show is here to expose all Dance 
Music Enthusiasts to fresh, tasteful and energizing Breaks, Progressive and 
Trance music. We wish to provide a fun and interactive experience using the 
guest DJ mixes as our foundation. We do not just wish to play the guest 
mixes, we want to emphasize upon the positive vibe that dance music can 
provide. Our goal is to make the listener feel as if they are experiencing 
the music "live" for the very first time. We wish to provide a reminiscent 
clubbing experience in each show. By providing a positive and uplifting 
studio presence to each show, we hope to provide that extra interactive 
presence that can be found in live broadcasts, giving our show a life and 
character of its own.

Our first show will feature a couple of local DJs:

Aaron Jae from Evil Breaks and Koroma with AuraSF

Aaron Jae will give us a flavor of some Progressive Tunes with a Breaks 
Flair and Koroma will close out the show with some of his signature 
sounds!!!

Be sure to tune in!!!!

Online at:

 www.AfterHours.FM

Time: 3pm - 5pm PST

Cover: FREE


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

everything. 
I'm invisible. 
an eraser of love. an eraser of love. 
why don't you call me I feel like flying in two. 
I'm invisible. 
an eraser of love. an eraser of love. 
why don't you call me I feel like flying in two. 
an eraser of love. an eraser of love. 

I don't dream. (ice cream.) I scream so much. 
you know what I mean. this electric stream. 
and my tears in league with the wires 
and energy and my machine. 
this is my beautiful dream. 
I'm hurting no one. hurting no one. 
I want to give you everything. 
I want to give you energy. 
I want to give a good thing. 
I want to give you everything. 
everything. 
in one final scream of love who could 
climb this high she looks beautiful 
like a child I feel tears. 
and I want to scream. 
you know what I mean cause this is hurting no one. 
an eraser of love. 
hurt. the necessary feeling. 
why don't you call me I feel like flying in two. 
an eraser of love.

X-Mailer: Turbo-Mailer
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] [skylab2000] from the trenches..

This one is NOT about what we have coming up. 

Seems like some really old skool kinda stuff lately in LA. 

I was booked for a party in LA last night. The venue was a really big old warehouse/soundstage kinda thing in south central. 
Odd to see things being so old skool lately. 

It was busted at 1am. Helicopters and many cars. 

To get to this party you parked in a sketchy part of LA and they shuttled everyone in from 5 1/2 miles away to another sketchier part, so when it was busted cops closed the streets. No shuttles could get there to get peopl back to ther cars, and who knows if any were coming anyway. So, all these people were walking in southern central back to their cars. Girls dressed for a rave, suburb-living guys out of their element. 

I just don't understand how this is for the public good to have young kids walking five and half miles on dangerous streets. 

I gave some kids a ride back to their car, but you can't drive everybody two by two.. 

Cops were well behaved, but what a terrrible policy to send kids safely dancing, out onto the rough streets. 

How was everyone else's night?

AND.. Just so you guys all know, I play shows most weekends, but only send an email out now and again so you don't go crazy. 
You may have to check our website now and again too. Upcoming very soon: Memphis, Tucson, Denver, New York, more. 

Thanks!

skylab2000
http://skylab2000.com
http://myspace.com/skylab2000

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Pioneer CDJ-700s/500s for sale

Selling my Pioneer CDJ-700s as it's time for me to upgrade to a single
800 (too poor for a 1000, can't afford two of anything!)

I'm guessing most of you aren't familiar with the 700s (which is
referred to overseas as the 500s).  I bought these used off eBay when
I wanted to begin the slow transition to playing CDs.  They've been
good to as practice tools and have even taken them out to gigs (since
they are so small and portable).

They are a top loading player with a jog dial.  They perform well and
have given me no troubles other than the tempo/master tempo buttons
being a little sticky.

I'm selling them for $300 for the pair, but am open to other offers!

On Platinum Records, they are selling these new for $550 each.  On
eBay, this guy is trying to sell them for $399 each.

http://www.platinum-records.com/PIONEER-CDJ-700S-prod4340.htm
Your Price:  $550.00

http://cgi.ebay.com/Pioneer-CDJ-700S-CD-DJ-Player-Brand-New_W0QQitemZ320040620331QQcmdZViewItem
US $399.88

For complete information, you can download the PDF manual here (click
on the 500s):
http://www.service.pioneer-eur.com/peeservice/RegistrInstrMan.nsf/search?openform&Modelnr=cdj

Subject: [sfraves] My W.R.: Part 1; Breaking Tradition & Reunion :n)

OK.. so like my Mom's side of the Family... like alota my Cousin's &
Aunties & Uncles are all gonna be in like Florida this coming Thanksgiving
& stuff.. it just so happen that last weekend, well, my 2 Sisters came up
from SoCal, My 1st Cousin Kristen came up from Socal as well, & my 1st
Cousin Sherry was in town from NYC... so Sherry's Mom, My Mom's Sister &
My Auntie (well, actually i should cacll her Tita, but i call her Ninang
which is Tagalog for God Mother even though she's my Older Sister's God
Mom, not mine) decided to have this years Thanksgiving holiday on Saturday
in V Town @ her pad... so that was like kinda well... filling.. Hello
2Day.. LOLOLMAO... yeah man.. ate Turkey, Stuffing, Mashed Potatos, & Crab
(which they said on the new is the new Turkey for Thanksgiving)

Anywaze... so like Inception @ 550 was goin' on & 1 of the Promoters
(MArty) picked me up in Vallejo @ Ninang's pad.. I mean.. by that point I
was like munching on crab legs still & eating mashed potatos, so
Thankfully i got outta there just in time like around 7 PMish :) 
YAAAAAAAAY.. & My Katya was in the car too <3<3<3 U Girl!!!

OK.. i gotta tell this story b4 i continue.. but like ok.. I dunno who
remember my 1 adventure 6 years ago when I got off work (Kozmo.com) &
happen to go like club hopping w/ Armand & the BrainChild Crew?  OK..
well.. quick recap... I got off my swingshift @ Koz & went strait to that
club in the Marina across the street from Safeway, ummmm.. the old movie
theater (the name totally escapes me atm & it's changed names like twice
since then), but I happen to run into Armand & his crew there & it was
dead so we all went to 550... there was a private party there & we
couldn't get in... so we ended up goin to 177 Townsend where there happen
to be this FTT event goin on...

So we all like get in & it was packed as usual... the usuals were out &
about the night: Kelly, the Russian Dude, the Stick Dancer Dude, Douchebag
Eric, like all the regs I kicked it w/ on Sundays @ Spundaes @ 1015 were
all there.. it was like 1 & there was still a good 3 hours of dancing to
get in & it was Hella fun night! :n)  I mean... all the FTT regs were
there too & yeah... all the clubbers I usually saw in the City :n)

So club closed... alot of us stood on the sidewalk like talking, ya know
that after club closes chat you have in front of the venue & stuff...
anywaze.. i was walkin' to my car when there were these Dudes from the
club just standing there all cold & confuzed lookin & stuff... so I asked
them if they needed a ride somewhere in the City or something... they said
they didn't have to report back to their ship until Sunday evening & just
needed somewhere to chill 'cause they wre pretty high still or
something... they were these Navy Dudes from like Texas or Seattle wait..
no wait... they were from Washington State 'cause we talked about
Bremorton 'cause I used to visit up there to see my cousins & stay w/ them
back in the day... & yeah.. that's what base they wre stationed @ but they
were down in SF doin' some routine blah blah yada blah...

So i took 'em to breakfast @ Denny;s in Emeryville 'cause that was the 1st
place i could think of to go... I mean... it was like 5-6 in the AM
already & i dunno.. lol... then i was like all getting tired & suggest
they come home w/ me to Hercules (well, i didn't feel like driving back to
the City Basically & pay toll & shit) & like hang out since i gotta go
back to the City anywaze to do my Sunday Swingshit @ Koz... so they
camehome w/ me.. i managed to convince my Mom they were friends from
Highschool & then after like an hour of chatting in my room, we all
crashed well.. except for 1 of the Navy dudes who was all spun & managed
to grab Party Monster from my book shelf & read it the whole time we were
all sleeping...

So yeah... woke up, got ready, ate soup my Mom made for us, drove to the
City, dropped them of in SOMA, then went to work... The End

OK.. so fast foward to last Saturday... we get to 550 & Frosty is out
there w/ his sound for the green room, the rest of ther Inception crew
from Sac was there, & then we all greet each other & ya know me, I always
use a diff name when i introduce myself to new people... lol

Yeah.. so like someone called me out when i was lying down on the base
bins 'cause I was still hella full of food, "Man.. stop lying, you're
name's Osby" I think it was Frosty who said that...

OK.. then that guest MC from Florida, MC Defy, looked @ me & goes, "Are
You Osby?  Seriously, are you Osby?"

I was like yeah, that me...

Then he said, "Holy Fuckin' Shit man.. it's me Kaleb Dude, that Navy Dude
you took out to breakfast w/ his Navy buddies & you took us to your
house!"

OK.. LoL... that was fuckin' TRIPPY... I mean... yeah.. it like totally
trip me out 'cause I mean.. well.. i mean.. i know stuff like that always
happens to me, but I dunno man... so yeah.. the MC dude was 1 of the Navy
dudes from 6 years ago!

Kaleb told me that he's been telling eeeeeveryone about me in Washington &
when he got kicked outta the Navy & moved back to Chicago & now lives in
Florida & still has the promo picture i gave him back in the day...
LOLOLMAO.. Heeeeeello 2day.. I mean.. serioulsy.. it was sooo trippy!!  I
mean... @ 550 that night... I intro-ed him to everyone & him & i both
would tell people hte story of how we met & funny enough, it was 6 years
ago to that night 'cause we back tracked & realized his ship run was in
November that year...

So yeah.. it was Tripy shit man!  So YAY!!!  LoL.. OK. i just had to share
this b4 i talked about my actually review of Incpetion :)  LOLOLMAO.. yeah
man.. i'm still buggin'... i wonder if the archieves are still fucked up
so i could retieve that post from 6 years ago!?

OK... to be continued!

Subject: [sfraves] [skylab2000] from the trenches..
Content-Length: 844

This one is NOT about what we have coming up. 

Seems like some really old skool kinda stuff lately in LA. 

I was booked for a party in LA last night. The venue was a really big old warehouse/soundstage kinda thing in south central. 
Odd to see things being so old skool lately. 

It was busted at 1am. Helicopters and many cars. 

To get to this party you parked in a sketchy part of LA and they shuttled everyone in from 5 1/2 miles away to another sketchier part, so when it was busted cops closed the streets. No shuttles could get there to get peopl back to ther cars, and who knows if any were coming anyway. So, all these people were walking in southern central back to their cars. Girls dressed for a rave, suburb-living guys out of their element. 

I just don't understand how this is for the public good to have young kids walking five and half miles on dangerous streets. 

I gave some kids a ride back to their car, but you can't drive everybody two by two.. 

Cops were well behaved, but what a terrrible policy to send kids safely dancing, out onto the rough streets. 

How was everyone else's night?

AND.. Just so you guys all know, I play shows most weekends, but only send an email out now and again so you don't go crazy. 
You may have to check our website now and again too. Upcoming very soon: Memphis, Tucson, Denver, New York, more. 

Thanks!

skylab2000
http://skylab2000.com
http://myspace.com/skylab2000

> man. what a ridiculous amount of work just to produce 3/4 of one side
> of one record.
>
> another stone age technology that should've died years ago.
>
> -g

From: Uncle Noah <unclenoah@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Turntable technology (was: How Vinyl Records are Made)



I still love the feel and sound of vinyl.  And having
gone through the production process for both full-on
CD replication and vinyl production, I have to say
that from a production standpoint, I also prefer
vinyl.  

But vinyl is hard to sell.  With so many distros
tanking (as has been documented here on SFR) and with
many DJs moving to all-digital setups, moving a coupel
hundred units of vinyl is a daunting task, even for
established artists.

The thing that continues to amaze me is the
advancement of DJ turntable technology.  I just heard
about the Numark x2 Hybrid Turntable - it's got a
setup much like the beloved TTX, but also has a CD
player built in that's controllable from the turntable
platter.  So you get your full vinyl feel in the
spins, but you can have CDs packed full of MP3s to
play from, or switch back and forth depending on what
you've got handy.

What I'd like to see is this tech taken just one step
further.  They need to incorporate a 250Gb hard drive
into the thing, so you can rip tunes from your CDs or
directly from vinyl and then store them in the deck's
internal hard drive.  Imagine having 60k+ songs that
you could call up instantly and then manipulate like
vinyl, plus still have the flexibility to play CDs and
vinyls in the set, all off one unit.  That would kick
some serious boo-tay.


___________________________________________________________________
"May the wings of Liberty never lose a feather." - Jack Burton

list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 55828 invoked from network); 21 Nov 2006 20:44:06 -0000
Message-ID: <456364F3.7090803@djvaritech.net>
Date: Tue, 21 Nov 2006 12:43:31 -0800
From: Gavin Varitech <gavin@djvaritech.net>
User-Agent: Mozilla Thunderbird 1.0.2 (Windows/20050317)
X-Accept-Language: en-us, en
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: The Twilight Laser Outpost <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Turntable technology


A lot of big clubs and mobile sound companies have the Serato hardware 
installed already. All you have to do is plug in your notebook and go, 
no touching of the mixer at all. Also, a few clubs have Serato and a 
computer already set up. In this case, all the deejay has to do is play 
in their hard drive via USB and go. The best part is that the Scratch 
Live software will stay open AND leave the last track playing while HDs 
are being exchanged. Plug and play!

Greg Albrecht wrote:

> what would facilitate the usage of the FS system is a mixer with top
> mounted bypass or tap inputs, saving you having to dig around behind
> the mixer. that or a mixer with the FS interface built in. just plug
> in USB and go.
>
> -g
>
> On 21/11/06, georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
>> The Numark HDX turntable uses hard drives mounted in removable 
>> cartridges a dj can carry with them and just slot in and go- the rub 
>> is, the damn deck costs $2500, and nobody in their right mind will 
>> ever install one in a club system- way too expensive and proprietary.
>>
>> I'd say, despite occasional niggles with plugging in in the hectic 
>> environment of a gig, carrying around a Final Scratch/Serato/Torq 
>> system is a WAY better bet.  A $600 cheap PC laptop + a $3-600 vinyl 
>> interface system = a setup you can fit into a messenger bag and set 
>> up at any club in 5 minutes.  Done.  No need to reinvent the wheel- 
>> just put the right tire on it.
>>
>> -GC
>>
>> ----- Original Message ----
>> From: Uncle Noah <unclenoah@yahoo.com>
>> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>> Sent: Tuesday, November 21, 2006 11:41:28 AM
>> Subject: RE: [sfraves] Turntable technology (was: How Vinyl Records 
>> are Made)
>>
>>
>>
>> I still love the feel and sound of vinyl.  And having
>> gone through the production process for both full-on
>> CD replication and vinyl production, I have to say
>> that from a production standpoint, I also prefer
>> vinyl.
>>
>> But vinyl is hard to sell.  With so many distros
>> tanking (as has been documented here on SFR) and with
>> many DJs moving to all-digital setups, moving a coupel
>> hundred units of vinyl is a daunting task, even for
>> established artists.
>>
>> The thing that continues to amaze me is the
>> advancement of DJ turntable technology.  I just heard
>> about the Numark x2 Hybrid Turntable - it's got a
>> setup much like the beloved TTX, but also has a CD
>> player built in that's controllable from the turntable
>> platter.  So you get your full vinyl feel in the
>> spins, but you can have CDs packed full of MP3s to
>> play from, or switch back and forth depending on what
>> you've got handy.
>>
>> What I'd like to see is this tech taken just one step
>> further.  They need to incorporate a 250Gb hard drive
>> into the thing, so you can rip tunes from your CDs or
>> directly from vinyl and then store them in the deck's
>> internal hard drive.  Imagine having 60k+ songs that
>> you could call up instantly and then manipulate like
>> vinyl, plus still have the flexibility to play CDs and
>> vinyls in the set, all off one unit.  That would kick
>> some serious boo-tay.
>>
>>

>> "May the wings of Liberty never lose a feather." - Jack Burton

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Turntable technology



yes, and I am sure in a 90'F club, with water dripping from the ceiling,
trainspotters and dancers crowded all around you, the power system
maxed to the limit, big wallwarts dangling off power strips, drunk
people with their sticky drinks leaving them on your setup, AND...

a USB hard drive plugged into someone else's laptop and a FS dongle
also plugged in receiving two coded audio feeds from the turntables and
one going back out to the mixer...

nothing, nothing could possibly go wrong.  Nothing.    

-troy

> A lot of big clubs and mobile sound companies have the Serato hardware 
> installed already. All you have to do is plug in your notebook and go, 
> no touching of the mixer at all. Also, a few clubs have Serato and a 
> computer already set up. In this case, all the deejay has to do is play 
> in their hard drive via USB and go. The best part is that the Scratch 
> Live software will stay open AND leave the last track playing while HDs 
> are being exchanged. Plug and play!

> >>ever install one in a club system- way too expensive and proprietary.

> >>established artists.
> >>

> >>advancement of DJ turntable technology.  I just heard
> >>about the Numark x2 Hybrid Turntable - it's got a
> >>setup much like the beloved TTX, but also has a CD
> >>player built in that's controllable from the turntable
> >>platter.  So you get your full vinyl feel in the
> >>spins, but you can have CDs packed full of MP3s to
> >>play from, or switch back and forth depending on what
> >>you've got handy.
> >>
> >>What I'd like to see is this tech taken just one step
> >>further.  They need to incorporate a 250Gb hard drive
> >>into the thing, so you can rip tunes from your CDs or
> >>directly from vinyl and then store them in the deck's
> >>internal hard drive.  Imagine having 60k+ songs that
> >>you could call up instantly and then manipulate like
> >>vinyl, plus still have the flexibility to play CDs and
> >>vinyls in the set, all off one unit.  That would kick
> >>some serious boo-tay.

easier to transport...  well, that was an easy choice!

> one going back out to the mixer...

> nothing, nothing could possibly go wrong.  Nothing.
>
> -troy

I didn't say FS. I said SSL. FS is crap.

I'm not sure what high end clubs out there that you go to that dont have 
air conditioning and fans that would allow the temp to get to 90', would 
have wall-warts dangling from extension cords, or allow drunks party 
people into the deejay booth, but I have never been to one.

tsheets@saturn5.com wrote:

>yes, and I am sure in a 90'F club, with water dripping from the ceiling,
>trainspotters and dancers crowded all around you, the power system
>maxed to the limit, big wallwarts dangling off power strips, drunk
>people with their sticky drinks leaving them on your setup, AND...
>
>a USB hard drive plugged into someone else's laptop and a FS dongle
>also plugged in receiving two coded audio feeds from the turntables and
>one going back out to the mixer...
>
>nothing, nothing could possibly go wrong.  Nothing.    
>
>-troy
>
>On Tue, Nov 21, 2006 at 12:43:31PM -0800, Gavin Varitech wrote:
>  
>
>>A lot of big clubs and mobile sound companies have the Serato hardware 
>>installed already. All you have to do is plug in your notebook and go, 
>>no touching of the mixer at all. Also, a few clubs have Serato and a 
>>computer already set up. In this case, all the deejay has to do is play 
>>in their hard drive via USB and go. The best part is that the Scratch 
>>Live software will stay open AND leave the last track playing while HDs 
>>are being exchanged. Plug and play!
>>
>>Greg Albrecht wrote:
>>
>>    
>>
>>>what would facilitate the usage of the FS system is a mixer with top
>>>mounted bypass or tap inputs, saving you having to dig around behind
>>>the mixer. that or a mixer with the FS interface built in. just plug
>>>in USB and go.
>>>
>>>-g
>>>
>>>On 21/11/06, georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:
>>>
>>>      
>>>
>>>>The Numark HDX turntable uses hard drives mounted in removable 
>>>>cartridges a dj can carry with them and just slot in and go- the rub 
>>>>is, the damn deck costs $2500, and nobody in their right mind will 
>>>>ever install one in a club system- way too expensive and proprietary.
>>>>
>>>>I'd say, despite occasional niggles with plugging in in the hectic 
>>>>environment of a gig, carrying around a Final Scratch/Serato/Torq 
>>>>system is a WAY better bet.  A $600 cheap PC laptop + a $3-600 vinyl 
>>>>interface system = a setup you can fit into a messenger bag and set 
>>>>up at any club in 5 minutes.  Done.  No need to reinvent the wheel- 
>>>>just put the right tire on it.
>>>>
>>>>-GC
>>>>
>>>>----- Original Message ----
>>>>From: Uncle Noah <unclenoah@yahoo.com>
>>>>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>>>>Sent: Tuesday, November 21, 2006 11:41:28 AM
>>>>Subject: RE: [sfraves] Turntable technology (was: How Vinyl Records 
>>>>are Made)
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>I still love the feel and sound of vinyl.  And having
>>>>gone through the production process for both full-on
>>>>CD replication and vinyl production, I have to say
>>>>that from a production standpoint, I also prefer
>>>>vinyl.
>>>>
>>>>But vinyl is hard to sell.  With so many distros
>>>>tanking (as has been documented here on SFR) and with
>>>>many DJs moving to all-digital setups, moving a coupel
>>>>hundred units of vinyl is a daunting task, even for
>>>>established artists.
>>>>
>>>>The thing that continues to amaze me is the
>>>>advancement of DJ turntable technology.  I just heard
>>>>about the Numark x2 Hybrid Turntable - it's got a
>>>>setup much like the beloved TTX, but also has a CD
>>>>player built in that's controllable from the turntable
>>>>platter.  So you get your full vinyl feel in the
>>>>spins, but you can have CDs packed full of MP3s to
>>>>play from, or switch back and forth depending on what
>>>>you've got handy.
>>>>
>>>>What I'd like to see is this tech taken just one step
>>>>further.  They need to incorporate a 250Gb hard drive
>>>>into the thing, so you can rip tunes from your CDs or
>>>>directly from vinyl and then store them in the deck's
>>>>internal hard drive.  Imagine having 60k+ songs that
>>>>you could call up instantly and then manipulate like
>>>>vinyl, plus still have the flexibility to play CDs and
>>>>vinyls in the set, all off one unit.  That would kick
>>>>some serious boo-tay.
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>___________________________________________________________________
>>>>"May the wings of Liberty never lose a feather." - Jack Burton
>>>>
>>>>

"I just don't have the discipline to be a hippie"    <- Homer J. Simpson

>>>On Tue, Nov 21, 2006 at 12:43:31PM -0800, Gavin Varitech wrote:
>>>
>>>
>>>      
>>>
>>>>A lot of big clubs and mobile sound companies have the Serato hardware 
>>>>installed already. All you have to do is plug in your notebook and go, 
>>>>no touching of the mixer at all. Also, a few clubs have Serato and a 
>>>>computer already set up. In this case, all the deejay has to do is play 
>>>>in their hard drive via USB and go. The best part is that the Scratch 
>>>>Live software will stay open AND leave the last track playing while HDs 
>>>>are being exchanged. Plug and play!
>>>>
>>>>Greg Albrecht wrote:
>>>>
>>>>  
>>>>
>>>>        
>>>>
>>>>>what would facilitate the usage of the FS system is a mixer with top
>>>>>mounted bypass or tap inputs, saving you having to dig around behind
>>>>>the mixer. that or a mixer with the FS interface built in. just plug
>>>>>in USB and go.
>>>>>
>>>>>-g
>>>>>
>>>>>On 21/11/06, georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:
>>>>>
>>>>>    
>>>>>
>>>>>          
>>>>>
>>>>>>The Numark HDX turntable uses hard drives mounted in removable 
>>>>>>cartridges a dj can carry with them and just slot in and go- the rub 
>>>>>>is, the damn deck costs $2500, and nobody in their right mind will 
>>>>>>ever install one in a club system- way too expensive and proprietary.
>>>>>>
>>>>>>I'd say, despite occasional niggles with plugging in in the hectic 
>>>>>>environment of a gig, carrying around a Final Scratch/Serato/Torq 
>>>>>>system is a WAY better bet.  A $600 cheap PC laptop + a $3-600 vinyl 
>>>>>>interface system = a setup you can fit into a messenger bag and set 
>>>>>>up at any club in 5 minutes.  Done.  No need to reinvent the wheel- 
>>>>>>just put the right tire on it.
>>>>>>
>>>>>>-GC
>>>>>>
>>>>>>----- Original Message ----
>>>>>>From: Uncle Noah <unclenoah@yahoo.com>
>>>>>>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>>>>>>Sent: Tuesday, November 21, 2006 11:41:28 AM
>>>>>>Subject: RE: [sfraves] Turntable technology (was: How Vinyl Records 
>>>>>>are Made)
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>>I still love the feel and sound of vinyl.  And having
>>>>>>gone through the production process for both full-on
>>>>>>CD replication and vinyl production, I have to say
>>>>>>that from a production standpoint, I also prefer
>>>>>>vinyl.
>>>>>>
>>>>>>But vinyl is hard to sell.  With so many distros
>>>>>>tanking (as has been documented here on SFR) and with
>>>>>>many DJs moving to all-digital setups, moving a coupel
>>>>>>hundred units of vinyl is a daunting task, even for
>>>>>>established artists.
>>>>>>
>>>>>>The thing that continues to amaze me is the
>>>>>>advancement of DJ turntable technology.  I just heard
>>>>>>about the Numark x2 Hybrid Turntable - it's got a
>>>>>>setup much like the beloved TTX, but also has a CD
>>>>>>player built in that's controllable from the turntable
>>>>>>platter.  So you get your full vinyl feel in the
>>>>>>spins, but you can have CDs packed full of MP3s to
>>>>>>play from, or switch back and forth depending on what
>>>>>>you've got handy.
>>>>>>
>>>>>>What I'd like to see is this tech taken just one step
>>>>>>further.  They need to incorporate a 250Gb hard drive
>>>>>>into the thing, so you can rip tunes from your CDs or
>>>>>>directly from vinyl and then store them in the deck's
>>>>>>internal hard drive.  Imagine having 60k+ songs that
>>>>>>you could call up instantly and then manipulate like
>>>>>>vinyl, plus still have the flexibility to play CDs and
>>>>>>vinyls in the set, all off one unit.  That would kick
>>>>>>some serious boo-tay.
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>>___________________________________________________________________
>>>>>>"May the wings of Liberty never lose a feather." - Jack Burton

-----Original Message-----
From: Mary Morris [mailto:morrism@washpost.com]
Sent: Tuesday, November 21, 2006 3:39 PM

Subject: [sfraves] sharam (deep dish): global underground 29 - dubai






for Ryan Smith.

mary  :)

SHARAM DOES DUBAI =E2=80=93 GLOBAL UNDERGROUND 29

Dubai, one of seven sheikdoms comprising the oil rich United Arab =
Emirates
(once known as the Pirate Coast, bordered by Saudi Arabia, Oman and the
Persian Gulf), has boomed from a little trading port into a major =
gateway
to the Middle East. Now a powerful business and tourist magnet, Dubai is
soon to be home to the world=E2=80=99s tallest building and the =
world=E2=80=99s largest
shopping mall.

Small wonder Global Underground picked Dubai for the 29th in its
prestigious mix-CD series, featuring Sharam Tayebi, the harder half of =
2001
Grammy Award-winning duo Deep Dish. =E2=80=9CSharam: Dubai GU29=E2=80=9D =
is two CDs, one
dubbed =E2=80=9CThe Club=E2=80=9D and the other =E2=80=9CThe =
Hub,=E2=80=9D inspired by his April 6, 2006
gig at super-club Trilogy.

The Deep Dish trademark vibe, rich, warm, sensuous, soulful house that
seeps into body and spirit like virtual comfort food, is in full force
albeit with Sharam=E2=80=99s more tempestuous sensibilities. CD1 rolls =
with hard
thumping gusto in a wide spectrum of flavors such as the smooth jazzy
Herbie Hancock-esque keyboard noodling on 16 Bit Lolitas=E2=80=99 =
=E2=80=9CPassing Lights=E2=80=9D
and the dark ethereal synth rock of the Felix da Housecat remix of =
Syntax=E2=80=99s
=E2=80=9CBliss.=E2=80=9D CD2 begins playfully, kicking off old school =
disco style, and
unwinding lightheartedly, peaking with an exciting emotional fusion of
string ensemble meets four-on-the-floor in =E2=80=9CThe Cello =
Track=E2=80=9D by TwoTrumps
that folds into an evocative Fleetwood Mac-reminiscent =E2=80=9CWho Is =
Watching=E2=80=9D by
Armin van Buuren feat. Nadia Ali, and ending gently with Planet =
Funk=E2=80=99s
wistful, hopeful, lilting =E2=80=9CEveryday.=E2=80=9D

On September 18, Sharam spoke with Music Monthly from his home in =
Virginia
between gigs at the start of his North American tour to promote GU29.

Music Monthly: Could you describe Dubai and Club Trilogy?

Sharam:  Dubai is like Las Vegas without the casinos. It=E2=80=99s a =
beautiful new
city, expanding faster than Vegas, full of mega structures and =
outrageous
buildings, restaurants and hotels. It=E2=80=99s an incredible =
environment as far as
what humans can do if they really put their minds into it. They have
manmade islands, they=E2=80=99re about to have the tallest building in =
the world by
a large margin, and a ski resort in a desert. It=E2=80=99s a manmade =
heaven, if you
will. The people are extremely friendly. It=E2=80=99s very cosmopolitan. =
It=E2=80=99s
become an international hub in the Middle East for tourists and business
people from all around the world.

I would compare Trilogy to Club XIIXXIII or Spank in the DC area. Very
posh, very bling bling. People dress up to go there, but it also caters =
to
people who are just regular clubbers, so they have table service and =
also
bar service. It has a very nice sound system, very nice dance floor, =
very
good flow to it. It=E2=80=99s a very well-designed club that caters to =
all sorts of
DJs and all sorts of people from all walks of life.

MM:  What is Dubai=E2=80=99s club culture like?

Sharam:  Just like anywhere else. Once you=E2=80=99re inside a club, you =
could be
in Tokyo, New York or Buenos Aires. Dubai is like any other city. People
are very open minded and actually it=E2=80=99s surprising because you =
might think
the Middle East would not be so open and warm to this sort of =
environment,
but they are. There are people who are extremely educated in the music =
who
come and have a good time.

MM:  Dubai boasts the world=E2=80=99s only seven-star hotel, Burj El =
Arab. Have you
been there?

Sharam:  Yes. It=E2=80=99s a self-proclaimed seven-star hotel. =
It=E2=80=99s an iconic
structure, sort of like the Opera House in Sydney or the Eiffel Tower in
Paris. Once you see it, anybody can draw it in three hand strokes and
anyone could recognize it. Outside of that, it=E2=80=99s an extremely =
posh hotel,
beautifully designed, and what your fantasy suite would be except that
every room is like that.

MM:  Could you compare GU Dubai to Deep Dish=E2=80=99s earlier GU =
releases, Moscow
(GU21, 2001) and Toronto (GU25, 2003)?

Sharam:  Our compilations are basically pieces of history from our DJ
travels, the music we play during our travels in a specific period of =
time,
so this one represents what happened playing the past year and what =
I=E2=80=99ll be
playing probably for the next six months. It=E2=80=99s a combination of =
music I
personally like and that I also think people will enjoy. I=E2=80=99ve =
always had
the motto that as a DJ my job is educating while entertaining. =
I=E2=80=99ve tried
to do the same thing with this CD, trying to highlight some of the up =
and
coming producers as well as some of the more established artists with =
new
songs, but the common theme between all of it is good music.

CD1 is called =E2=80=9CThe Club=E2=80=9D which basically encapsulates =
what you would be
hearing at a club. CD2, I called it =E2=80=9CThe Hub,=E2=80=9D could be =
viewed two ways.
One is before you go to a club you want to get in the mood, you put it =
on
and it=E2=80=99s deep, more house-y, and builds and builds and by the =
time you get
to the middle and towards the end, you=E2=80=99re ready to go have a =
good time in a
night club. Or it could be viewed as an after-hours CD where =
you=E2=80=99re done
with the hype and commotion inside the club and you want to listen to
something a little more house-y, a little more laid back.

MM:  What=E2=80=99s behind the Deep Dish remix of =E2=80=9CThe Other =
Side=E2=80=9D by Paul van Dyk
featuring Wayne Jackson?

Sharam:  It was Paul=E2=80=99s first single from his album =E2=80=9CThe =
Politics of Dancing
2.=E2=80=9D They sent it to us. I really liked the song and told Ali =
(=E2=80=9CDubfire=E2=80=9D
Shirazinia, the other half of Deep Dish), there=E2=80=99s something =
unique about
this. We were one of the first to use guitar in dance music and every =
time
someone else does it, we have a special place in our hearts for them.
Immediately we were like this song has guitar but all the traditional
elements of dance music as well so we thought we could do something cool
with it, so we did the remix. Paul, in return, did a remix of our single =
at
the time, =E2=80=9CSay Hello.=E2=80=9D We swapped. We=E2=80=99re good =
friends.

MM:  The =E2=80=9CCello Track=E2=80=9D by TwoTrumps on CD2 is a =
showstopper.

Sharam:  The guys who produced that track are from Denmark. I=E2=80=99ve =
been
playing it exclusively for about a year now and finally decided that
somebody needs to bring more attention to it so I signed it to our =
label,
Yoshitoshi, and put it on the CD. Amazing instrumental track. =
There=E2=80=99s going
to be another version coming out with vocals on it.
There=E2=80=99s a total of thirteen Yoshitoshi tracks on this album that =
will be
available on our website Yoshop.com or iTunes or Beatport.com in the =
next
few months.

MM:  What other tracks do you absolutely love on GU29?

Sharam:  That=E2=80=99s hard. Every song represents something different =
and serves
a purpose so there=E2=80=99s not one I love more than another. Some =
tracks are
viewed as fillers, but without them the songs before and after would not
shine as much. So I love them all, but if I had to choose one, then I =
would
say I want to choose two because one would be the first track on the =
first
CD (Dyad 10=E2=80=99s =E2=80=9CSugar (Sweet Thing)=E2=80=9D Nicka & Alse =
remix), a beautiful sweet
vocal record, and the first track on CD2, =E2=80=9CDirect Me=E2=80=9D by =
Reese Project,
which is actually a song from 1992. At the time that record was =
extremely
influential and inspirational for me and I wanted to bring it back and
introduce it to a whole new audience. It=E2=80=99s Joey Negro=E2=80=99s =
remix. To me, it=E2=80=99s
one of the best pieces of music ever created.

MM:  What=E2=80=99s the story with Deep Dish=E2=80=99s =E2=80=9CPATT =
(Party All The Time)=E2=80=9D single,
the most sought after buzz record of the 2006 Winter Music Conference?

Sharam:  That=E2=80=99s a record I did for a WMC seminar. Basically I =
wanted to do
a fun, happy party record. I tapped into Eddie Murphy=E2=80=99s =
=E2=80=9CParty All The
Time=E2=80=9D and sampled a piece of it and it blew up, took on a life =
of its own.
There was such a strong reaction to it we decided to release it, so I
rerecorded the vocals and you have =E2=80=9CPATT.=E2=80=9D It=E2=80=99s =
out now in the U.S. and
Europe.

MM:  Why are you and Ali working solo now?

Sharam:  We=E2=80=99ve been doing things together for a long time and we =
always get
bored very fast. We just had our [artist] album (=E2=80=9CGeorge Is =
On=E2=80=9D) released
last year and we did eight or nine compilations together. So [GU29] was
something new. We wanted to do something different, that challenges us
individually, so we thought let=E2=80=99s each do some productions and =
compilation
albums on our own and sort of flex our personal muscles. It helps to get
away from something to realize certain things about it. Then when we =
come
back to it, I think we=E2=80=99ll have better and fresher minds so the =
next album
we do won=E2=80=99t be a repeat of stuff we=E2=80=99ve done in the past =
but something
completely different. Also, we=E2=80=99re two different individuals with =
different
musical, DJ=E2=80=99ing and production styles, so this is a great =
opportunity for
us to showcase all of that.

MM:  Who is Matt Nordstrom, whose name appeared with Deep Dish=E2=80=99s =
for your
2006 Grammy nomination for =E2=80=9CSay Hello=E2=80=9D?

Sharam:  He=E2=80=99s our engineer. He=E2=80=99s involved with all of =
our projects. I call
him our 24/7 tech support because he=E2=80=99s always there, =
he=E2=80=99s always available,
and he=E2=80=99s always amazing. None of this stuff would be available =
as easily if
we were to do it without him.

MM:  Where do you keep your 2001 Grammy?

Sharam:  (sigh) You know, it=E2=80=99s in my old apartment in a box. I =
haven=E2=80=99t even
brought it to my new house yet. That doesn=E2=80=99t sound so good, does =
it?
(laughs)

MM:  What are you working on now?

Sharam:  I just finished a track for the astronaut Anousheh Ansari who =
went
into space today. She=E2=80=99s the first female private space explorer. =
I wrote
the theme song =E2=80=9CBe the Change,=E2=80=9D for her website.

MM:  Deep Dish has done lots of charity fundraising. Do you have =
favorite
charities?

Sharam:  Outside of the unexpected stuff that happens like hurricanes =
and
earthquakes, we=E2=80=99ve always tried to do as much as we can to help =
the needy.
We=E2=80=99re always involved with charities like the Children=E2=80=99s =
Foundation,
anything that has to do with the kids, enabling them to have a better
education and have a better life.

MM:  What are you most of proud of in your career so far?

Sharam:  The most proud/surreal moment for me was with =E2=80=9CParty =
All The Time=E2=80=9D
because that song was originally written by Rick James and the new
composition is basically a collaboration between me and Rick James, a =
new
writer and the original writer. When I saw my name next to Rick =
James=E2=80=99s, I
was like, all right, you know what, that=E2=80=99s it. If today is the =
last day
that I do music, I=E2=80=99m fine with that. (laughs)

mary ishimoto morris
music monthly
november 2006
www.musicmonthly.com

I know this isn't a joke list, but it's dead today so here:
   
  My wonderful   girlfriend and I had been dating for over a year, and so
we
decided to get  married.  There was only one   little thing bothering
me.
It was her beautiful younger sister.  My prospective   sister-in-law 
was
twenty-two, wore very tight miniskirts, and generally was bra-less.  
One
day
"little" sister called and asked me to come over to check the wedding
invitations.  She was alone when I arrived, and she whispered to me 
that
she
had feelings and desires for me that she couldn't overcome.  She told 
me
that she wanted to make love to me just once before I got married and
committed my life to her sister.  Well, I was in total shock, and
couldn't
say a word. She said, "I'm going upstairs to my bedroom, and if you 
want
one
last wild fling, just come up and get   me."  I was stunned and frozen
in
shock as I watched her go up the   stairs.  When she reached the top 
she
pulled off her panties and threw them down the stairs at me.   I stood
there
for a moment, then turned and made a beeline straight to the front 
door.
I
opened the door, and headed straight towards my car.  Lo and behold, my
entire future family was standing outside, all clapping!  With tears in
his
eyes, my future father-in-law hugged me and said, "we are very happy
that
you have passed our little test.....we couldn't ask for a better man 
for
our
daughter. Welcome to the family."  

   And the moral of this story is:

   Always keep your condoms in your car.

i am on east coast time ... (and i just woke up from a nap).  the  
thing is, i *was* thinking about going to Cool Whip in DC tonight.  i  
really want to see Photek, they are great.  if i do that, i can  
expect a nice drive with lots and lots of rain and winds shifting  
from the east to the north by the time i get to DC 23 mph with 28 mph  
gusts.  oh, 39 degrees.  you should see this jacket i bought in  
boston a couple years ago.  ecko function double down reversible XL  
size cause that's the last one they had.  only paid 60 smackers for  
the thing and it's white and it doesn't matter if it's 5 degrees out  
i'm sweatin in that thing, only thing is i look like the michelin man  
in it, it's friggen dope tho.

i think weather is interesting though!  i want to chase at least one  
tornado in my life.

once.  Speaking of second chances, you don't need a second chance  
when it comes to fast food, they will give you as many chances as you

stuff just because it's disgusting, pulling into a drive-thru is now  
becoming a last resort.  Speaking of driving, I almost hydro-locked  
my car in a big puddle a couple months ago, I'll never be stupid like

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Alex Jones

I didn't put BSP on this but it's a plug for the Alex Jones show, so  
if you don't like such things just hit delete now ... by the way, I  
did mention raves at the end so maybe I should have taken the (nrr) out.

Anyway, I listen to Alex on my iPod because it's easier for me and we  
don't get him around here.  And he asked his listeners to email their  
lists and post the message boards, so that's what I'm doing because I  
believe in what this guy is doing and the priceless information and  
decoding of the endless political spin.

Anyway, I was just looking for the list of stations that play Alex  
Jones but I remember he said a while back that when they listed the  
stations on the internet, they would have people calling all the  
stations and threatening them.  So I actually don't know if you can  
listen to him in the Bay Area, I could research it, but googling  
didn't come up with anything right off the bat, so hopefully someone  
that knows and listens can post it.

So listen, everyone, I never told you I think you should listen to  
Michael Savage, I still find him sometimes mildly entertaining, and I  
follow Bob Wilson's strategy, which is to get some of my information  
from extreme sources just to see if I might be missing something.

Anyway, I'm urging you to do me a personal favor and go to the  
internet and subscribe to his 2 podcasts, just type in Alex Jones  
Show podcast and Prison Planet Podcast and listen to his show for one  
week.  And I mean really listen, and if you hear something you don't  
believe, research it.  That's something I'm convinced most people  
don't do, research, they just believe whatever is on the newspaper  
stands or what is bullet point served to them on headline TV news.  I  
really think we have a good chance of saving this country if we wake  
enough people up, but we've got to be expedient.  Think of the  
condition of the rave scene if the elite is able to set up a world  
government and a world police state.  Think of it, and I know you'll  
make the right decision.

So anyway, remember, podcast, and also, the websites:

http://www.infowars.com
http://www.prisonplanet.com
http://www.jonesreport.com
http://www.arnoldexposed.com

i just read this from the bayraves forum...i thought i share....

PLEASE DRIVE SAFETLY.....love ya guys..
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ladera Ranch woman killed in 241 collision
Nicole Catsouras, 18, lost control of a Porsche 911 at over 100 mph before crossing median and crashing into northbound toll booth.
By RYAN HAMMILL
The Orange County Register

LAKE FOREST  An Ladera Ranch woman was killed in a two-car collision on the south side of the Eastern (241) Toll Road in Lake Forest on Tuesday.

Nicole Catsouras, 18, lost control of a black Porsche 911 Carrera while attempting to pass another vehicle at more than 100 mph, California Highway Patrol officials said.

The Porsche crossed the center median, traveled across north lanes and the Alton Parkway southbound on-ramp, before colliding into a toll booth building.

Catsouras was pronounced dead at the scene from head trauma.

Police said she was attempting to pass a gray Honda Civic traveling about 70 mph in the far left lane, when the Porsche clipped the Honda and lost control.

The Honda then veered to the left and hit the center median.

The driver of the Honda, a 20-year-old man from Rancho Santa Margarita, was taken by ambulance to Mission Hospital with minor to moderate injuries. Both drivers were wearing seatbelts.

Police found open alcoholic beverage containers inside of the Honda but alcohol is not suspected as a cause of the collision, CHP officials said.

A toll booth operator was believed to be in the structure at the time of the accident. There were no additional injuries, CHP officials said.

http://www.ocregister.com/ocregister/news/local/communities/rsm/article_1340232.php

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)

Well, for those that are keeping up on my to do list, events, and  
action items, I did in fact finally make that vodka martini last  
night, home made, with grey goose and martini and rossi vermouth,  
extra dry, shaken not stirred.  Also had a couple Crown Royal and  
Coke.  Decided not to go out because the weather is pretty bad here  
right now.  I actually had trouble making it home from work yesterday  
because all the routes into the part of town I live in were flooded  
except for one.  A 10 minute drive took me almost 2 hours because I  
kept having to find another route.  And my cold air intake is  
downpiped by the wheel well, so I can't even think of risking any  
deep puddles.

Anyway, I don't want to hold you guys up from watching the Macy's  
Thanksgiving Day Parade.  Enjoy!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) Alex Jones, now re: podcasting

i just thought i'd throw my $.02 in here. there seems to be, at least
from what i've experienced, a misconception that podcasts, such as the
one deepfog brought up, are only accessible to those of you who have
ipods, itunes, or macs.

for the record, you do not need an ipod to listen to a podcast. anyone
with any mp3 player on any platform can listen to a podcast, which is,
essentially, just an mp3 (usually).

if you're entertaining coming over to the world of podcasts, may i
suggest you read:

http://theletterg.org/subscribe/

and

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Podcasting

-g
