 <7a86c50c0611241420p3ef08867xbf0edd48fcea2a3f@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Jeff Mills & What the Fuck is Wrong with San Francisco?


So Jeff Mills played last night.  Sound was good, the guy showed, he was 
playing a smoother more mature version of what I'd hoped he'd play.  By 
the end of the few hours he played, I felt I'd been educated and given an 
opprtunity to finally see one of my musical heroes.  Minimal cuts and 
deeper tracks often being layer to create tastefully layered collages, 
some braver sounds with polyrhythmic elements usually more typical of NYC 
or UK techno, the people were great, teases going on for several tracks 
before dropping into genre defining works like "the bells".  A handful of 
those moments where the elements of of one track have been reduced to 8 
no... 16 no... 32 bars of all treble cranked snares with the crowd eating 
it up, hands in the air, before pulling the pin on that grenade and 
exploding into another bass and percussion driven grinder.  At times 
driven by the repeated chanting of a soulful voice against sparse piano 
chord stabs, other times setting it up with the plingy music box 
percussion doing call and response with the looming basslines and driving 
909 he's best known for, almost every mix totally craft.  The type of 
pressure mixes where a masterful control of the mixer allowed tension to 
be built across a third piece of music where 2 tracks overlapped, traded 
voices, pressurized and shot out into a new idea using only volume and 
equalization.

And the crowd was *DOWN*, fucking way good times were had by most if not 
all.

Followed by...

DJ Seven?

Are you fucking serious, hope the favor or whatever went down was worth 
it.  Waiting behind Jeff Mills without even seeming particuarly polite or 
aware of the fact that we'd just like more passion and science, neither 
his respect nor enthusiasm seemed at all bonafide.  Fumbling along like a 
guppy with a hardon, the local name in my experience more synonymous with 
unsolicited email promotion than bringing anything new or interesting to 
the SF scene, we made a fucking ass of ourselves.  A couple mixes as he 
flopped between hyphenated genres was all it took to get me the fuck out 
of there.

Nevermind that I ran into at least 25 DJs and/or producers in the crowd 
who would have done a better job, put records out, have a definitive style 
and done the time.  Or thought of at least 25 more that would have been 
great.  Never mind that the greater San Francsico area is home to some of 
the best in the genre period.  Or maybe we could have had one of SF's 
distinctive twist on house legend come in.  Or maybe a respectful silence.  
Or maybe anything but a freaking spammer who social climbed his way into 
our club culture on an email list that most of us never signed up for... 
of all things last night playing whack ass boring cheese breaks and 
progressive miasma after an extended dancefloor dicking from the mutha 
fucking Wizard of the 313, a guy so synonymous with proper high intensity 
DJing that for years "Jeff Mills" was a slang for mdma in Britan.

Maybe they wanted the place to clear out fast, I'm not sure.  If so, why 
bother with music.  I don't think there was a soul in there that would 
have had a problem with being let down hard to the sound of tinnitus, 
promises to keep in touch and strangers around them mumbling about what 
they'd just experienced and where to find a proper hash brown at 4am.

Thanks to the promoters for footing the bill for bringing out who is 
generally considered the world's first proper techno DJ, but *wow* that 
was a weird choice for follow up.  Some 5 + years ago when DJ Seven first 
showed up putting out his "picks" list it might have been ok (his skills 
were horrible then but at least he was playing tasteful housey stuff that 
would have been a lot more appropriate)... but WTF was that.  I think even 
DJ Seven was capable of far better, but his heart wasn't in it or 
something, maybe he just didn't know or thought it wouldn't be right to 
play techno or minimal house after Mills (it was just sounding seriously 
"make the drunk marina chicks dance" clubber trash).  Jon Williams would 
have killed in that slot.  Eli Bingham would have killed in that slot.  
Or Twerk, or Jonah Sharp, Kit Clayton or Andre Lucero.  Mark Johns, Monty, 
Joe Rice, tons of folks who know what the fuck and what for would have 
done great (and I won't even go into my "San Jose gets the dick again" 
rant).  So many serious veteran deck technicians, techno luminaries, mad 
collectors, genius producers, and we get *ow my head* a club scene staple 
who has so little to do with the local techno community.

Look at what brought that decision on, and fix it.  So much talent in this 
town, so many people who would have done that slot right but apparently 
the favor network still rules... just ridiculous in light of all the 
talent (just in the audience last night let alone in town) that would have 
killed for that slot.  Shit, Mark Johns and Monty played other slots that 
night and they would have been more appropriate by an order of magnitude.  
Just *irksome* to hear something that good followed by something so blah 
while I'm bumping into local techno badass after local techno badass all 
night at a $25 show with the expectation that I'm gonna be experiencing 
some of the best in the world supported by (hopefully) the best in town.

This was like booking me after Tipper or Freq Nasty at a breaks party or 
something.  No, take that back, I think I'd shred after those guys and if 
the crowd wasn't getting it at least I'd be hitting the best I know how.  
Cause when you love this life, you don't "kinda have intercourse" and you 
don't go half-ass when they hand you the keys to the whip.

Think this is the crabbiest I've felt since that time Laidback Luke and 
Tim Taylor played at an Area51 here and all there kids just sat there on 
the floor with their fucking pacifiers and slot machine eyeballs giving 
each other back rubs waiting for Mystere to come on.

fknsrsly.
andyw

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Jeff Mills & What the Fuck is Wrong with San Francisco?

i've been to a lot of parties this year and i'd say i enjoyed being on
that dancefloor more than any other party of the year.  it was packed
and hot and sweaty and as andy stated...the crowd was really reacting
to the music.  hands in the air.

it was the most rave feeling i've ever had on the mighty dancefloor.

even though i left a little early, i had a really great time.  mills
got my juices flowing.

i'm going to go play records now.

On 11/26/06, AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:
>
> So Jeff Mills played last night.  Sound was good, the guy showed, he was
> playing a smoother more mature version of what I'd hoped he'd play.  By
> the end of the few hours he played, I felt I'd been educated and given an
> opprtunity to finally see one of my musical heroes.  Minimal cuts and
> deeper tracks often being layer to create tastefully layered collages,
> some braver sounds with polyrhythmic elements usually more typical of NYC
> or UK techno, the people were great, teases going on for several tracks
> before dropping into genre defining works like "the bells".  A handful of
> those moments where the elements of of one track have been reduced to 8
> no... 16 no... 32 bars of all treble cranked snares with the crowd eating
> it up, hands in the air, before pulling the pin on that grenade and
> exploding into another bass and percussion driven grinder.  At times
> driven by the repeated chanting of a soulful voice against sparse piano
> chord stabs, other times setting it up with the plingy music box
> percussion doing call and response with the looming basslines and driving
> 909 he's best known for, almost every mix totally craft.  The type of
> pressure mixes where a masterful control of the mixer allowed tension to
> be built across a third piece of music where 2 tracks overlapped, traded
> voices, pressurized and shot out into a new idea using only volume and
> equalization.
>
> And the crowd was *DOWN*, fucking way good times were had by most if not

Didn't stay til the end of Jeff's set, but I was really diggin what ML
Tronik was playin for the opening set- even if his technical skills don't
come close to the Wizard's.  Aside from a sloppy first mix out of ML's last
track, I wasn't blown away by Alain Octavo's set, but was impressed that a
spundae resident who mainly plays progressive house had some decent taste in
techno.  I didn't even hear Seven's set, and even if I hadn't read your
review I'd be questioning the reasoning for this.  Maybe you're onto
something, does seven have a party in the works to bring jeff mills to none
other than the matrix- maybe gavin newsom can close out the night-  do you
think he'll play a white stripes bootleg? Wouldn't a live PA by EBE/Lucas
Rodenbush work for such a slot, hell why not fly up John Tejada from LA if
they weren't gonna let jeff close the night out???

>

> playing a smoother more mature version of what I'd hoped he'd play.  By
> the end of the few hours he played, I felt I'd been educated and given an
> opprtunity to finally see one of my musical heroes.  Minimal cuts and
> deeper tracks often being layer to create tastefully layered collages,
> some braver sounds with polyrhythmic elements usually more typical of NYC
> or UK techno, the people were great, teases going on for several tracks
> before dropping into genre defining works like "the bells".  A handful of
> those moments where the elements of of one track have been reduced to 8
> no... 16 no... 32 bars of all treble cranked snares with the crowd eating
> it up, hands in the air, before pulling the pin on that grenade and
> exploding into another bass and percussion driven grinder.  At times
> driven by the repeated chanting of a soulful voice against sparse piano
> chord stabs, other times setting it up with the plingy music box
> percussion doing call and response with the looming basslines and driving
> 909 he's best known for, almost every mix totally craft.  The type of
> pressure mixes where a masterful control of the mixer allowed tension to
> be built across a third piece of music where 2 tracks overlapped, traded
> voices, pressurized and shot out into a new idea using only volume and
> equalization.
>
> And the crowd was *DOWN*, fucking way good times were had by most if not
> all.
>
> Followed by...
>
> DJ Seven?
>
> Are you fucking serious, hope the favor or whatever went down was worth
> it.  Waiting behind Jeff Mills without even seeming particuarly polite or
> aware of the fact that we'd just like more passion and science, neither
> his respect nor enthusiasm seemed at all bonafide.  Fumbling along like a
> guppy with a hardon, the local name in my experience more synonymous with
> unsolicited email promotion than bringing anything new or interesting to
> the SF scene, we made a fucking ass of ourselves.  A couple mixes as he
> flopped between hyphenated genres was all it took to get me the fuck out
> of there.
>
> Nevermind that I ran into at least 25 DJs and/or producers in the crowd
> who would have done a better job, put records out, have a definitive style
> and done the time.  Or thought of at least 25 more that would have been
> great.  Never mind that the greater San Francsico area is home to some of
> the best in the genre period.  Or maybe we could have had one of SF's
> distinctive twist on house legend come in.  Or maybe a respectful silence.
> Or maybe anything but a freaking spammer who social climbed his way into
> our club culture on an email list that most of us never signed up for...
> of all things last night playing whack ass boring cheese breaks and
> progressive miasma after an extended dancefloor dicking from the mutha
> fucking Wizard of the 313, a guy so synonymous with proper high intensity
> DJing that for years "Jeff Mills" was a slang for mdma in Britan.
>
> Maybe they wanted the place to clear out fast, I'm not sure.  If so, why
> bother with music.  I don't think there was a soul in there that would
> have had a problem with being let down hard to the sound of tinnitus,
> promises to keep in touch and strangers around them mumbling about what
> they'd just experienced and where to find a proper hash brown at 4am.
>
> Thanks to the promoters for footing the bill for bringing out who is
> generally considered the world's first proper techno DJ, but *wow* that
> was a weird choice for follow up.  Some 5 + years ago when DJ Seven first
> showed up putting out his "picks" list it might have been ok (his skills
> were horrible then but at least he was playing tasteful housey stuff that
> would have been a lot more appropriate)... but WTF was that.  I think even
> DJ Seven was capable of far better, but his heart wasn't in it or
> something, maybe he just didn't know or thought it wouldn't be right to
> play techno or minimal house after Mills (it was just sounding seriously
> "make the drunk marina chicks dance" clubber trash).  Jon Williams would
> have killed in that slot.  Eli Bingham would have killed in that slot.
> Or Twerk, or Jonah Sharp, Kit Clayton or Andre Lucero.  Mark Johns, Monty,
> Joe Rice, tons of folks who know what the fuck and what for would have
> done great (and I won't even go into my "San Jose gets the dick again"
> rant).  So many serious veteran deck technicians, techno luminaries, mad
> collectors, genius producers, and we get *ow my head* a club scene staple
> who has so little to do with the local techno community.
>
> Look at what brought that decision on, and fix it.  So much talent in this
> town, so many people who would have done that slot right but apparently
> the favor network still rules... just ridiculous in light of all the
> talent (just in the audience last night let alone in town) that would have
> killed for that slot.  Shit, Mark Johns and Monty played other slots that
> night and they would have been more appropriate by an order of magnitude.
> Just *irksome* to hear something that good followed by something so blah
> while I'm bumping into local techno badass after local techno badass all
> night at a $25 show with the expectation that I'm gonna be experiencing
> some of the best in the world supported by (hopefully) the best in town.
>
> This was like booking me after Tipper or Freq Nasty at a breaks party or
> something.  No, take that back, I think I'd shred after those guys and if
> the crowd wasn't getting it at least I'd be hitting the best I know how.
> Cause when you love this life, you don't "kinda have intercourse" and you
> don't go half-ass when they hand you the keys to the whip.
>
> Think this is the crabbiest I've felt since that time Laidback Luke and
> Tim Taylor played at an Area51 here and all there kids just sat there on
> the floor with their fucking pacifiers and slot machine eyeballs giving
> each other back rubs waiting for Mystere to come on.
>
> fknsrsly.
> andyw
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>

  b=nPQWOguDtIOauiivN4c8dEDf5ia4w4iMP1FykSvtE2mr9k3s6XWpLrn0nayFr+xP6siJ3jVbrHraiwNcIHjLij/a+0JRAD9EJQ28z+u1d0dshqHt/7maDBC5vK9UyUW3LQP2dJtOHGSffv5VzM4LXhFJZ7ZT2DjgMNBE+A7k/eI=  ;
X-YMail-OSG: 66ihKQsVM1miDu3BA5Y.9ZyRyyfLfwjabjdpxloRO0Pa3OX7eSAXa6RhIaENHGV.f3CyfzOzb.t9Mimm5DM6vJpuJtyYDA2H.Q3HZMbbl8VEHrlpHGE0Zg--
From: "Chris Jackson" <cjax@sbcglobal.net>
To: "'AndyW'" <andy@saturn5.com>,
	"'SFR'" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Date: Mon, 27 Nov 2006 09:28:15 -0800

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Jeff Mills & What the Fuck is Wrong with San Francisco?

Ok.  So I'm sure that anybody who was looking, didn't see me on Saturday
night.  I was supposed to come back into town on Saturday afternoon, but my
travel plans got all fucked up....so I missed the show.  I was really
bummed.  But since talking to a few people and reading a few reviews....it
was probably a good thing!  If I was there and saw that DJ Seven was playing
after Mills, I might have thrown a bottle or glass at him or something.
Seriously.  To hear he was standing back there like some fucking lost
puppy...waiting for Mills to let him play his crap-ass cover tune mash-up
white labels makes me sick. 

Wasn't Blasthaus involved with this night??  Alain Octavio??  WTF??  I don't
give a fuck how surprised everybody was with his/her [ok...is this a fucking
man or woman?  i've heard both...and have been lucky enough NOT to witness
it's music first hand] non-progressive set....it isn't a TECHNO DJ!!  Why
the fuck would you have a non-techno DJ play at a Jeff Mills show?  Avalon
LA showed the bay area how to pick a supporting cast for Mills when they had
Hawtin play with him on Friday night.  SF's answer:  Alain Octavio and DJ
Seven?  Did the organizers think that nobody would show unless they put a
couple local, less capable, played out douche bags on the bill??  Like Andy
said, and MANY have confirmed....it was like a techno DJ pick list in there
Saturday night!  Not one of those guys/girls got the nod....but DJ Seven
did?  LOL!  Dr. Toolbox and his self promoting spam-a-thon?  Nice.  Way to
go SF!  Truly ground breaking stuff.  I'm glad I wasn't there, because I
would have the same nasty taste in my mouth as all the other local techno
DJ's/producers who got the shaft in favor of mediocrity.

=(

Chris

-----Original Message-----
From: AndyW [mailto:andy@saturn5.com] 
Sent: Sunday, November 26, 2006 1:37 PM
To: SFR
Subject: [sfraves] Jeff Mills & What the Fuck is Wrong with San Francisco?


So Jeff Mills played last night.  Sound was good, the guy showed, he was 
playing a smoother more mature version of what I'd hoped he'd play.  By 
the end of the few hours he played, I felt I'd been educated and given an 
opprtunity to finally see one of my musical heroes.  Minimal cuts and 
deeper tracks often being layer to create tastefully layered collages, 
some braver sounds with polyrhythmic elements usually more typical of NYC 
or UK techno, the people were great, teases going on for several tracks 
before dropping into genre defining works like "the bells".  A handful of 
those moments where the elements of of one track have been reduced to 8 
no... 16 no... 32 bars of all treble cranked snares with the crowd eating 
it up, hands in the air, before pulling the pin on that grenade and 
exploding into another bass and percussion driven grinder.  At times 
driven by the repeated chanting of a soulful voice against sparse piano 
chord stabs, other times setting it up with the plingy music box 
percussion doing call and response with the looming basslines and driving 
909 he's best known for, almost every mix totally craft.  The type of 
pressure mixes where a masterful control of the mixer allowed tension to 
be built across a third piece of music where 2 tracks overlapped, traded 
voices, pressurized and shot out into a new idea using only volume and 
equalization.

And the crowd was *DOWN*, fucking way good times were had by most if not 
all.

Followed by...

DJ Seven?

Are you fucking serious, hope the favor or whatever went down was worth 
it.  Waiting behind Jeff Mills without even seeming particuarly polite or 
aware of the fact that we'd just like more passion and science, neither 
his respect nor enthusiasm seemed at all bonafide.  Fumbling along like a 
guppy with a hardon, the local name in my experience more synonymous with 
unsolicited email promotion than bringing anything new or interesting to 
the SF scene, we made a fucking ass of ourselves.  A couple mixes as he 
flopped between hyphenated genres was all it took to get me the fuck out 
of there.

Nevermind that I ran into at least 25 DJs and/or producers in the crowd 
who would have done a better job, put records out, have a definitive style 
and done the time.  Or thought of at least 25 more that would have been 
great.  Never mind that the greater San Francsico area is home to some of 
the best in the genre period.  Or maybe we could have had one of SF's 
distinctive twist on house legend come in.  Or maybe a respectful silence.  
Or maybe anything but a freaking spammer who social climbed his way into 
our club culture on an email list that most of us never signed up for... 
of all things last night playing whack ass boring cheese breaks and 
progressive miasma after an extended dancefloor dicking from the mutha 
fucking Wizard of the 313, a guy so synonymous with proper high intensity 
DJing that for years "Jeff Mills" was a slang for mdma in Britan.

Maybe they wanted the place to clear out fast, I'm not sure.  If so, why 
bother with music.  I don't think there was a soul in there that would 
have had a problem with being let down hard to the sound of tinnitus, 
promises to keep in touch and strangers around them mumbling about what 
they'd just experienced and where to find a proper hash brown at 4am.

Thanks to the promoters for footing the bill for bringing out who is 
generally considered the world's first proper techno DJ, but *wow* that 
was a weird choice for follow up.  Some 5 + years ago when DJ Seven first 
showed up putting out his "picks" list it might have been ok (his skills 
were horrible then but at least he was playing tasteful housey stuff that 
would have been a lot more appropriate)... but WTF was that.  I think even 
DJ Seven was capable of far better, but his heart wasn't in it or 
something, maybe he just didn't know or thought it wouldn't be right to 
play techno or minimal house after Mills (it was just sounding seriously 
"make the drunk marina chicks dance" clubber trash).  Jon Williams would 
have killed in that slot.  Eli Bingham would have killed in that slot.  
Or Twerk, or Jonah Sharp, Kit Clayton or Andre Lucero.  Mark Johns, Monty, 
Joe Rice, tons of folks who know what the fuck and what for would have 
done great (and I won't even go into my "San Jose gets the dick again" 
rant).  So many serious veteran deck technicians, techno luminaries, mad 
collectors, genius producers, and we get *ow my head* a club scene staple 
who has so little to do with the local techno community.

Look at what brought that decision on, and fix it.  So much talent in this 
town, so many people who would have done that slot right but apparently 
the favor network still rules... just ridiculous in light of all the 
talent (just in the audience last night let alone in town) that would have 
killed for that slot.  Shit, Mark Johns and Monty played other slots that 
night and they would have been more appropriate by an order of magnitude.  
Just *irksome* to hear something that good followed by something so blah 
while I'm bumping into local techno badass after local techno badass all 
night at a $25 show with the expectation that I'm gonna be experiencing 
some of the best in the world supported by (hopefully) the best in town.

This was like booking me after Tipper or Freq Nasty at a breaks party or 
something.  No, take that back, I think I'd shred after those guys and if 
the crowd wasn't getting it at least I'd be hitting the best I know how.  
Cause when you love this life, you don't "kinda have intercourse" and you 
don't go half-ass when they hand you the keys to the whip.

Think this is the crabbiest I've felt since that time Laidback Luke and 
Tim Taylor played at an Area51 here and all there kids just sat there on 
the floor with their fucking pacifiers and slot machine eyeballs giving 
each other back rubs waiting for Mystere to come on.

fknsrsly.
andyw

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Jeff Mills & What the Fuck is Wrong with San Francisco?

ON A DJ Seven note: 

He pissed me off so bad with his spam that I had his
ISP shut his services down COMPLETELY at 3 different
ISP's over a oone year period. ALL BECAUSE HE WOULDN'T
stop spamming me. 

He is retarded, talentless, and a fucking "i'll
promote your event if you let me play" trust fund
fuckhole from Marin. He went to UCSD with me, and was
the Fraternity DJ there. We made fun of him then too.
He finally stopped his spamming when I sent him a
message telling him, " Do you know that you are the
butt of everyones jokes because EVERYONE knows that
all your gigs come from swappping promoting for
letting you DJ. It must suck knowing that everyone you
know and talk to is constantly ripping on you whenever
you turn your back?"

On what Andy said: I hate it too, but as much as I
hate it, you are going to have to accept that in order
to make money, clubs are doing things that would have
killed them in the 90's.... like booking format DJ's
to play everything under the sun, as that is what the
current "cllub crowd" wants. Long gone are the days of
DJ's telling a fantastic story of music from 9 pm to 6
am.... ah... the good ole days.

E

> night at a $25 show with the expectation that I'm
> gonna be experiencing 
> some of the best in the world supported by
> (hopefully) the best in town.
> 
> This was like booking me after Tipper or Freq Nasty
> at a breaks party or 
> something.  No, take that back, I think I'd shred
> after those guys and if 
> the crowd wasn't getting it at least I'd be hitting
> the best I know how.  
> Cause when you love this life, you don't "kinda have
> intercourse" and you 
> don't go half-ass when they hand you the keys to the
> whip.
> 
> Think this is the crabbiest I've felt since that
> time Laidback Luke and 
> Tim Taylor played at an Area51 here and all there
> kids just sat there on 
> the floor with their fucking pacifiers and slot
> machine eyeballs giving 
> each other back rubs waiting for Mystere to come on.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Jeff Mills & What the Fuck is Wrong with San Francisco?

When DJs become promoters (or vice versa), opening slots go to those folks =
these days.  It's one of the most annoying behaviors I've seen lately.  "I'=
m throwing the party, putting up all this money, and my boy so-and-so hooke=
d up the sound, so he plays from 12-2, me from 2-4, and then the headliner =
goes on after my sister does a half-hour interperetive dance!  Sick lineup!=
".  They always push the artist you want to see off into the nether hours t=
o force you to watch them and stack paper for the bar all night, and styles=
 frequently clash, not to mention skill levels.=0A=0AFew folks are putting =
much thought into choosing anyone but the headliner du jour, and many not p=
utting much thought into that slot, either.  The gigs I get in those sphere=
s come not from my releases or my reputation, but generally always from a p=
romoter having a few drinks with me or one of my collaborators and going, "=
ey, dude, would you open for *insert big name here* for like, $50 next week=
end?  We're soooooooo strapped for cash and err........  I love your music!=
".  I generally wince, say, "uh... aight.." and have a good fun gig that do=
esn't pay.=0A=0AIn the underground when I get booked it's for my music, not=
 my chumminess to anybody or my shameless taking of low cash for promoter "=
friends".  I'm pretty distanced from the UG these days though, which sucks.=

>When DJs become promoters (or vice versa), opening slots go to those folks 
>these days.  It's one of the most annoying behaviors I've seen lately.  
>"I'm throwing the party, putting up all this money, and my boy so-and-so 
>hooked up the sound, so he plays from 12-2, me from 2-4, and then the 
>headliner goes on after my sister does a half-hour interperetive dance!  
>Sick lineup!".  They always push the artist you want to see off into the 
>nether hours to force you to watch them and stack paper for the bar all 
>night, and styles frequently clash, not to mention skill levels.
>
>Few folks are putting much thought into choosing anyone but the headliner 
>du jour, and many not putting much thought into that slot, either.  The 
>gigs I get in those spheres come not from my releases or my reputation, but 
>generally always from a promoter having a few drinks with me or one of my 
>collaborators and going, "ey, dude, would you open for *insert big name 
>here* for like, $50 next weekend?  We're soooooooo strapped for cash and 
>err........  I love your music!".  I generally wince, say, "uh... aight.." 
>and have a good fun gig that doesn't pay.
>
>In the underground when I get booked it's for my music, not my chumminess 
>to anybody or my shameless taking of low cash for promoter "friends".  I'm 
>pretty distanced from the UG these days though, which sucks.
>
>-gc

>-----Original Message-----
>From: AndyW [mailto:andy@saturn5.com]
>Sent: Sunday, November 26, 2006 1:37 PM

>Subject: [sfraves] Jeff Mills & What the Fuck is Wrong with San Francisco?

>
>So Jeff Mills played last night.  Sound was good, the guy showed, he was
>playing a smoother more mature version of what I'd hoped he'd play.  By
>the end of the few hours he played, I felt I'd been educated and given an
>opprtunity to finally see one of my musical heroes.  Minimal cuts and
>deeper tracks often being layer to create tastefully layered collages,
>some braver sounds with polyrhythmic elements usually more typical of NYC
>or UK techno, the people were great, teases going on for several tracks
>before dropping into genre defining works like "the bells".  A handful of
>those moments where the elements of of one track have been reduced to 8
>no... 16 no... 32 bars of all treble cranked snares with the crowd eating
>it up, hands in the air, before pulling the pin on that grenade and
>exploding into another bass and percussion driven grinder.  At times
>driven by the repeated chanting of a soulful voice against sparse piano
>chord stabs, other times setting it up with the plingy music box
>percussion doing call and response with the looming basslines and driving
>909 he's best known for, almost every mix totally craft.  The type of
>pressure mixes where a masterful control of the mixer allowed tension to
>be built across a third piece of music where 2 tracks overlapped, traded
>voices, pressurized and shot out into a new idea using only volume and
>equalization.
>
>And the crowd was *DOWN*, fucking way good times were had by most if not
>all.
>
>Followed by...
>
>DJ Seven?
>
>Are you fucking serious, hope the favor or whatever went down was worth
>it.  Waiting behind Jeff Mills without even seeming particuarly polite or
>aware of the fact that we'd just like more passion and science, neither
>his respect nor enthusiasm seemed at all bonafide.  Fumbling along like a
>guppy with a hardon, the local name in my experience more synonymous with
>unsolicited email promotion than bringing anything new or interesting to
>the SF scene, we made a fucking ass of ourselves.  A couple mixes as he
>flopped between hyphenated genres was all it took to get me the fuck out
>of there.
>
>Nevermind that I ran into at least 25 DJs and/or producers in the crowd
>who would have done a better job, put records out, have a definitive style
>and done the time.  Or thought of at least 25 more that would have been
>great.  Never mind that the greater San Francsico area is home to some of
>the best in the genre period.  Or maybe we could have had one of SF's
>distinctive twist on house legend come in.  Or maybe a respectful silence.
>Or maybe anything but a freaking spammer who social climbed his way into
>our club culture on an email list that most of us never signed up for...
>of all things last night playing whack ass boring cheese breaks and
>progressive miasma after an extended dancefloor dicking from the mutha
>fucking Wizard of the 313, a guy so synonymous with proper high intensity
>DJing that for years "Jeff Mills" was a slang for mdma in Britan.
>
>Maybe they wanted the place to clear out fast, I'm not sure.  If so, why
>bother with music.  I don't think there was a soul in there that would
>have had a problem with being let down hard to the sound of tinnitus,
>promises to keep in touch and strangers around them mumbling about what
>they'd just experienced and where to find a proper hash brown at 4am.
>
>Thanks to the promoters for footing the bill for bringing out who is
>generally considered the world's first proper techno DJ, but *wow* that
>was a weird choice for follow up.  Some 5 + years ago when DJ Seven first
>showed up putting out his "picks" list it might have been ok (his skills
>were horrible then but at least he was playing tasteful housey stuff that
>would have been a lot more appropriate)... but WTF was that.  I think even
>DJ Seven was capable of far better, but his heart wasn't in it or
>something, maybe he just didn't know or thought it wouldn't be right to
>play techno or minimal house after Mills (it was just sounding seriously
>"make the drunk marina chicks dance" clubber trash).  Jon Williams would
>have killed in that slot.  Eli Bingham would have killed in that slot.
>Or Twerk, or Jonah Sharp, Kit Clayton or Andre Lucero.  Mark Johns, Monty,
>Joe Rice, tons of folks who know what the fuck and what for would have
>done great (and I won't even go into my "San Jose gets the dick again"
>rant).  So many serious veteran deck technicians, techno luminaries, mad
>collectors, genius producers, and we get *ow my head* a club scene staple
>who has so little to do with the local techno community.
>
>Look at what brought that decision on, and fix it.  So much talent in this
>town, so many people who would have done that slot right but apparently
>the favor network still rules... just ridiculous in light of all the
>talent (just in the audience last night let alone in town) that would have
>killed for that slot.  Shit, Mark Johns and Monty played other slots that
>night and they would have been more appropriate by an order of magnitude.
>Just *irksome* to hear something that good followed by something so blah
>while I'm bumping into local techno badass after local techno badass all
>night at a $25 show with the expectation that I'm gonna be experiencing
>some of the best in the world supported by (hopefully) the best in town.
>
>This was like booking me after Tipper or Freq Nasty at a breaks party or
>something.  No, take that back, I think I'd shred after those guys and if
>the crowd wasn't getting it at least I'd be hitting the best I know how.
>Cause when you love this life, you don't "kinda have intercourse" and you
>don't go half-ass when they hand you the keys to the whip.
>
>Think this is the crabbiest I've felt since that time Laidback Luke and
>Tim Taylor played at an Area51 here and all there kids just sat there on
>the floor with their fucking pacifiers and slot machine eyeballs giving
>each other back rubs waiting for Mystere to come on.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Jeff Mills & What the Fuck is Wrong with San Francisco?

it was actually a Spundae and Blasthaus event.  Alain is Spundae's
resident and typically does open for most Spundae events in San
Francisco.  Techno he may not be, but the connection is there (also,
it was his birthday).

Seven i have no idea.

and yes, Chris, we missed you. i was actually looking for you all
night.  i was scanning the dancefloor for the big, old, sweaty white
guy but all i found was Andy and Shane.

On 11/27/06, Chris Jackson <cjax@sbcglobal.net> wrote:
> Ok.  So I'm sure that anybody who was looking, didn't see me on Saturday
> night.  I was supposed to come back into town on Saturday afternoon, but my
> travel plans got all fucked up....so I missed the show.  I was really
> bummed.  But since talking to a few people and reading a few reviews....it
> was probably a good thing!  If I was there and saw that DJ Seven was playing
> after Mills, I might have thrown a bottle or glass at him or something.
> Seriously.  To hear he was standing back there like some fucking lost
> puppy...waiting for Mills to let him play his crap-ass cover tune mash-up
> white labels makes me sick.
>
> Wasn't Blasthaus involved with this night??  Alain Octavio??  WTF??  I don't
> give a fuck how surprised everybody was with his/her [ok...is this a fucking
> man or woman?  i've heard both...and have been lucky enough NOT to witness
> it's music first hand] non-progressive set....it isn't a TECHNO DJ!!  Why
> the fuck would you have a non-techno DJ play at a Jeff Mills show?  Avalon
> LA showed the bay area how to pick a supporting cast for Mills when they had
> Hawtin play with him on Friday night.  SF's answer:  Alain Octavio and DJ
> Seven?  Did the organizers think that nobody would show unless they put a
> couple local, less capable, played out douche bags on the bill??  Like Andy
> said, and MANY have confirmed....it was like a techno DJ pick list in there
> Saturday night!  Not one of those guys/girls got the nod....but DJ Seven
> did?  LOL!  Dr. Toolbox and his self promoting spam-a-thon?  Nice.  Way to
> go SF!  Truly ground breaking stuff.  I'm glad I wasn't there, because I
> would have the same nasty taste in my mouth as all the other local techno
> DJ's/producers who got the shaft in favor of mediocrity.
>
> =(
>
> Chris
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: AndyW [mailto:andy@saturn5.com]
> Sent: Sunday, November 26, 2006 1:37 PM
> To: SFR
> Subject: [sfraves] Jeff Mills & What the Fuck is Wrong with San Francisco?
>
>
> So Jeff Mills played last night.  Sound was good, the guy showed, he was
> playing a smoother more mature version of what I'd hoped he'd play.  By
> the end of the few hours he played, I felt I'd been educated and given an
> opprtunity to finally see one of my musical heroes.  Minimal cuts and
> deeper tracks often being layer to create tastefully layered collages,
> some braver sounds with polyrhythmic elements usually more typical of NYC
> or UK techno, the people were great, teases going on for several tracks
> before dropping into genre defining works like "the bells".  A handful of
> those moments where the elements of of one track have been reduced to 8
> no... 16 no... 32 bars of all treble cranked snares with the crowd eating
> it up, hands in the air, before pulling the pin on that grenade and
> exploding into another bass and percussion driven grinder.  At times
> driven by the repeated chanting of a soulful voice against sparse piano
> chord stabs, other times setting it up with the plingy music box
> percussion doing call and response with the looming basslines and driving
> 909 he's best known for, almost every mix totally craft.  The type of
> pressure mixes where a masterful control of the mixer allowed tension to
> be built across a third piece of music where 2 tracks overlapped, traded
> voices, pressurized and shot out into a new idea using only volume and
> equalization.
>
> And the crowd was *DOWN*, fucking way good times were had by most if not
> all.
>
> Followed by...
>
> DJ Seven?
>
> Are you fucking serious, hope the favor or whatever went down was worth
> it.  Waiting behind Jeff Mills without even seeming particuarly polite or
> aware of the fact that we'd just like more passion and science, neither
> his respect nor enthusiasm seemed at all bonafide.  Fumbling along like a
> guppy with a hardon, the local name in my experience more synonymous with
> unsolicited email promotion than bringing anything new or interesting to
> the SF scene, we made a fucking ass of ourselves.  A couple mixes as he
> flopped between hyphenated genres was all it took to get me the fuck out
> of there.
>
> Nevermind that I ran into at least 25 DJs and/or producers in the crowd
> who would have done a better job, put records out, have a definitive style
> and done the time.  Or thought of at least 25 more that would have been
> great.  Never mind that the greater San Francsico area is home to some of
> the best in the genre period.  Or maybe we could have had one of SF's
> distinctive twist on house legend come in.  Or maybe a respectful silence.
> Or maybe anything but a freaking spammer who social climbed his way into
> our club culture on an email list that most of us never signed up for...
> of all things last night playing whack ass boring cheese breaks and
> progressive miasma after an extended dancefloor dicking from the mutha
> fucking Wizard of the 313, a guy so synonymous with proper high intensity
> DJing that for years "Jeff Mills" was a slang for mdma in Britan.
>
> Maybe they wanted the place to clear out fast, I'm not sure.  If so, why
> bother with music.  I don't think there was a soul in there that would
> have had a problem with being let down hard to the sound of tinnitus,
> promises to keep in touch and strangers around them mumbling about what
> they'd just experienced and where to find a proper hash brown at 4am.
>
> Thanks to the promoters for footing the bill for bringing out who is
> generally considered the world's first proper techno DJ, but *wow* that
> was a weird choice for follow up.  Some 5 + years ago when DJ Seven first
> showed up putting out his "picks" list it might have been ok (his skills
> were horrible then but at least he was playing tasteful housey stuff that
> would have been a lot more appropriate)... but WTF was that.  I think even
> DJ Seven was capable of far better, but his heart wasn't in it or
> something, maybe he just didn't know or thought it wouldn't be right to
> play techno or minimal house after Mills (it was just sounding seriously
> "make the drunk marina chicks dance" clubber trash).  Jon Williams would
> have killed in that slot.  Eli Bingham would have killed in that slot.
> Or Twerk, or Jonah Sharp, Kit Clayton or Andre Lucero.  Mark Johns, Monty,
> Joe Rice, tons of folks who know what the fuck and what for would have
> done great (and I won't even go into my "San Jose gets the dick again"
> rant).  So many serious veteran deck technicians, techno luminaries, mad
> collectors, genius producers, and we get *ow my head* a club scene staple
> who has so little to do with the local techno community.
>
> Look at what brought that decision on, and fix it.  So much talent in this
> town, so many people who would have done that slot right but apparently
> the favor network still rules... just ridiculous in light of all the
> talent (just in the audience last night let alone in town) that would have
> killed for that slot.  Shit, Mark Johns and Monty played other slots that
> night and they would have been more appropriate by an order of magnitude.
> Just *irksome* to hear something that good followed by something so blah
> while I'm bumping into local techno badass after local techno badass all
> night at a $25 show with the expectation that I'm gonna be experiencing
> some of the best in the world supported by (hopefully) the best in town.
>
> This was like booking me after Tipper or Freq Nasty at a breaks party or
> something.  No, take that back, I think I'd shred after those guys and if
> the crowd wasn't getting it at least I'd be hitting the best I know how.
> Cause when you love this life, you don't "kinda have intercourse" and you
> don't go half-ass when they hand you the keys to the whip.
>
> Think this is the crabbiest I've felt since that time Laidback Luke and
> Tim Taylor played at an Area51 here and all there kids just sat there on
> the floor with their fucking pacifiers and slot machine eyeballs giving
> each other back rubs waiting for Mystere to come on.
>
> fknsrsly.
> andyw

From: fr33st4t3 <freestate@hossfest.com>
User-Agent: Thunderbird 1.5.0.8 (Macintosh/20061025)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-2022-JP
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Re: Jeff Mills & What the Fuck is Wrong with San Francisco?

First off, Mills rocked! It's about time...

However...as far as the closer (DJ Seven)...
> (it was just sounding seriously 
> "make the drunk marina chicks dance" clubber trash)
Unfortunate truth: Drunk marina chicks spend lots of money on booze.

While I absolutely agree that a) there are some great REAL techno DJs in
town that should have been playing this set and b) the choice of DJ
Seven lacks integrity, from a club's perspective (and certainly Mighty's
- given the run-of-the mill events they often throw) he's a good pick.
Why? Because in making those drunk marina chicks dance, he makes the
club money.

I HATE it when it comes down to that, but I think that the choice here
was more of a business decision than any other motivation. This is a
common occurance around town these days, and it seems like many venues
pass up on the chance for something artistic and original (read: GOOD)
in favor of a "sure thing".

Meh....

//Derek

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: Jeff Mills & What the Fuck is Wrong with San Francisco?

it was a great lineup and great venue.  but this is the thing about SF
nightlife right now.  it's competitive and whether or not your
crew/party has a regular and loyal following...you still need to
promote your ass off.

Spundae has a following.  Blasthaus has a following.  in addition to
that, Spundae has some of the widest reaching promotions in the bay
area (and Alain is one of the reasons it is so good).

by lineup alone, Inception looked to be a good party.  but if nobody
sees your flyer and nobody knows the reputation of the
promoter/organizer...it doesn't matter.  no one will come.

we learned this very early on with Evil Breaks after many, many
disheartening turnouts and many dollars spent.



On 11/27/06, Spinmylifeaway@aol.com <Spinmylifeaway@aol.com> wrote:

> Stacked from closing to end, and no one showed...........  Whaaaaaa

Subject: [sfraves] Fliers (WAS: Re: [sfraves] Re: Jeff Mills & What the Fuck is
  Wrong with San Francisco?)


You bring up a real valid point, and something I've been fighting 
with.  So, I'll put it out to everyone...

Do fliers really matter in 2006 (almost 2007)?

Do peopel actually look at them, or are they just $.03 coasters and drink 
covers?  Are they useful or just landfill and something to provide jobs for 
bar backs and homeless guys looking for scratch outside the club with a 
broom.  I've seem people scrounge a half smokes cigarette before 
grabbinga  flier off the ground.

With the internet and mobile tech being what it is, are fliers just a relic 
of the past?

I've had event that we fliered the hell out of the bay area, and gotten 
shit for turn out.  Other parties I've placed an online blurb in a few 
spots and sold out.  ex-  Bondage a Go Go is now 100% online marketing 
only, and our numbers and quality are the best it's been since the days of 
the Troc.

What about large print (Bay Guardian/SFWeekly)?  Does anyone read it for 
club info?

With all of these, does the target market and demograph have much a of 
bearing?  Does one market live for fliers while another disdains them?  I 
ran a single ad in both papers above for substance and had better numbers 
than I've seen with teh past 6 months with HEAVY flier distro.   Does the 
demograph matter (80's night vs other formats)?



At 04:02 PM 11/27/2006, Bam wrote:
>by lineup alone, Inception looked to be a good party.  but if nobody
>sees your flyer and nobody knows the reputation of the
>promoter/organizer...it doesn't matter.  no one will come.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fliers (WAS: Re: [sfraves] Re: Jeff Mills & What the Fuck is Wrong with San Francisco?)

i think the demographic matters as does the party.

something like bondage a go go that has a long history and well-known
reputation probably doesn't need much more than internet promos.

but in other cases, i think flyers are absolutely neccessary.  not
everyone uses the internet as their primary means of hearing about
parties.  not everyone is in the know.  not everyone has 50 friends
that also like to go to the same types of nightlife events as they do.

At 04:43 PM 11/27/2006, Shatter wrote:

>You bring up a real valid point, and something I've been fighting with.  So, I'll put it out to everyone...
>
>Do fliers really matter in 2006 (almost 2007)?
>
>What about large print (Bay Guardian/SFWeekly)?  Does anyone read it for club info?
>
>With all of these, does the target market and demograph have much a of bearing?  Does one market live for fliers while another disdains them?  I ran a single ad in both papers above for substance and had better numbers than I've seen with teh past 6 months with HEAVY flier distro.   Does the demograph matter (80's night vs other formats)?

Most of the responses by promoters to your questions will be based on feelings and anecdotal info IMO.  Very, very few have done disciplined testing for source of business and market behaviours here.  

One might, for example, do a test with generally used marketing communications:  fliers;  email lists and advertising.  Offer a discount of some sort upon presentation at the door of flier, printed email or coupon from a print ad.  Track the results.  Simple and relatively inexpensive testing.  Printed emails are especially interesting for one can test various email lists also.

I think the test will reveal that email is the most powerful marketing tool these days.  Targeted lists are gold in every business.  Productive list development based on consumer behaviour is a challenge in the nightlife business however.  Using resources like My Space and Tribe is an obvious approach to get the low-hanging fruit.  I'm surprised that few local promoters use networking lists effectively.  A  promoter should be using every opportunity available to acquire names and emails.  Club 6 does a good job here;  as long as I have been going an employee asks each customer to sign up for their email list.  Every flier and ad should make an email addy available for signing on to a promotion list.  

As for demographics and email lists:  it might have been said with validity ten years ago that email users are those under 25.  These days computer penetration is quite high in all age and income groups.  I would think fliers are least effective among an older demographic.  Can't be bothered with collecting paper these days :-)

No matter what tool you use you will offend someone.  Flier complaints have increased dramatically in SF and action can be taken against specific clubs and promoters who use them.  Then there are the complaints about "spam."  The much reviled DJ Seven used to issue a weekly email overview of parties in the city.  I found it quite useful and was sorry when it disappeared.  The list still exists and has nearly 8,000 names on it.  Promoters might think of combining resources and producing a comprehensive online club guide.  LOL.

Apollo




<http://www.asambleapopulardeoaxaca.com/>http://www.asambleapopulardeoaxaca.com/ 

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k 
                
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"An adult is one who has lost the grace, the freshness, the innocence of the child, who is no longer capable of feeling pure joy, who makes everything complicated, who spreads suffering everywhere, who is afraid of being happy, and who, because it is easier to bear, has gone back to sleep.  The wise man is a happy child."
-Arnaud Desjardins

"Music rots when it gets too far from the dance.  Poetry atrophies when it gets too far from the music."
-Ezra Pound

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Mighty Breaks w/ DJ Friendly - Friday, Dec 1st

Mighty Breaks Presents:
Chew The Fat! featuring FRIENDLY

Friday December 1st at MIGHTY
119 Utah, San Francisco
10pm-4am, 21+, $10 at door
info and $5 presales: www.mightybreaks.com


with local rockstars
Murphstar -SEISMIC
8ball -Space Cowboys
Bam -Evil Breaks
Ding Dong -Brass Tax
Lud Dub -NetAMp
Trav -SEISMIC

On December 1st, Friendly is coming back to SF to rock the city with
his characteristic sound of funky Breaks and Electro House. It has
been two years since this SEISMIC favorite has been through town and
he has a new arsenal of tracks to drop on our eager ears.

You'll know Friendly, he's the Australian chap who's been known for
smashing up the breaks scene at clubs like Chew The Fat! And beyond.
His mission statement is simply "dirty" and he mixes it up between
breaks, electro house, bootlegs and oddities to create a bass heavy
sweat fest.

A resident at Chew the Fat, Friendly has had a string of well received
releases that have got everyone from The Plumps, Zane Lowe, Freq Nasty
and Annie Mac jumping on board to give him support. 2006 has seen him
remix the massive Justice Vs Simian monster "We are Your Friends"
under his 'Milke' guise touring China and signing to Electro House's
hottest label iO Music

This latest outing on iO Music sees Friendly dropping some electro
house gems. "It's got all the same energy and structure and sounds as
other Friendly tracks, just the kick drum is in a different position.
And as my mum always said "The kick drum does not maketh the genre",
and she was right.

"There's some really exciting stuff going on in house at the moment,
so I've been playing a bit more of it, and these tracks reflect that"

Check out some of his latest material on Friendly's MySpace page:
http://www.myspace.com/friendlybits

On 11/26/06, AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:
>
> So Jeff Mills played last night.  Sound was good, the guy showed, he was
> playing a smoother more mature version of what I'd hoped he'd play.  By
> the end of the few hours he played, I felt I'd been educated and given an
> opprtunity to finally see one of my musical heroes.  Minimal cuts and
> deeper tracks often being layer to create tastefully layered collages,
> some braver sounds with polyrhythmic elements usually more typical of NYC
> or UK techno, the people were great, teases going on for several tracks
> before dropping into genre defining works like "the bells".  A handful of
> those moments where the elements of of one track have been reduced to 8
> no... 16 no... 32 bars of all treble cranked snares with the crowd eating
> it up, hands in the air, before pulling the pin on that grenade and
> exploding into another bass and percussion driven grinder.  At times
> driven by the repeated chanting of a soulful voice against sparse piano
> chord stabs, other times setting it up with the plingy music box
> percussion doing call and response with the looming basslines and driving
> 909 he's best known for, almost every mix totally craft.  The type of
> pressure mixes where a masterful control of the mixer allowed tension to
> be built across a third piece of music where 2 tracks overlapped, traded
> voices, pressurized and shot out into a new idea using only volume and
> equalization.
>
> And the crowd was *DOWN*, fucking way good times were had by most if not
> all.
>
> Followed by...
>
> DJ Seven?
>
> Are you fucking serious, hope the favor or whatever went down was worth
> it.  Waiting behind Jeff Mills without even seeming particuarly polite or
> aware of the fact that we'd just like more passion and science, neither
> his respect nor enthusiasm seemed at all bonafide.  Fumbling along like a
> guppy with a hardon, the local name in my experience more synonymous with
> unsolicited email promotion than bringing anything new or interesting to
> the SF scene, we made a fucking ass of ourselves.  A couple mixes as he
> flopped between hyphenated genres was all it took to get me the fuck out
> of there.
>
> Nevermind that I ran into at least 25 DJs and/or producers in the crowd
> who would have done a better job, put records out, have a definitive style
> and done the time.  Or thought of at least 25 more that would have been
> great.  Never mind that the greater San Francsico area is home to some of
> the best in the genre period.  Or maybe we could have had one of SF's
> distinctive twist on house legend come in.  Or maybe a respectful silence.
> Or maybe anything but a freaking spammer who social climbed his way into
> our club culture on an email list that most of us never signed up for...
> of all things last night playing whack ass boring cheese breaks and
> progressive miasma after an extended dancefloor dicking from the mutha
> fucking Wizard of the 313, a guy so synonymous with proper high intensity
> DJing that for years "Jeff Mills" was a slang for mdma in Britan.
>
> Maybe they wanted the place to clear out fast, I'm not sure.  If so, why
> bother with music.  I don't think there was a soul in there that would
> have had a problem with being let down hard to the sound of tinnitus,
> promises to keep in touch and strangers around them mumbling about what
> they'd just experienced and where to find a proper hash brown at 4am.
>
> Thanks to the promoters for footing the bill for bringing out who is
> generally considered the world's first proper techno DJ, but *wow* that
> was a weird choice for follow up.  Some 5 + years ago when DJ Seven first
> showed up putting out his "picks" list it might have been ok (his skills
> were horrible then but at least he was playing tasteful housey stuff that
> would have been a lot more appropriate)... but WTF was that.  I think even
> DJ Seven was capable of far better, but his heart wasn't in it or
> something, maybe he just didn't know or thought it wouldn't be right to
> play techno or minimal house after Mills (it was just sounding seriously
> "make the drunk marina chicks dance" clubber trash).  Jon Williams would
> have killed in that slot.  Eli Bingham would have killed in that slot.
> Or Twerk, or Jonah Sharp, Kit Clayton or Andre Lucero.  Mark Johns, Monty,
> Joe Rice, tons of folks who know what the fuck and what for would have
> done great (and I won't even go into my "San Jose gets the dick again"
> rant).  So many serious veteran deck technicians, techno luminaries, mad
> collectors, genius producers, and we get *ow my head* a club scene staple
> who has so little to do with the local techno community.
>
> Look at what brought that decision on, and fix it.  So much talent in this
> town, so many people who would have done that slot right but apparently
> the favor network still rules... just ridiculous in light of all the
> talent (just in the audience last night let alone in town) that would have
> killed for that slot.  Shit, Mark Johns and Monty played other slots that
> night and they would have been more appropriate by an order of magnitude.
> Just *irksome* to hear something that good followed by something so blah
> while I'm bumping into local techno badass after local techno badass all
> night at a $25 show with the expectation that I'm gonna be experiencing
> some of the best in the world supported by (hopefully) the best in town.
>
> This was like booking me after Tipper or Freq Nasty at a breaks party or
> something.  No, take that back, I think I'd shred after those guys and if
> the crowd wasn't getting it at least I'd be hitting the best I know how.
> Cause when you love this life, you don't "kinda have intercourse" and you
> don't go half-ass when they hand you the keys to the whip.
>
> Think this is the crabbiest I've felt since that time Laidback Luke and
> Tim Taylor played at an Area51 here and all there kids just sat there on
> the floor with their fucking pacifiers and slot machine eyeballs giving
> each other back rubs waiting for Mystere to come on.
>
> fknsrsly.

Mime-Version: 1.0

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fliers (WAS: Re: [sfraves] Re: Jeff Mills & What
  the Fuck is Wrong with San Francisco?)


Personally, I have done a lot of testing and such over the last few years.

In truth I'm more asking the non promoters what they think.  As a patron, 
do you want to get hit with the "flier gauntlet" when walking out a 
club?  How happy are you to come bakc to your car and find it decorated all 
over with fliers for stuff you may or may not give two shits about?  Do you 
actually look at the fliers outside of a club or do you take the thing long 
enough to shut the flier guy up and then toss it once you get past him?

Personally, opt in mail lists & social systems are my favorite places to 
market.  I've had a few people complain with some of my mega profiles 
(2300+) about "Stop spamming me" (1 event everyone 1-2 weeks is spamming?) 
and my response is always "If you don't like it, you can unfriend me" which 
you have to admit is a lot easier than trying to "UNSCRIBE" (sic) from the 
old majordomo for people who arn't geeks.

Myspace is of course the ultimate spam tool, but you get as many people 
from Kansas adding you as you do local people half the time.  Always 
surprised me when I get responses to things when I'll put a single bulletin 
out.      It's funny that your best targets on MySpace are those with the 
least amount of active friends.

At 09:02 PM 11/27/2006, Apollo wrote:
>Most of the responses by promoters to your questions will be based on 
>feelings and anecdotal info IMO.  Very, very few have done disciplined 
>testing for source of business and market behaviours here.


Shatter

http://www.sonic.net/~shatter

Soulseek:  Shatter242
http://www.imeem.com/  Shatter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fliers (WAS: Re: [sfraves] Re: Jeff Mills & What  the Fuck is Wrong with San Francisco?)

I think its worthwhile to distinguish "hand to hand marketing" from bulk fl=
ier distribution.  When someone comes up to me at a party the right way and=
 hands me a flier I am much more likely to attend their party than if they =
leave a flier on my car or in a stack at a record store or ...=0A=0AMaybe i=
ts just nostalgia for the days when the only way to hear about a party was =
by a flier handed to you at a party or from a friend that was handed a flie=
r, but I don't really think so.  Here's the thing.  When you, or your highl=
y trained personnel, hand someone a flier they have the opportunity to vet =
the person at least a little bit.  Is the person dancing?  Are they into it=
?  Do they have the right energy and attitude?  This is someone you want to=
 hand a flier to.  And there is a right way to do it.  The result is (somet=
imes/often) a better crowd, a better vibe, fewer problems, etc.=0A=0AIn con=
trast e-mails lists are essentially unvetted.  You simply can't know who th=
e person subscribing to your e-mail list is.  Maybe they say they're a rave=
r from Kansas, when they are really a cop or drug dealer right down the str=
eet.  Wonder why your renegade party got busted?  Maybe you emailed the pho=
ne number with directions to the police.  Not everyone has positive reasons=
 for wanting to be on your e-mail list or MySpace friends list.=0A=0ASo I s=
till value the flier thats handed to me by the pretty girl with the knowing=
 smile, or the guy with the furry backpack that can dance like the wind, or=
 simply someone I know or I'm sure I've met somewhere somehow before.=0A=0A=
But the truth is I hear about most parties via email now simply because I'm=
 not out there that much. :(=0A=0APeace,=0A=0APeter=0A=0A----- Original Mes=

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fliers (WAS: Re: [sfraves] Re: Jeff Mills & What the Fuck is Wrong with San Francisco?

I see the problem with wanting to attract people who would want to
enjoy your event, but also not being able to tell who that might be,
*and* bring in new people to enjoy it.

When I look at the flyer, I look for names I recognize. If I don't
recognize names, I start looking for genres. I keep this in the back
of my mind, and if I'm feeling D&B, I know where I could go.

Also, one of the things that stands out for me is when I get a flyer,
and it has a DJ that is spinning at the event I'm currently at - which
is cool. It reminds me of Amazons "other people have purchased" idea;
it would be cool to have a section near the front that has the line-up
of the DJs (novel concept), but also a flyer timeline of where else
they'll be playing. If you like them, you can see where they'll be
next. If you have to leave, but know they're good, you can grab a
flyer and check them out there.....

Sometimes it feels like DJs are afraid to share their genres - just
because YOU aren't playing castles-in-the-sky-trance on Thursday night
doesn't mean you can't recommend somebody else that is similiar. ;)

- buzz.
On 11/28/06, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
> I think its worthwhile to distinguish "hand to hand marketing" from bulk flier distribution.  When someone comes up to me at a party the right way and hands me a flier I am much more likely to attend their party than if they leave a flier on my car or in a stack at a record store or ...
>
> Maybe its just nostalgia for the days when the only way to hear about a party was by a flier handed to you at a party or from a friend that was handed a flier, but I don't really think so.  Here's the thing.  When you, or your highly trained personnel, hand someone a flier they have the opportunity to vet the person at least a little bit.  Is the person dancing?  Are they into it?  Do they have the right energy and attitude?  This is someone you want to hand a flier to.  And there is a right way to do it.  The result is (sometimes/often) a better crowd, a better vibe, fewer problems, etc.
>
> In contrast e-mails lists are essentially unvetted.  You simply can't know who the person subscribing to your e-mail list is.  Maybe they say they're a raver from Kansas, when they are really a cop or drug dealer right down the street.  Wonder why your renegade party got busted?  Maybe you emailed the phone number with directions to the police.  Not everyone has positive reasons for wanting to be on your e-mail list or MySpace friends list.
>
> So I still value the flier thats handed to me by the pretty girl with the knowing smile, or the guy with the furry backpack that can dance like the wind, or simply someone I know or I'm sure I've met somewhere somehow before.
>
> But the truth is I hear about most parties via email now simply because I'm not out there that much. :(
>
> Peace,
>
> Peter
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Shatter <shatter@sonic.net>

> Personally, I have done a lot of testing and such over the last few years.

> In truth I'm more asking the non promoters what they think.  As a patron,
> do you want to get hit with the "flier gauntlet" when walking out a
> club?  How happy are you to come bakc to your car and find it decorated all
> over with fliers for stuff you may or may not give two shits about?  Do you
> actually look at the fliers outside of a club or do you take the thing long
> enough to shut the flier guy up and then toss it once you get past him?
>
> Personally, opt in mail lists & social systems are my favorite places to
> market.  I've had a few people complain with some of my mega profiles
> (2300+) about "Stop spamming me" (1 event everyone 1-2 weeks is spamming?)
> and my response is always "If you don't like it, you can unfriend me" which
> you have to admit is a lot easier than trying to "UNSCRIBE" (sic) from the
> old majordomo for people who arn't geeks.
>
> Myspace is of course the ultimate spam tool, but you get as many people
> from Kansas adding you as you do local people half the time.  Always
> surprised me when I get responses to things when I'll put a single bulletin
> out.      It's funny that your best targets on MySpace are those with the
> least amount of active friends.
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Underground busts?

Not a speakeasy, and not underground, but if you're talking about the 
south bay (sunnyvale) venue, I was there for the bust on Halloween. 
Farily uneventful of a bust, other than the 10 cop cars, and cops 
snapping photos of everyone and everything. Kids spilled out all over the 
paring lot and streets.

It was one of those cases of a venue that was technically permitted, but 
c'mon who are we kidding, they're throwing raves, and Sunnyvale PD isn't 
that stupid.

Apparently the owner put in a proper fire exit after that and they tried 
to use it 3 weeks later. Sunnyvale PD wasn't having it, busted again.

-t

Subject: Re: [sfraves] question: John Kelley

John Kelley is quite possibly the WORST "name" deejay in the world. I've 
heard him many times, in different cities, and the guy just sucks. Can't 
mix for shit and has no personality and both deficiencies show in his 
performance (if you can call them performances). Going to "see" John 
Kelley, at an underground or otherwise, would be retarded (as is going 
to "see"  almost any deejay in my estimation). He's good as a name on a 
flyer but nothing else after that. You wanna talk about the guy that was 
in the right place at the right time and milked the resulting notoriety 
for a decade? Talk about John Kelley.

Brian from Moontribe is a great deejay.

every mistake in Kelley's mixes.  No, he isn't the cleanest mixer.
No, he isn't the best live.  But you know what?  I have seen djs like

and his is pretty fucking sweet!

Subject: [sfraves] Can I Get An Amen?

--Apple-Mail-1--280899361
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	delsp=yes;
	format=flowed

Check out the two short movies documenting the history of the Amen  
Break, which is the most sampled rhythm ever, the very foundation of  
most rap, techno and jungle, and another one of the history of the  
TB-303.

There are called Can I Get An Amen? and Bassline Bassline and are  
available on this website:  http://nkhstudio.com/#



apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm



"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path  
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and  
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras,  
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and  
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can  
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and  
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond  
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative  
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in  
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--Apple-Mail-1--280899361--

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: 12.09.06 :: Robots In The Club @ BUTTER w/ Greg J & Kevin Kind

This may be my last appearance out in the Bay Area for a while - I have some 
personal shit to attend to in my life right now and need to be introspective 
for a while. But I hope to see as many of you out as possible...

December 9th
@ BUTTER (354 11th Street, San Francisco, CA 94103)
21 +
$5 cover
10pm - 2am

ROBOTS IN THE CLUB!!!

Come hear some of the funkiest, dirtiest, nastiest old skool & nuskool beats 
around - cuz I have a feeling Butter will be blowing up!!!

With your host: KEVIN KIND

& special guests:

Greg J - Funky Cactus Records/kidbippy.com (SF)

Marc(O) - Ill Behavior//OtherWorld//Renegade Ferrets (SF)

If y'all haven't been to Butter on a Saturday night, and you love some funky 
beats, as well as stiff cocktails and folks dancing on the bar like insane 
people...then you need to come see what the hype is all about.

Marc(O)
*THWAP!*//Otherworld//Mario Bros.//The Midnightsons//Renegade Ferrets 
(SF/DC)

Upcoming:
12.9.06 @ ROBOTS IN THE CLUB (Butter, SF)
1.27.07 @ SUPERFUNKADICULOUS w/ Greg J & Myagi + MANY more (Baltimore, MD)

Message-ID: <8c97d1a70611301158y81d8e11j263c1de094df9bcc@mail.gmail.com>
Date: Thu, 30 Nov 2006 11:58:15 -0800
From: "jason hemmenway" <deceptakahn@gmail.com>
To: "Terry Estioko" <terry@hyperreal.org>
Cc: "Van Mundegaarde" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20061130114844.W81116@taz3>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline
References: <BAY110-F27CB5DE79595ED99778C0385DB0@phx.gbl>
	 <20061130114844.W81116@taz3>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: RE: [sfraves] wtf is bmg???? was Re: [sfraves] um, hello?

If someone sent mail (usually spam) and used the list email as a false
"From: address", when that mail bounces, its sent to the spoofed
"from" address.

This sort of thing was relly common in the late 90s, when worms
infected Microsoft Outlook and would send a message as the infected
person to every address in their address book.

-jasonh

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Evil Breaks: A White X-Mas - Dec. 16th

We know this is kinda last minute, but we found this snazzy little
underground space and we decided that we needed to help make this a
white Christmas for everyone. Along with the kickass local lineup, an
awesome underground spot goin from 10-5, we'll be doing a bit of a
gift exchange. If you bring a NEW, wrapped gift (valued @ $5-$10),
we'll let you in to our little show for the stupidly low price of only
$5. If you don't come prepared to participate in our fun, then the
door will cost $10 for you, so please bring a gift, and let's have
some fun with this.

Evil Breaks:
A White X-Mas
Dec. 16th, 2006
$5 w/gift, $10 w/out
Please visit our website for location details tba
www.EvilBreaks.com
10pm - 5am


Ethan (Friends and Family)
Mozaic (Nexus, Raindance)
Aaron Jae (Evil Breaks/XM/Space Cowboys)
Bam (Evil Breaks/Invibe)
Phokus (Ritual Sounds/Desert Trax)
Alxndr (LowDown/Panda Rejects)
Robb Green (Tilted Records/Shameless)


We will be limiting attendance to this party to only 200 people to
make sure that all those attending are comfortable and have a good
time, so please plan on showing up early if you want to ensure your
admittance.

--

Subject: [sfraves] Re: BSP: Mighty Breaks w/ DJ Friendly - Friday, Dec 1st

Timeslots for tomorrow.  Come one, come all!

10:00  Lud Dub
11:30  Murphstar
12:30 Friendly
2:30  Bam

11:30  8ball

2:15 Ding Dong

On 11/27/06, Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:
> Mighty Breaks Presents:
> Chew The Fat! featuring FRIENDLY
>
> Friday December 1st at MIGHTY
> 119 Utah, San Francisco
> 10pm-4am, 21+, $10 at door
> info and $5 presales: www.mightybreaks.com
>
>
> with local rockstars
> Murphstar -SEISMIC
> 8ball -Space Cowboys
> Bam -Evil Breaks
> Ding Dong -Brass Tax
> Lud Dub -NetAMp
> Trav -SEISMIC
>
> On December 1st, Friendly is coming back to SF to rock the city with
> his characteristic sound of funky Breaks and Electro House. It has
> been two years since this SEISMIC favorite has been through town and
> he has a new arsenal of tracks to drop on our eager ears.
>
> You'll know Friendly, he's the Australian chap who's been known for
> smashing up the breaks scene at clubs like Chew The Fat! And beyond.
> His mission statement is simply "dirty" and he mixes it up between
> breaks, electro house, bootlegs and oddities to create a bass heavy
> sweat fest.
>
> A resident at Chew the Fat, Friendly has had a string of well received
> releases that have got everyone from The Plumps, Zane Lowe, Freq Nasty
> and Annie Mac jumping on board to give him support. 2006 has seen him
> remix the massive Justice Vs Simian monster "We are Your Friends"
> under his 'Milke' guise touring China and signing to Electro House's
> hottest label iO Music
>
> This latest outing on iO Music sees Friendly dropping some electro
> house gems. "It's got all the same energy and structure and sounds as
> other Friendly tracks, just the kick drum is in a different position.
> And as my mum always said "The kick drum does not maketh the genre",
> and she was right.
>
> "There's some really exciting stuff going on in house at the moment,
> so I've been playing a bit more of it, and these tracks reflect that"
>
> Check out some of his latest material on Friendly's MySpace page:
> http://www.myspace.com/friendlybits
>
> --
> --------------------------
> < Brandon / DJ Bam >
>
> DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
> http://www.getbammed.com
> http://www.evilbreaks.com
>
> December 1st:  Mighty Breaks w/ DJ Friendly @ Mighty
> December 16th:  TBA
> January 27th:  Oneiromancy presents: Cyberpunk
>


--

< Brandon / DJ Bam >

> >>sweat fest.
> >>

> >>and Annie Mac jumping on board to give him support. 2006 has seen him
> >>remix the massive Justice Vs Simian monster "We are Your Friends"
> >>under his 'Milke' guise touring China and signing to Electro House's
> >>hottest label iO Music
> >>
> >>This latest outing on iO Music sees Friendly dropping some electro
> >>house gems. "It's got all the same energy and structure and sounds as
> >>other Friendly tracks, just the kick drum is in a different position.
> >>And as my mum always said "The kick drum does not maketh the genre",
> >>and she was right.
> >>
> >>"There's some really exciting stuff going on in house at the moment,
> >>so I've been playing a bit more of it, and these tracks reflect that"

Subject: RE: [sfraves] wtf is bmg???? was Re: [sfraves] um, hello?

it's an autoresponder, designed to send emails back to whoever sent 
an email to that address, but instead of responding to the list, it 
used the individual sender.  simple scripting.
